column105:
Had a scheduled 30 minute phone call with Kara that went a full hour.  She's super nice and came highly recommended from Bill Grover of Hanai Marketing Partners.  He also texted me over the weekend to say he's good friends with her and to ensure she's taken care of.  

She's super nice! Hawaiian native but went to school in Worcester and that's where she met her husband who is from Worcester.  She says she loves Massachusetts because the people were direct and no bullshit.  She says she's the same way. 

She has a Swim Academy with 8 total "Employees" this year (probably half of that as some come and go.. I asked for total for 1099 purposes) and some more contractors during the summer.  She has no payroll system right now and just pays the Employees/Contractors out of the bank account.  

Accounting team should note that she specifically asked about using Homebase as her payroll system so the team should look into if there's a Homebase Pro account similar to QB, Gusto, etc. for accountants who manage client payroll.  She likes Home base because a lot of her employees are "kids" and she has learned that the honor system didn't work as far as tracking hours.  I told her other payroll systems have that feature as well but we'd definitely be able to help set the time tracking part as part of the payroll set up.  

She said she has a bookkeeper and she said the quality was great and that she met with him a couple of times in order to get "onboarded" which was great but hasn't heard from him since.  She asked if she, as the client, should be the one reaching out to him.  She also asked where we would be if we had 2 months with her business.   

She said she set up the chart of accounts and has set up the clients / billing files as well as some reports.  She also has pulled all her statements and reconciled her accounts.  She says she just gets mixed up with the categorization of transactions.  I think it'll be a lighter Accounting Onboarding lift.  

She says she's gone over the transactions with him and hasn't heard from him in months and just heard back this week and he said he's been moving.  It's a 1 man shop so she has concerns he has the bandwidth.  She also says that he represents himself as a CPA but she can't find any record of that anywhere which made her lose trust in him.  I explained that not having the CPA doesn't necessarily mean he isn't doing a good job but also think it's illegal to say that you're a CPA if you aren't.  

The business makes around $100k annually and she says she just needs help making better business decisions (like a mini CFO) because swim lessons drop off between December - February and she always finds herself not budgeting well.  Essentially the money comes in and goes out but she's not exactly sure where.  I told her if she doesn't know that, her bookkeeper probably wasn't doing a good job.  

She has an LLC set up that she has never done anything with and then she started another business with a business partner that went south so that business is dissolved.  She asked if she should just start a new one or keep the only one.  I said if we don't need a new one than let's not start a new one but let's see what the old EIN looks like.  Compliance check and potential LLC for Caroline! I told her we'll take a look but if we're going to be setting up payroll, might be a good time to change if we are going to.  

She's 100% owner right now but says she has a operations person who has done a lot of work for free because she knows the business is just getting started so wanted to give her shares of the business.  I said we can cross that bridge if/when we're working with her and the considerations around that.  

She said she's talking to him next week and I mostly said let's see if he's done with his move and what he has for a work product but she was pretty set on moving over to us regardless of how that meeting goes.   She asked what's the best way to break up with him so gave her some pointers there and said we can even help facilitate.  I think we'd just need her QBO and should be able to handle the rest.  

I told her we'd send out discovery requests and get the proposal cooking.  Caroline to send out tax discovery documents.  A-Team, let's hold off on sending QBO instructions until after she talks to her accountant.  It would be super awkward for them to see us added before she told him she's leaving him.
column109:
We talked about pricing for a decent bit because she only had the bookkeeper and not sure what she was doing for taxes but she really liked that we offered Accounting, Payroll, and Taxes all under one roof.  

She asked if there was any packaging and said there definitely was.  Explained that the more a client does with us, the more we can be flexible with pricing cause we'll have most of the information already.   

I think the Work Items / Proposal should be the following: 

1. Onboarding (Payroll - Homebase) - $500
2. Onboarding (Accounting) - $400.  I told her for her, it'd be less clean up and more understanding her set up.
3. Monthly Bookkeeping: $200 per month
4. Tax Prep (1040c): $550. I told her she's around SCorp territory and the considerations around that.  

She really appreciated that the pricing is geared towards a small business because it's super important but she talked to Gusto and said they asked her for ALOT of money upfront.  She said for a new business owner, she appreciates that our pricing is mindful of that and she says she fully understands that when the business grows and there's more work than the prices will go up but liked that we are willing to grow with her.  

She also appreciated the non up front nature because she says she wants to be cause to trust her partners before making a significant commitment although she says she can already tell she's going to like working with us.

column105:
Caught up with Barrie for an impromptu catch up call.  It was partially to tell me that he's gathering all the documents which might take some time and also he's still sorting out / splitting the businesses with him and his brother.  Guessing their bookkeeping was comingled and he's trying to clean it up before he sends it over.   I told him if we can help with any of that than we're happy to.  

I had texted back and forth with John after which I'll also share but John gave some good intel.  I won't bore you with it cause the texts will tell the story but he's Mormon and also manipulative.  I could kind of tell that from the meeting of a series of tests to see if we're the right fit.  

He mentioned on the intro call that most of his advise will be impromptu so I think today was a test of that to see if we'd be available and if he dropped a question on us, how we'd do.  He asked about deductions for his Hard Money Loan company so I stalled and asked ALFRED quick.  He asked about going from cash to accrual and I sang and danced enough to pass I believe.  I'll post the link and research as well but  [ACTION ITEM] I think we should do some additional research / avenues we can take.  Tough without actually looking at the numbers but think we can kick the tires at least to show we're diligent.  Let's have Brian and/or Caroline help with that.  

John said Barrie provided good feedback on us and that he likes us/me.  He re-iterated that on the call and that he appreciated us taking the time to hop on the phone with him.  Again, I think it was a test.  

We'll wait for discovery docs but maybe Caroline can also reach out and say if it's easier for us to request the requests part from the previous accountant than we're happy to help.  I think that would show that we've spoken and on the same page and going out of our way to take care of the administrative/awkward interactions with previous CPAs.
column109: N/A - Discovery call of sorts. Might take longer to get to proposal stage but also think it's because it's trying to test us in a way.

column105:
Talked to Kurt for about an hour to get context to the offer letter he sent over.  

He basically runs the Carpentry and Mill side of the business (which is essentially the whole thing) and said he was a 1 man shop when he started and grew the business to 14 people.  Seems like Kurt is CEO, COO and Nik (see scouting report on the business and business owners) is essentially Chairman of the Board, CFO, President.  Kurt basically runs the business and has A LOT of influence on the business. 

The only reason they offered this was because he had a job offer elsewhere.  He said they went in full panic mode and offered him equity then offered him a pay bump the day after.  Alledgedly they were thinking of doing that already.  

Nik isn't the best business person and says it's newer to him (See debrief on fees for what he's currently doing with the business) and he's good with numbers but he's a contractor.  I said he's good with numbers as far as making a good deal but different skill set when it comes to running a business.  

Kurt thinks this is a profit share and from what I understand, these are RSUs.  My concerns with this "Opening Deal" is the following: 

1. Is there a profit share aspect? It says Salary increase + Bonus but discretionary.  

2. Ability to review the financials.  If it's an RSU play, gotta see the value & growth of the business to see if it'll be worth anything.  

3. He's not sure what say he'll have.  He's acting like a principal and feels like the deal / offer should reflect that.  The shares are NON VOTING so he can have shares but he can't really do anything with them.  I think he should at least have the rights to "Audit" the financials / tax returns if his compensation is dependent on it and this is their play to get him to stay at this company.  

4. Non Compete - Self explanatory, if it was an actual ownership deal than I would be more amendable but if it's an RSU play than no chance.  

5.  Kurt has grown the business significantly so not sure if the offer is enough for that. 

6. 10 Year vesting term is a lot.. 

Overall he said he needed someone to "Represent" him because this is all out of his depth.  I said I would have helped anyways cause he's one of my best friends but want to make sure he's not getting screwed from an offer standpoint with corporate shackles on him on top of that.  I'd say no to the deal as of now.  

Overall I think Kurt wants / deserves an Owner's stake in the company and he's getting heavily restricted long vesting RSUs.
column109:
Kurt is going to bring me in as an advisor for his equity deal.  They use a Fractional CFO right now with a bookkeeper and from what I hear from Kurt they are probably both ass.  The CFO is in his 60's and Kurt suspects he does everything on paper.  

It would be aggressive if Kurt said "Hey, I'm bringing in my advisor to review these RSU grants. Also fire your CFO and install my CPAs to replace your finance department".  

So we'll "Comp" this negotiation and once Kurt gets in there, we'll provide feedback on how we're better and Kurt will then install us into the business.  

I have to be mindful not to be a dickhead with this negotiation because this is basically discovery for a long term Bookkeeping & Fractional CFO services prospect.  Kurt specifically asked if we do CFO services and I said 100%.  

They are probably paying this dude $250+ per hour and no idea what they are doing for bookkeeping.  

Kurt said he has a ton of leverage here (Biz might fold if he leaves) and if he's going to be financially tied to the company, he's going to want to make sure the numbers are crisp.

column105:
Kurt & Melissa facetimed me to tell me that they are expecting their second child (Boy) and to catch up in general.   

Kurt also just got offered an equity partnership type of arrangement at his company so asked if we'd be able to review it.  I'll take a look at it but also might toss it into ALFRED as a check.  We can also have BB take a look if we really wanted to.  

For background, Kurt started a carpentry business with his father which basically got absorbed by a company and now they are offering him equity in the company.  I'm guessing it'll be pretty plain vanilla but we'll kick the tires on it.  

Kurt also said that the "CEO" of the company is a tradesman and is very skilled at what he does but is not a great businessman.  I feel like we hear this a lot... 

I was a groomsmen in Kurt's wedding so pretty close friend of mine.  Thinking this could be parlayed into the business client as well but let's get him a seat at the table first.  

We'll toss Matty / Brian on this one.  Might be good for Caroline & Mark to shadow as well as equity instruments are always good to learn
column109: Equity Compensation Analysis - Doing this complimentary with hopes of landing the overall business he's working at.

column105:
Had a 47 minute conversation with Mitch: 

1. Bookkeeping Clean Up: Mitch is going to do a deep dive in 2023 because Sharon was doing a forecast and her numbers were out of whack because of the accounting numbers so Mitch said he was going to spend the evening re-categorizing transactions.   Half of me thinks this was our fault because of the change of hands in prior year and my neglect of the client during said transitions.  He noted things like HomeBot (which is their mortgage tracking software) was under advertising.  The other half of me thinks Mitch is trying to get cute with numbers because he said he's talking to some company about a merger and the budget/forecast are part of that.  Who knows but think we should level set on the accounting front and do a full scrub of prior year if we can (P24) to clean up vendors and things of the sort.  

2. Glasswing / Sharon - So Mitch hired Sharon (Consulting firm AVL) as part of a bigger deal with Liam (This was going to be a Glasswing JV from the guy who was one of the first employees of Uber) along with his wife's book of realty business.   Mitch says Sharon hasn't done much and that it has taken Liam 9 months to find a loan officer for the Glasswing JV and he has interviewed 2 people during that time.  Mitch said that Liam said for a $100k book of business, it really hasn't been worth his time and Mitch says he's not considering the ancillary revenue.  He said the idea was that Glasswing would have produced enough to cover all of Liam/Sharon's consulting fees but he hasn't even hired an originator for the branch.  


3. Motta New Contract - Point of clarification was that the $19k was for Liam/Sharon total.  He says he pays Sharon $2.5k per month and there was a $5k discovery fee and the other $5k was the retainer.  They still have some time with her but Mitch also said that Sharon was billed to him has having mortgage industry experience and she does not.. Mitch says he's asking for his money back.  He says they are billing her out at $280 per hour and that was WAYYY too high for her.  Consider the updated information in pricing as we work through our proposal.  At $2500 per month that will get him a lot but there still might be taxes on top of that.  

He mentioned that he owes us back pay because we agreed to an additional $50 per branch and I remember those numbers from when Matty was here so a longgg time ago but think we just reset on the engagement in general.   I'm not sure if $50 per JV is the right number anymore but if we said we'd do it for that much before, there's less wiggle room here.  

3. Loan processing - He said he hired a loan processer.  He used Hancock, then moved to some other company, and now hired someone who can do it internally so he might start getting some of that revenue as well.  

4. 3 Point Insurance - Mitch was talking about transferring money between 3PM and 3PI and I said it was fine because they need cash to open the business.  Thinking back, it should have probably gone to Mitch then 3PI because the ultimate idea is to form Three Point Capital where they will all roll up to.  

Weird sidenote but he HATES Thalia.  They had a mortgage process gone poor and he said Thalia said her dad had a 800+ credit score so he based the quote on that but her dad's credit score was in the high 600's which changed the rate.  Part of me thinks he probably sold her on best case scenario but final deal wasn't as advantageous.  Part of me thinks he was laying this in case word got back to us about that deal and that he potentially tried to pull something sleazy.  He went as far as to say he hopes the marriage doesn't go through.  

I would agree that Thalia needs explaining sometimes and a lot of this is difficult for her to wrap her head around but from what I know, she really tries to understand what's going on so I tend to give the benefit of the doubt to her.  Doesn't impact us directly but some tea.
column109:
Total "CFO Services" fees should be a little under the $280 per hour or $2,500 they are paying Sharon/AVL.  I'm not sure how Liam's consulting fees are factoring into this but maybe Matty/OCP research this as we come up with our pricing.  

Mitch says he's probably gonna let Sharon go at the end of the month so let's try to level set on the accounting and meet with them about all of this before 8/1.

column105:
Had a scheduled 15 minute call with Elly that turned into an hour.  Great call though, she's just super detailed because she's nervous about all of this.  She apologized a zillion times for all the questions and mentioned a bunch of times that she wants to make sure what the services are so that she doesn't take advantage of our time.  Super considerate person overall.  

I had put together an Advisory Proposal for her which I think we should leverage more going forward because it helps us from an internal pricing standpoint and think it's an easier layout for the client.  Think Matty and I can refine that template a little more as well.  

She'll be a QBO set up, Quarterly Bookkeeping, Tax Prep (Schedule C for now), and Tax Estimates.  

She basically wants to be as hands off as possible and also asked for help as far as calculating "If I get paid $100, can you tell me how much I should put into a savings account for taxes? I just want to set it and forget it".  She'll definitely be an SCorp in 2026 and will need to pay herself a salary.  I suggested once that happens than we do a Salary for all her fixed expenses that go into her personal checking.  Payroll taxes will already be withheld but then the Income Taxes on the Business income into another account.  I think we'll be able to sort it out for her.  She's most likely just going to give us access to all her bank accounts and just let us cook.  She wants to be very hands off in a good way.  

I think if we do a detailed Onboarding with her QBO than we can set up all those things off the jump and just maintain along the way.  Also it'll be good to educate her from the beginning which I think will help with trust for her to really throw us the keys.  

She wanted to start off with Quarterly bookkeeping because she didn't want to overcommit with business dollars and not be able to pay us.  She said "If we start with quarterly and you guys rock, am I committed or can I ask for monthly at that point?" I said we can be flexible and adjust as the business grows / changes.  I'll also note she says "I'm getting expenses all over the place and you guys are the most important one but I just want to make sure I'll be able to pay you guys".  

I think this will be one of those "Start small and quickly expand" type of clients.  She said multiple times she's nervous about all of this and wanted to know that we had her back which I assured her that we would.  

We can get started on the QBO set up immediately so A-Team can get that going.  Caroline already set up an estimates work item as well but she's not putting in her notice until 8/1 and the business isn't going to start until 8/15.
column109:
I'll attach the pricing sheet -  Taxes, estimates, Quarterly Bookkeeping. 

One thing to note is that we talked about getting Bookkeeping clients on billing cycles of the 1st and the 15th so we don't have clients on a zillion different billing schedules.  Let's start to implement that.  

She asked when everything was due so we talked through that.  We'll talk to her along the way but let's do the Onboarding fully upon completion (along with the taxes and estimates) with no deposit.  Quarterly Bookkeeping to start on 8/15.  

She's going to talk to her Step Dad about this as he's her "Yoda" but she says she'll talk to him and sign the proposal tomorrow.

column105:
Saw Dalen at Collin Wiseman & Brooke Freemen's wedding in Portland Oregon over the weekend.  

I've known Dalen for a couple years now through the friend group in Vegas.  He is from Colorado (we're v familiar with those types of clients) and went to CU.  He worked for MGM for a little bit then moved to Hilton where he works in Supply Management. 

I'm also in a fantasy league with him and he's always a little "Fan boy" with me but think the admiration makes him a good prospect from a Motta standpoint.  

He usually has a Suite on 16 at the Waste Management Open through his company so he's a good plug in certain areas.  Got to catch up with him a little bit during the wedding.  Great dude.  A bit on the "loud" side but good guy at heart.  

He's a lead for now.  I added all the details I knew (phone, socials, etc.) and created a blank work item (I did the same thing for Sampang as well) because I'm guessing the templates will change and didn't want to have to have to redo it.  Easier to company tasks over if/when they become clients.

Finally got to meet one of Cary's old friends, Andrew Sampang who went to the University of Oregon.  Cary had 3 of his close friends go to Oregon so growing a network there.  

He goes by "Pang" and essentially is in charge of all Brand Marketing & Partnerships for the NCAA division of Adidas.  I'm personally a Jordan Athlete but seems like he has a cool job.  He says he is looking to leave Adidas but I'm not sure for what.  If he does, I'm guessing he'll stay in the sports marketing & partnerships world.  

I don't think that industry (or Marketing in general) pays that well which is why I'm gathering he's looking for a new job and as it relates to us, I think he's a LOMAR but he's a friend and could be a good network of leads for pro athletes or people in the industry in general.  

He's a lead for now but Cary speaks VERY VERY highly of my skills and built rapport with Pang over the weekend so if he ever needs an accountant, I think he'll be the people.

Spoke w/ Blackburn regarding Synergy Evanston related to their purchase agreement and their necessary structure.  Left with more questions than answers, but that's typical with Synergy acquisitions.

Ultimate take away is that there should be two set of books, Uinta Physical Therapy & Synergy Evanston.  They technically could be two books run under one QBO Account, but would just need to install classes and put designations on transactions to differentiate them.  Additionally based on the type of transaction, Stock Purchase, they are taking ownership of Uinta's books from inception and thus we would need to get their books provided to us in order to have everything properly recorded. 

Result, I believe we need to meet with Daren and get a confirmation of what the expected intention was with their purchase and convey to them what the actual situation is and see if those two things align, and if not, figure out what needs to be done to rectify it.   Blackburn said they pretty much went about doing this in the most difficult way possible which is no surprise.

So glad to be back...ahah

BREAKING NEWS: Motta Capital has it's first portfolio client on 7/10/2025. Super early into our second year.  It's working! 

Finally caught up with Kenny about the proposal and got him to up the percentage to 2.5% and also for a contract for Bookkeeping / Taxes with Motta. 

He had sent all the statements and I set up the QBO and got it synced (even though I think it was only 2025 so there will be some importing).  If we need anything, Kenny/Damion are SUPER responsive... especially Kenny (maybe even too much).  

We also need to do some forecasting.  I went through their model briefly with the team and it was... not good.  At least if you want accurate numbers.  At least there's data in there.  

We also have access to their Nabis system (Sales and Inventory) so let's make sure we can pull all that info.  

Andrew / Grace to work on Onboarding, Catch Up, and Monthly Bookkeeping.  Matty to lead on the forecasting front with me in support.  

They are also still looking for financing so I had reached out to Blue Street Capital, Steve Femino who pointed us to Clinton Jolley, and also reached out to Kenneth Mooney of SEED to see if he know any funding sources and he mentioned Leaf Link.  

Kenny used to have some Factoring arrangement and and think Nabis/Leaf Link does that service but Kenny said they needed financials and tax returns as part of the application so this is why we're here.  

I'm not actually sure how he's filed this entity in the past so maybe that's a follow up.  

This is an accounting job for now and if we can somewhat prioritize because it's a gating item for financing, that would be great.  Technically this is a subsidiary of ours.
column109: Proposal Launched - Brian O to look at it and see if there are other work items that need to be created.  Most are just under CFO Services, Bookkeeping, and Tax but I don't know if we've made a tax one.. I also don't know what type of entity they are technically but Kenny sent over all their registration docs.

column94:
1040: Individual Return
1040: State Return
Sch B: Interest & Dividends
Sch C: Self Employed
Sch D: Capital Gains / (Losses)
706: Estate Tax
1041: Trust / Estate
column105:
Talked to Barrie for about 45 minutes.  He is the CEO of John Mallouk's company (Sibi).  He is definitely an eccentric CEO and seems younger but might be older than we think. 

Super personable and charismatic guy who will shoot it to you straight and always himself always.  Very genuine and self aware guy and has a sense of humility to him.  I think he understands more than he lets on and partly and act so people skip the boring details and give it to him simply.  

He has a Commercial RE loan company where they do Hard Lending which is people who are looking for Cash really fast for flips and stuff.  So a company will propose a flip, ask him for the money, he provides short term loans, they sell the property, they get their money back and some.  

He started it with his brother who passed away this year.  When he initially brought it up you can tell it choked him up a bit.  His brother was also the finance guy and tax expert so Barrie has gone his entire life not knowing anything and relying on his brother.  He says his current tax guy is a really cheap prepper because he's relied on his brother to be his personal CFO.  He's asking us to do the same for him.  Feels like a Jason Gavan type of situation so advisory for very high net worth individuals.  

He has a bunch of businesses (including this business and Sibi) and said he'd need us to do the Duke Silver LLC (for now.. he says he has other so think this is a try out) and also his Sister in law's returns including his brother's estate.  He also had an old business partner that passed away and he manages the estate for that as well.  Seems like he's taking care of their families which I find admirable.  I'll lay out the returns below.  Caroline is aware of this so I think we'll know more about these Prospects post discovery docs.   

He doesn't need any Bookkeeping because it's a pretty lean business but he emphasized that he needs tax planning and strategizing.  He has A LOT going on and usually just had his brother do everything so he's hoping we can fill that void in his life (his words not mine).  

He asked a bit about fees and said most of his questions are going to be Impromtu and I emphasized that's what we do and never appreciated hearing clients get billed for 15 minute phone calls.  That resonated with him.  

Overall he wants to have that same way of life with his brother where he didn't have to do anything and is very hands off.  He knows it'll cost him money but he's one of those people who wants to be hands off and let the people do what they do.  

We brought up financial planning and he says he's at Merrill Lynch and they have all his assets and the estates assets but he was visibly annoyed because he says they always explain it to him in such technical terms and leads to him having more questions / confusion.  

EMPHASIZING that when dealing with him, we want to basically explain it like we're explaining it to a six year old.  

This could be a financial planning lead for Mark as well.  He doesn't seem overly satisfied with them and said something to the effect of "Why do I pay you the 0.8% management fee if you're not telling me anything I can understand".  


ACTION ITEMS:

1. Caroline will send discovery documents with adding some Ad'Hoc requests for some of the other returns he asked us to help with.  

2. Brian O to create a contact for Duke Silver LLC (he took an intake form right before the meeting).  The business contact wasn't created so flag that for Tekyz as well.  

3. Brian O to hold off on the other work items until we get discovery docs.  It will most likely be like 5 work items but we don't have enough details yet.  

4. Even though it's a Tax Client. Caroline to add the "QBO Access" as well so that we can get a feel for numbers.
column109:
This will be like a Cam type of structure.  Brian to work with Caroline / Grace to get one of those Advisory Pricing Sheets going with all the returns below and things he'll most likely need (Quarterly estimates, planning, ad hoc hours, etc.) and we can come up with a Advisory plan for him.  Caroline to spearhead. 

Work item List: 

1. 1040 (Married Filing Jointly) - Barrie
2. 1040 (Widowed Sister in Law)
3. 1040 (Other Partners family)
4. Estate for Widowed Sister
5. Estate for Old Partner
6. Duke Silver LLC Biz Return - Not sure what type of biz

Note John wants to be part of the Affiliate Program so he'll get a Rev Share. We need to set that program up and see what types of percentages based on what services.  I did research on it awhile back.  For United Financial Planning Group so let's refresh ourselves on that.

column105:
Caught up with Austin for a full 45 minutes.  I doubt he'll be a client in 2025 but he'll definitely be a referral partner and affiliate.  This one might be a good recording for Brian O to watch and read the transcription because this was essentially a Business Development meeting for a new Channel.  

Austin does a lot of things: 

1. He works for Tech Launch Solutions.  I think I had him as a recruiter for Blue Signal but he says he doesn't do that anymore.   Tech Launch Solutions is a NO COST service to businesses to review their IT Infrastructure and Software Licenses and help them build if necessary.   Not like an IT consultant but even Adobe licenses and stuff like that.  He has distribution contracts with 766 vendors where they get wholesale pricing (he says it's roughly 21% off) so he can almost always get the client their same license but for cheaper.  They'll also make sure you have the right softwares / licenses for your business at no cost to them.  They get a 8% - 25% commission off the licenses they sell so it's the vendor that pays them.  

He says he works with CPA firms all the firm because they a warm with business owners, know how much they are paying for IT services, and understand the financial savings.  He was going to send over Marketing Materials, Agreements, etc. 

2.  Titan Consulting.  He basically is a brokerage for all services including CPAs.  Basically he just brokers referrals.  If someone needs a CPA, he sends them to us and gets a rev share from it.  

He says they don't sell but their strategy is to work with channels like CPA firms to get new clients.  He also says he has standing Monthly/Quarterly meetings with all of his referral partners where they bang through a list of referrals for us and we provide any potential referrals for him.  I said we also have a rev share / affiliate program for any clients he sends our way.  

3.  Dev.Ai - He has an Agenic Ai platform (who doesn't) that he'll send our way as well.  I told them we already do that but it'll be cool to see what they have going on for recon purposes.  


We didn't talk about Peoria Commerce at all which is strange.  Maybe he had a different CPA partner for that one or maybe he's just waiting to see what the rev share would be.  

I think I mocked up a rev share agreement when we were talking to Amir and think I said we should start building out an Affiliate program at that point so here's our chance.

John shared texts between John/Austin Younglove who I'm speaking to on 7/10. 

Quick scouting report from John is that he's very well connected in AZ.  The text message said he was working with the Peoria Chamber of Commerce on helping them set up their 501c6 which is basically a Non-Profit that is designated for things like Sports Clubs or Business Groups like this.  

I did ALFRED / AnyQuest research, created the Karbon Contact for the PCoC as well as the work item.  

Austin said in his text that they don't have much of a budget but I think this would help us build some goodwill with the organization which might lead to business clients in the Arizona area.  Luckily we already have boots on the ground out there.  

I'll note that I should not be the one creating the Karbon contact or the work item. It shouldn't take the Managing Partner to read a couple of texts and be able to determine WHO the prospect is and WHAT they need.

Caught up with Eben via phone.  He had reached out around April cause he's looking for a change and has wanted to get more into the Accounting / Finance world.  

I used to work with Eben at Outseer (same company as P24) where Eben was in charge of revenue and billing.  Essentially, his job was to track all the deals that the sales people close and set it up within the accounting system (i.e. Once the proposal is signed than building out the revenue schedule in the system) as well as billing for consulting projects.  

Eben indirectly reported to me so didn't work with him day to day but when I did work with him, he was super diligent.  We had a giant pile of poop from Dell and Eben combed through all the details to ensure the new company was set up.  I think he'd do well in the proposals/billing role here if the position were to become available.  

He's working at BU right now and he's going to send me his resume. I'll circle back with him next week.

Talked to Harrison for 1.5 hours because we were originally supposed to get lunch but my assessment of the opportunity did not merit leaving The Dat Cave (my home office) so we had a zoom.  

...we talked for all 1.5 hours... 

I think I provided background on the first debrief but basically he is currently managing the leases for the commercial properties that his dad already established and he is, as he would say, and aspiring commercial real estate developer.  He was working on some 150 acre project that he wants to build a medical hub and talking to non profits (Shriners, Make a Wish, etc.) who might want to invest and or rent.  He needs to find $77m in order to fund this project.  

He also says he has a couple side projects such as a Denny's that is already rented out with a 20 year lease and another project of the type in the $1m range.  He says if we knows anyone that will want to invest, he pays a 1.0 - 1.5% referral fee.  

From a Tax standpoint, he uses the CPA his father uses for their business and says the guy is elite at the beginning of the call.  After I gave him the Motta rundown and ALFRED Ai, he said that he is looking to branch off on his own eventually and that the CPA is like 65 and he's 25 so he'll need to find a new accountant eventually so think he'll be a longer term prospect while being a referral channel in between.   

He also has a brother who is a lawyer but doesn't seem like they are similar really.  From what I gather, his brother is part of the LBGTQIA+ community which Harrison has no issues with, but his brother in general makes it about his sexual preferences and seems like a narcissistic person in general.  He says his brother is more left and he leans more right politically but more about his brother as a person than it is any of that stuff.  

Either way, I guess he's my "friend" here and hopefully a referral channel but he seems like a Trust Fund Baby and on the list of people asking me to hang out with them when I just want to stay at home and hang out with Brody.  

He won't be a client this year so we can just keep the LEAD work item open for communications and such.

Dat and Caroline met with Mitch Dolman because he is closing on the Mrytle Beach rental property at the end of the month and he wanted to make sure he understood how his taxes were going to look. We explained the breakdown that he'll have a schedule E with his portion of the income and his mom will have the same thing on her non-resident return with her portion. We discussed some math options on how we can possibly move some of the income to his mom since she'll get an income exclusion since she's foreign but we'll need to see how things shake out.

He told us that him and Molly are looking to add more properties to their portfolio in the future (2026/2027) and they'll want to go the LLC and trust route (opposite of what his mom wanted for their shared property). We discussed how that will look for them as well and he will reach out to us once those things start to come to fruition so that we can re-group and do it all properly.

He also gave us some background on him and Molly and their finances - basically they have a large amount of consumer debt/debt in general that they're trying to pay down and he said they're throwing everything they have to pay that off currently. He said on paper it looks like they're doing great (400k in combined w-2) but always feels like they have nothing left and just getting by. Molly also hates her job, so he said once they get some more debt paid off in 1-2 years she's going to be stepping away from it and will probably take a 150k pay cut. he said he did the math and it maths, but he was obviously stressed and just trying to get everything in order so that they can afford to do that and set themselves up well for the future.

no action items, just notes to add to their file.

Dat and Caroline finally met with Ellie from purple label after many attempts. She rescheduled the call from earlier today and then told us she might be being induced in 30 minutes but still wanted to talk through this.

She wanted to know how to avoid tax penalties at year end and discuss payroll. She said her financial advisor "who makes a lot of money" only pays himself a $55K salary so she wants to do the same because she doesn't really want to do the salary but wants the tax savings (she also doesn't really understand that her not having a salary but having an active s-corp is tax evasion but alas). So we need to help her set up Gusto for payroll and she'll probably only pay herself 50-60k. She also wants to do quarterly estimates, we explained the difference between doing it based on prior year vs on actuals, we'll send her two quotes so she can pick which option she wants to go with. She said her business income will be in line with prior year ($407K) so we can use that for estimates. Note the 407K makes the 55K salary really not make much sense but she's difficult so we can hopefully get that better aligned over time because she didn't like to hear 60/40 (but her current set up also isnt legal).

NOTE: she wants her husband to be cc'd on all of the emails for these items since she might have the baby today/coming soon regardless.

Action items:

- Brian to make three proposals:
1. Gusto onboarding
2. tax estimates (simple, safe harbor estimates - $250/quarter? defer to dat)
3. tax estimates (based on actuals) for $799/quarter

- Dat to send follow up email with all of the proposals

column94:
1040: Individual Return
Sch C: Self Employed
column105:
Elly is a hairdresser who is planning on leaving her current position at a salon to rent a chair.  She anticipates all her clientele to follow her with the transition so expects it to be business as usual.  

She has an LLC, EIN, bank account for business, applied for the business cc, August 1st will be giving her two weeks and then starting the rental in the new salon, she got the business insurance, chair rental is $450/week (makes that in 2.5 hours), made about 117k annual, $170/hour rate, works 9-4 4 days a week, some things $200/hour., they have some commission based product sales too - but that will come off of her rent so when her rent dips that’s why

She is essentially looking for whole gambit with not wanting to have to worry about touching the accounting/finance.  Thinking for Accounting it would be a light lift so would do $250 for Onboarding, $200/month bookkeeping for Denver Hair Party, and then Taxes would be 1040 w/ Schedule C for Elly in 2025.  Also she wants quarterly tax assessments, so would factor that into proposal.

2026 we will review potential S-Corp election and possible payroll services with the switch.

Talked to Mitch about Three Point Insurance and he opened it on the Colorado SoS website and applied for the EIN.  He forwarded us all the registrations docs so I added them to the work timeline.  One thing was that he opened it as an LLC but think it'll be an SCorp by the end of 2025.  

He said he was about to sign some Mega deal but some guy who's looking to invest had to go to London to meet with the company who "invented insurance" then going into the July 4th weekend so his grand plan for zillions of dollars is on hold until he can talk to that guy.  

We parlayed the conversation into talking about our services and said that Sharon (APL is the consulting firm name) had sent Mitch an email with all the reports and stuff she needs cleans up before she can make CFO recommendations.  Mitch and the person who recommended the firm recognizes that they've paid $19k to them and she's done nothing.   

I directly said to Mitch that if he paid us $19k than we would have been able to do it easily.. we just can't allocate time towards 3PM at $300 per month especially when Andrew already does weekly meetings with them.  

We came to the agreement that they'll get rid of Sharon and increase our contract to a CFO services account somewhere between the $300 they're paying now and the $5k per month they are paying Sharon.  I'd be down for the $5k per month but also that would increase our workload with 3PM significantly.   

One thing to note is that Mitch doesn't need monthly meetings with all the branches but just monthly reports to go out to them on a monthly basis.  Also nothing that 3PM will be switching to accrual method so the A-Team (accounting team) can build this client out as a CFO client.  

I saw 2 separate repeating work items for their Monthly Accounting and a lot of stale work items in general so Matty/Andrew to sync up and level set with all things 3PM as we're moving towards a CFO relationship anyways.  


Action Items: 

1. Brian O to update the Karbon Client Contact (Three Point Insurance) with all the info from the registrations such as Address, Incorporation Date, EIN, etc.
column109: I think Andrew had done some pricing on the bookkkeeping front but Andrew to sync with Matty on everything we know that's going on with 3PM right now and come up with a monthly number for them.  Maybe loop in Brian/Caroline because I think their fee will require one of those Pricing Sheets.  Maybe Grace can help with that.. 3PM has A LOT of work items so you'll need to leverage a lot of the team to get all the work we've done for them.

column105:
Caught up with Angel who is a Realtor and is the brother in law of Mitch Hamilton.  

Angel hasn't filed taxes in 2022 and seems like he's still paying off taxes from previous years.  He said he's seen money come in and quickly go out then he gets slammed with a tax bill at the end of the year.  He is an SCorp and has payroll set up via QBO (he thinks) but seems like he's spent 0 time on finance over the past few years.  He'll be another Dean Sharabi.  

He has a business account set up but hasn't used it at all and doesn't seem to be organized with all of his income / expenses.  He said he had a few bank accounts and multiple credit cards (business / personal) for his business.   

Also brought up that someone told him that it's a $200 per month non-filing fee and he added up all the months and said he's probably screwed.  

Caroline, Andrew, and Matty were on the call so they're aware of what we need to do here.  I think there's a request in Client Requests Bank to ask for bank statements or "Business Transaction Details".  Also think we have a Schedule C template in the Templates folder which should help us with the massive amount of poop for this client.  

He'll also need an abatement letter so Grace can cook up another one of those for this client!
column109:
Defer to Caroline and Matty/Andrew because this will be a a lot of poop clean up.  Build in a discount because he's family with Mitch but this is going to take us a LONG time to do so should reflect as such.  

Also add the IRS abatement letter so try to get his penalties off.  

Not sure if he'll need Bookkeeping / Payroll yet and said we need to get caught up then we'll get to planning.  The $200 per month non-filing penalty scared him so think he'll want to move on this quick!

column94:
1040: Individual Return
1040: State Return
Sch C: Self Employed
column105:
Met with Elly after a debacle of an onboarding process because she was CC'd on an email with the development team on her intake form.  We were eventually able to smooth it over and assure her that her information is safe with us.  

Matt, Caroline, and Dat met with Elly who has her LLC set up with an EIN, bank account, and applying for a business credit card.  has an LLC, EIN, bank account for business, applied for the business cc, august 1 giving her two weeks and then starting the rental in the new salon, she got the business insurance, chair rental is $450/week (makes that in 2.5 hours), made about 117k annual, $170/hour rate, works 9-4 4 days a week, some things $200/hour., they have some commission based product sales too - but that will come off of her rent so when her rent dips that’s why. The old shop took a 50% cut off the top and doesn't offer any benefits which is why she decided to go solo.  She said her clients are 100% coming with her.  

She admits that all this is not her area of expertise and she seems like she's already in a good mindset of making sure she is focusing on tasks to grow the business and not trying to wear too many hats.  We got the old "Where do I sign" early into the meeting because she said she didn't want to try to find chill accountants and we came highly recommended from the Graf's.  

Listed the services below and debriefed with Caroline/Matty about this one. I don't care who takes the lead here (Matty or Caroline) but let's send out a thank you email and discovery docs for her.
column109:
She'll be: 

1. QBO Set Up
2. Monthly or Quarterly Onboarding (she wanted to see pricing for both)
3. Quarterly Tax estimates (and compliance?)
4. 1040c Tax Return

Potential SCorp Conversion with Payroll Services down the line.  

Defer to Caroline / Matty for pricing

column105:
Sol called me because he had paid his 2024 taxes (we didn't prep but I guess he owed?) and said when he checked online, he had a $12k tax balance from back in 2017 when he was with the Brooklyn Nets.  I think he left the job and liquidated his 401k.  The standard withholdings for 401k withdrawals are 20% so if he was in a higher tax bracket than he most likely owed more.  His aunt did his taxes so guessing he didn't share the 1099 with her and Penalties / Interest have been accruing for years.  

I sent a POA request as well as a Karbon Client Task with Approval instructions.  

I don't know if we got any of his tax docs so I'll request those under his 2025 work item but think we'll need a work item for a 2017 amendment.  Grace should also start cooking up another IRS penalty abatement letter.
column109:
When we hold meetings (and other business development opportunities in Vegas), the Resorts World team usually gives me the free invite which has led to some high quality business development.  I also think they'll bless us up if we do a retreat in Vegas.  

Let's cook up a proposal for an IRS abatement for $150 and a tax return amendment for $100.

column105:
Mark and Andrew met with Meredith to help her setup QB payroll to where they can electronically file the payroll tax returns automatically for her. This was never setup unfortunately. I also brought up that I sent her a client request to finalize her 2023 tax return. We have to file 2025 Q1 & Q payroll tax returns for her manually. We already billed her like $250 and I think that is fair to get 2 Quarters competed for her. 

-Action Items

-Need to file 2025 Q1 & Q2 payroll tax returns manually and then QBO can manage it for them. QB may need 3rd party administrator.

Mark, Andrew and Grace met with Nicole for the monthly review. Nicole wanted to see the breakout of advertising and software subscriptions so they can see what they are spending and to see how they can cut costs and see what subscriptions they are paying on a monthly basis which was setup before the meeting which she liked. Overall, meeting went well. Just need to review the simpilfile costs since they pay this up front and then the client reimburses them back a for little more but it might be pennies so we will need to figure out how to reallocate this. Provided her with some insights and ways to possibly balance transfers and moving to the AMEX plum card (60 days to defer interest, 1.5% unlimited cash back if you pays 10 days after closing, and no preset limits). 

Action items:
-Need to clean up simplifile charges

The month of May and June has been working on getting his financials from Cash to Accrual. 3PM doesn't have many accruals (commissions, contract labor, and AR) and 1 prepaid (annually subscription that gets expensed each month). The progress has been working great but just fine tuning until we get it to where we need it.

Finally caught up with Joe Grassi, kind of a waste time, didnt really have much to say, really just sales call trying to get us to apply for LOC or SBA loan with Eastern Bank. Talked in circles for a little while and i said i would touch base with Dat on it when he gets back from vacation.

I met with Brian and Ann to discuss their financials and seeing where they are struggling with and getting updates on the operations. As we were talking, they seem to have AP issues and managing this along with their cash on hand. I told them I had experience in this area and provided the potential scope of work and they were extremely interested. The service would provide them complete AP management which includes monitoring all of their payables, scheduling 2 meeting a month on top of the monthly meeting which will include a customized excel spreadsheet of their total cash on hand balance, all of their payables and go over which payables they want to pay and how much and then the excel will calculate what their ending balance is. Ann is going to work on adding in all of the outstanding payables into QB for managing and tracking purposes. If we can manage their AP which I see no issues with, I think this is help them in the long run as they wait for their collections. 


Action Items
-Ann adding in all the outstanding payables
-Need to customize a proposal and pricing for full AP management services

Had Seed Directors Meeting - Mark, Nick, Ken, Will and Beth were on the call. Beth was jealous that Mark got a Suffolk ID. 

Nick and Mark discussed Medford Boat Club.  He told this crazy story about how a member was trying to sue the club because a bench fell over and he said it landed on him but it didnt. So he has been dealing with that mess and the guy sueing the club had actually spent time with him at his cape house but lawyers said he is not allowed at the house anymore and he doesnt want him there anyway as they found out he hasnt work for 25yrs and just sues people as his job it seems like. Anyway, Nick again apologized and said he would be in touch about the bookkeeping. 

SEED: went over high level items, they need to finalize companies but looking to work with 8 companies overall but not all companies would work with each clinic. SEED itself is going to be assigned a team of students and be a client of the clinic. Nicks hope is it will help reel in Chaim and Boris from bouncing around from one big idea to the next.  

Nick, said everybody needs to have the same syallabus and everybody needs to partner for midterms- not sure how Ken will handle this...

Classes for the first 5 weeks with be set up in 45mins all hands, 45mins (AI, Lawyer Clinic, guest speakers), and 45mins clinic specific time. The Lawyer Clinic will also be present a few times during the semester for office hours during class time, when teams can pop in and ask questions. 

Will is working on developing a 4 part vidoe series that will highlight was SEED does. Nick and Will are going to discuss SEED outreach ideas and get back to the group. Trying to improve on the last business leader meeting, Nick wasnt really thrilled with how Boris and Chaim ran it.

Mark caught up with Andrew Piatelli from Baystate. Just did a phone call, he was in the car driving to the meeting so a little more informal convo, mostly caught up personally. 

One thing he mentioned was the Rico, got in with a team that deals with a lot big 401ks, one of the main partners on that 401k team is actually taking as new President of Baystate Financial, so they are going to be offloading some 401ks to Rico and Andrews Team. He didnt have a lot details but seemed exciting opportunity. Andrew mentioned trying to get more 401ks under his belt with the businesses in Woburn. So that is something, I can help him out with and keep my ear open for 401k opportunities partner the Claredon Team on. Him and Rico seemed to be on better terms these days.

Mark attended Multi City Chamber Event at Kinds in Lynnfield. Overall a good crowd of people.

Talked to Mark Comerio who is the head of the Woburn Chamber of Commerce, Ive become good friends with. He runs a remediation firm with him and his wife. Love of mutual connections he is good friends with TQ, Jmac's step dad. 

David Cockreham- Principal Partner at DB2 Architecture.  He recently bought out the original founding partner, so he is stil trying to figure out the finances of running a business. He has one other Partner but the other guy is client facing focused on business building, I met him as well, I believe it was Steve, did get his business card. David is doing the categoriztion of the bookkeeping and than they are doing monthly meeting with an accounting firm out of beverly. He said they are ok but not married to them.  He wsa upset that last year, they only had him do estimate in Q1 and Q2 and told him he didnt need them for Q3 or Q4 but than he had 10k tax bill that he wasnt happy about, would of rather just paid the estimates. I got along really well with David, he is kind of a shy guy, so I started talking to him when he was standing by himself. I think he will be a client of ours in the future. 

Matthew Troisi is younger, started a bookkeeping business, he was nice, I explained our business and how we have worked with Financial Advisors, and happy to just play in the tax space and be a resource for his clients. He was very open to it, his clients are always asking for a CPA referral but hasnt found a CPA he works well with.  Only been in business about 1yr not sure how many clients he has yet.  Could be a potential Motta Contractor or buy up his business in the future. For now, a center of influence for tax and wealth management referrals. 

Gerry McCarthy -owns Mac's Landscape Contacting.  Super nice guy, older gentlemen.  He has the landscaping business that seems to do ok but he also has a big real estate portfolio, he owns the land the dunkin donut in stoneham on franklin st is on, he leases the land to the franchise owner, said that a really nice paycheck and mentioned he owns other properties. He most likely has a finance team in place but a good guy to build a relationship with. 

Leah Hancock - Founder of Placid Marketing- super nice lady, was there with her husband who is a Wakefield firefighter. Both great people, 4 years older than Mark, they both went to Wakefield. Her husband new Matt Chambers who is a Wakefield Police Officer, that I am friends with. She is still early in the launch of her marketing business, will do website build outs and general marketing consulting on social media and the overall business. She said the biggest mistake she sees is people overspending on social media ads, made me think of Monteforte. Talk a little bit about the struggles of running a business and a little shop on accounting and financial planning. They liked the idea of having everything under one roof, thye have a CPA and Financial Planner but they siad they not always on the same page.  I recommended they set up quarterly or bi-annual meetings with their team of advisors and they loved that idea. No action items but good people added to the pipeline. 

Warren Fuller- Works for USA Demolition on Winn Street in Woburn, he was there with the owner Mike Winn. Warren, recently retired from the VA and I think Mike and him are good friends so he just started working for Mike in retirement to stay busy. They mainly do large scale commercial demolition but will do residential 10% of their business. They just joined the Chamber and are doing ribbon cutting next week at their office. They have been in business for 41yrs.Warren asked about TSP plans, they are the retirement plans for federal employees. I was familiar with them because Kylee has one from when she worked at the VA, its basically the same as 401k.

Caught up with Matt Sears on the phone (he's the Drive Motor Company sales tax audit guy) because I re-sent the document request for the sales tax audit and he realized he missed a few emails from me so he was apologetic. He basically just wanted to know next steps and he's overwhelmed with the audit and what's going on. I told him we're in the discovery stage so we're just trying to gather some documents and see what NV is saying to him and what he's been sending so that we can get the lay of the land. He's going to send us some preliminary documents just so that we can start to get a feel for things while he waits on them to send their 'findings'. He thinks a lot of this is from out of state sales (meaning, someone comes in and buys a car and lives in AZ then takes it home to AZ and they need to pay the AZ sales tax) which he says they're doing by the books and the have the registrations for everything but NV wants some super specific document and its going in circles. He was on the same page as me in terms of we'll just review the docs and get the lay of the land while he waits for the findings - he didnt want us going down rabbit holes/doing extra work until we get that doc which i appreciated.   

He's going out of town for the next few weeks on saturday so he's going to try to get me everything before then - we left it as i'll review everything in the meantime to get a feel for whats going on and the scope of the work.

super nice/cool guy and very easy to talk to & he already loves us after his first convo with dat (he spoke super highly of that convo & likes that were just real & normal people) so this will probably lead to a lot more work items down the road. he asked about bookkeeping (monthly reconciliations etc.) and i explained that we're a full service firm so we can definitely help him with that if he wants it - i told him that we would reach out with some bookkeeping resources/motta info so that he can just see what we offer for the time being and get a feel for the firm which he seemed really excited about. 

Action Items:
- Caroline to email him the motta brochure that shows our different service offerings
- Caroline to review docs when they come in

Went to a quick Happy Hour with Kenny and Chris from CannaLean (it was actually on Juneteenth and they are black so I'm super celebrating the holiday).
Chris is a super good and chill dude. You can tell he's just a genuine guy and just loves cannabis. Really smart guy, he was a Chemistry / Statistics major and spent his career as a Chemist & Scientist. Kenny said he can basically take any ingredient (including sports nutrition type stuff) and turn it into a good product (like Syrup or gummies). They have a lab out here and Chris spends most of his time there. He's a personable guy but seems like he defer to Kenny for the networking & business development front. He's also a big golfer.

He brought some samples of (1) 1000 MG THC Syrup (2) 50 MG THC / CBD combo (3) CBD Syrup they are developing {This is the product they want to get into grocery stores}
 
Kenny also said he spent most of the day with Damion "talking about you actually" referring to me. He said it was good but I'm not sure in what context. I'm sure Kenny was briefing Damion on who I am because Kenny brought me on without really saying anything about me or what I'm helping with so think they did a debrief on that front.
column109: I'm not sure if Chris will be a client himself out just a contact for CannaLean but I got along with him great (I think it was partially as a vibe check for them for potential investment) and all this finance / tax stuff is foreign to him so think he'll come over.

column105:
Caught up with Tyler and his younger brother Tucker for 30 minutes.  Referrals from Tyler who says Cary spoke extremely highly of the firm and told Tyler that I am a "Fucking Wizard".  This was a "Consult" for a potential investment property but he said he's definitely going to use use for taxes at year end.  

Tyler is a childhood friend of Cary.  He got his MBA at NYU and is currently a big dick Management Consultant at E&Y Parthenon (Big 4 firm but their consulting arm) so we've commiserated about Big 4 life.  He says he's probably making close to $300k in 2025 so think he'll be a tax planning / wealth management prospect for sure.  

Tucker is his younger brother (not sure how much younger) but also knows Cary well.  He just started in the Real Estate world so he makes no money but essentially the "Brains" behind his real estate investment with Tyler mostly being the funder.  All this stuff is a very new world for Tyler so a lot of the meeting (for the both of them) was talking through tax concepts (Active vs Cap Gains vs Passive Income).

Tyler scheduled the meeting so I don't have a recording but they are looking to buy a Duplex under an FHA loan which will be a lower interest rate (although it's only 0.5% lower than commercial which gives you the state of the RE market) which means they can't transfer it to an LLC and they have to live in it for a year.   Luckily it's a duplex.  

We talked through a bunch of scenarios but Tucker is going to live in and manage the two units and the other unit is already being rented out.  Think the most efficient strategy is for Tyler/Tucker to buy the house together (and probably just Tyler is on the mortgage) and then Tyler than Lease the property to the LLC for the other side of the duplex.  This will help Tucker qualify for RE Professional status and for Tyler to be able to take 50% of the interest as an itemized deduction.  Between that and his state taxes ($10k cap but he lives in Cali so he'd paid way more than that) he'll still be able to itemize which will already help from a tax standpoint.  He'll also most likely have passive activity losses.
column109:
No proposal quite yet because this was meant to be a consult but they'll both be tax clients over the client month or so.  Seems like they want to figure this out first but I'll plant the SEED for Tyler to get on my calendar for tax planning.  He was super concerned with his increase in taxes that he was going to get demolished in taxes.. which is true.  

Tucker will be a 1040c prospect and pretty good chance he uses Motta as well.  

We can talk about pricing once we talk to them again.

column105:
Caught up with Tommy and did bring up that his last paystub has his W2 wages in California and talked though how much of a pain in the ass that would be.  

The issue is that from a "Company Optics" perspective, he's getting pressure to move to California so he's looking to get an apartment in Sacramento to appease them.  The company is a Non Profit called "Visit California" which is essentially The State of California's subsidiary for tourism.  Sort of tough message to send to not live in the state... 

He is currently supporting his gf and her daughter so they are amendable to him going back and forth.  They said they would cover flights for the first 6 months but expect him to have a primary residence in California within the year.  

We talked through the approach of getting an apartment in California and still getting wages there but if his payroll department can set up Nevada as a work location for him since he'll be working a decent amount of hours in Nevada and it would help him on state taxes.  This is similar to the New York clients we see where they have W2 wages in New York and New Jersey.  I think if he makes sure to allocate his wages and spends more than 181 days in Nevada (which he will), the state tax implications will be minimal.   Call this strategy "Sac Town Trap House". 

I put together a quick estimator for him but we don't have his wages and he was having trouble accessing all of that but said he made $155k base there and his weekly paycheck was like $1700.  

His income will go up significantly this year, he's the director of IT and building out an IT team.  He currently only has 2 help desk people and only 1 of them is good.  I said he was like James Harden and he agreed.  He said he needs a CP3 and I said that it still didn't work and he responded "At least it's the furthest he went" 

He'll get that all set up but also said when the travel expenses do dry up he was looking to run the travel expenses through an LLC he has set up.  When he was looking for jobs he was doing independent work.  Although Sean Day is among my favorite people in the world.  He has a new born in the world and think that takes priority in his life (which it should) so TJ said he'd be willing to do some independent IT work for us.  This might work out because TJ lives up the street.  

He said he'd send us his 2024 tax return (we only asked for 2023 and 2022..) and said he'd take care of the payroll stuff but definitely wants to start using us for taxes / planning since his income just went up significantly.  He said he wanted to get his finances in order in general so I think this will be a financial planning prospect generated by taxes... plus an IT resource.

Zoom Meeting summary for Thomas Johnson and Dat Le (06/20/2025)

Quick recap
The meeting focused on tjohnson's financial situation, particularly regarding tax withholding issues related to his work location and potential strategies to minimize tax liability. Discussions also covered tjohnson's challenges with his IT department, including staffing needs and team management concerns. Additionally, the conversation touched on tjohnson's new job, financial planning, and the possibility of starting a consulting business to optimize tax benefits.

Next steps
tjohnson to contact HR about adding Nevada as a workplace location to potentially reduce California state tax withholdings.
tjohnson to obtain and provide Dat with income and tax withholding information from his previous job for the first part of the year.
Dat to update tax projections with the additional income information and send the Excel sheet to tjohnson.
tjohnson to explore options for leveraging his LLC (Thomas Johnson Consulting) to write off travel expenses.
tjohnson to consider maxing out his 401(k) contributions once eligible (after 6 months of employment) to lower taxable income.
tjohnson to investigate obtaining a California address (e.g., studio apartment) for work purposes while maintaining Nevada residency.
Summary
Tax Withholding and 401(k) Discussion
Dat and tjohnson discussed tjohnson's financial situation, particularly regarding tax withholding issues due to his work location being incorrectly set as California. Dat explained the complications with payroll companies and suggested two options: getting the withholding corrected now or claiming a credit on taxes at year-end, though some deductions might not be available immediately. They also briefly touched on tjohnson's new job, which is a tourism nonprofit, and his eligibility to contribute to a 401(k) after six months of employment.

IT Team Leadership Challenges
Tjohnson discussed challenges with his IT department, noting that while some help desk staff are competent, communication can be difficult. He mentioned having openings for two roles, a systems engineer and a solutions architect, but expressed concern that the data team was trying to take the solutions architect position. Tjohnson emphasized the need for someone to manage his small team, comparing his situation to running a basketball offense like James Harden, and suggested he needed a "Chris Paul" to help balance the team.

Tax Planning and Financial Review
Dat and tjohnson discussed tjohnson's tax situation and financial planning. They reviewed tjohnson's current pay stubs and discussed projecting his tax withholding and deductions for the year. Dat suggested tjohnson consider changing his work location to Nevada to potentially reduce state income taxes. They agreed to gather more information about tjohnson's previous income and deductions to make more accurate projections. Dat also mentioned the need to determine appropriate 401(k) contributions and withholding levels once they have all the necessary data.

Tax Strategies for Remote Work
Tjohnson discussed his situation with Dat regarding his work location and tax implications. He explained that his company prefers him to move to California, but he plans to maintain his Nevada residency by getting a studio apartment near the office. Dat suggested talking to HR about adding Nevada as a workplace and advised on tax strategies to minimize California tax liability. They also discussed the possibility of tjohnson starting a consulting business to write off travel expenses.
column109:
I said I'd just toss all this "Planning" into his tax prep fee but I'd like to show him the Gross Prices so he has a reference point for potential IT services.  

I would say do Tax Prep, 1040 Schedule C (Thomas Johnson LLC),  MottaGuard Compliance, and a Comprehensive Review & Assessment.

Do it all under tax prep and do it for $100 deposit and the remaining $150 upon completion of the tax return.  If we want to do the $100 for the review now just so we don't have open Proposals if/when we switch to Karbon Engagements than do that but get it to $250 all together.  He'll be an easy tax client for the most part and it's a WM prospect + potential vendor

column105:
Talked to Jason/Vamsi who were super appreciative with Motta for all of our help and patience when scrambling to get their taxes done last year.  We talked through a lot of the issues and compliance type considerations we found during the process.  

It was a great conversation and they understood they had some messiness on their end.  It was also evident that this is not their world (Vamsi is a doctor so not surprising) and they got some bad advice.  Vamsi said her attorney said she can get an app that she can set up and she would not have to do any work.  When I asked her which part of the job the app would do, she wasn't sure.  Also talked through Salary vs Distributions for Upiri.  

Jason didn't talk a ton, it seems he's super on board but Vamsi is more technical in making sure they understand what they are paying for.  I think Jason has a lot of super successful friends and also wants to be able to say he's got a CPA when talking to them.  

We spent a decent amount of time on the pricing which was expected since it was a "Here's all we do, what would you like to do?" and we've learned more about them since that point.  I was accidentally working off a wrong version and it had an excel error in there.  I hate myself for this.  

I updated the model with the services and explanations.  Sent them the updates with detailed explanations.  

Overall they'll do something (Tax Prep at least) and it was a great conversation.  Vamsi comes off way more harsh in emails, which I think she mentioned during the call but I'm not sure if she was talking about me, and think they like us a lot.  Jason appreciates that we're so responsive and Vamsi even shared the origins of her SCorp name.  

One outstanding item is that they wanted to basically simulate if they did tax planning with us in 2024, how much they would have saved.  Action item is for Caroline (or designee) to draft their 2023 return based on what they filed (Link here: https://ito.intuit.com/app/protax/tax-return?clientId=9341454074902086&engagementId=3bf0e3f7-44a0-4a96-a623-854b8b8952bf) because we need it in order to do the Intuit Tax Advisor plan for 2024.  

I think we'll be able to throw a handful of recommendations in there that would have covered our planning fees.  One key thing is that the ROI they are trying to calculate is the "Planning & Advisory" so when presenting it to them, it's only those fees because the others they would have to do anyways (i.e. tax prep) 

Providing the Zoom Ai summary for reference as well.  


Zoom Ai Meeting Transcription / Summary: 


Meeting summary for Caroline Buckley's Personal Meeting Room (06/20/2025)
Quick recap
The team welcomed new members and discussed ongoing tax and accounting projects, including filing deadlines and technical issues. They reviewed the firm's comprehensive suite of financial and tax planning services, including bookkeeping, payroll processing, and quarterly estimates, while addressing concerns about pricing and service bundles. The conversation ended with discussions about the firm's name and operational processes, including the use of a new platform for efficient data management and strategic planning.

Next steps
Dat to revise and send updated Excel sheet with accurate pricing information and potential tax savings estimates.
Jason and Vamsi to review the updated pricing and potential savings information and make a decision within a week.
Jason to continue attempting to contact the IRS or previous accountant regarding the 2023 filing notice.
Caroline to assist with IRS communication if Jason is unable to make progress within a week.
Vamsi to set up proper payroll withholdings for Ubery S Corp starting in 2025.
Dat to provide beta access to Alfred AI platform once interface is ready.
Summary
Team Updates and New Member Introductions
The team met to discuss ongoing projects and introduce new members. Caroline and Andrew provided background on their roles in the tax and accounting departments, respectively. Jason joined the call and expressed appreciation for Caroline's responsiveness in email communications. The group briefly discussed technical issues related to Andrew's internet connection at his new location.

Tax Filing Deadlines and Issues
The meeting focused on tax filing deadlines and issues. Jason reported receiving an IRS notice for their 2023 filing and is having trouble contacting their previous firm. Caroline clarified that the hedgehog LLC, being a partnership, must file by March 15th, unlike personal returns due April 15th. The group discussed the different deadlines for various tax entities, with pass-through entities like partnerships and S-corps due a month earlier than personal returns. Jason agreed to try contacting the IRS or previous firm one more week before seeking further assistance.

Tax Planning and Service Review
The team discussed their tax preparation experience, with Jason and Vamsi expressing satisfaction with the responsiveness and efficiency of the team despite some initial errors. They agreed that next year's process should be smoother. The conversation then shifted to tax planning, where Jason raised concerns about the high costs of quarterly tax planning services. Dat explained that accounting fees are generally deductible and emphasized the importance of analyzing whether the savings would exceed the costs. They agreed to review the pricing details and discuss which services would be most beneficial for the client.

CPA and CHCFT Service Structure
The team discussed the structure and approach to providing CPA and CHCFT services, emphasizing a personalized and comprehensive suite of services tailored to each client's unique needs. Dat explained their method of categorizing income types and conducting tax planning, while also addressing bookkeeping, payroll, and ongoing accounting needs. The group reviewed a cost structure document, which Dat agreed to share with the team, and discussed the potential for deductibility of fees.

Financial and Tax Services Overview
Dat discussed financial and tax services, including monthly or quarterly bookkeeping, payroll, and account reconciliations. He mentioned consolidating financials on an entity and consolidated basis, handling quarterly payroll filing fees, and providing tax planning with quarterly estimates. Dat also talked about strategies to optimize tax savings, such as increasing 401(k) contributions, cost segregation studies for real estate, and exploring donor-advised funds and residential energy credits. He emphasized the importance of analyzing the cost and benefits of tax-saving strategies and mentioned that Caroline would handle most IRS communications.

Pricing and Service Bundle Review
The meeting focused on reviewing pricing and service bundles, where Dat explained that the provided pricing was not final but rather a high-level overview of potential costs for comprehensive services including tax preparation, bookkeeping, payroll, and planning. Vamsi asked questions about base fees versus adjustments, clarifying that adjustments account for bundling discounts and the ease of planning when all numbers are already available. The discussion confirmed that the quarterly estimates and planning fee of $4,000 was annual, and Vamsi acknowledged his initial misunderstanding about the cumulative nature of certain charges.

Bookkeeping vs. Financial Planning Services
Dat explained the difference between bookkeeping and quarterly estimates and planning services. He clarified that while bookkeeping involves daily transactions and compliance, quarterly estimates and planning provide a consolidated financial overview and forecasting for both business and personal finances. Vamsi asked about potential duplication with their financial consultant, Ross, and Dat confirmed that while there might be some overlap, their services would complement each other, with Dat's team collaborating with Ross on tax and financial planning considerations.

S Corp Payroll Planning Discussion
