Vamsi discussed setting up and managing an S Corp, particularly regarding bookkeeping and payroll for 2024 and 2025. Caroline explained that while Vamsi could get away with informal quarterly payments in 2024 as it was their first year, proper payroll withholdings would be necessary for 2025 to comply with IRS requirements. Dat clarified that using a payroll system would help avoid self-employment taxes by treating the income as W-2 wages rather than business distributions, and Vamsi agreed to implement proper payroll processing starting next year.

Financial Planning and Alfred Platform
The meeting focused on discussing financial and tax planning services, including the use of a new platform called Alfred for efficient data management and strategic planning. Dat explained their pricing structure, emphasizing competitive rates and the potential for cost savings through their streamlined processes. Vamsi requested a detailed analysis of potential savings based on previous data, which Dat agreed to provide. The group also discussed the benefits of using Alfred, a beta platform designed to offer personalized tax advice and reduce administrative work. Dat promised to send a revised Excel sheet with high-level estimates and examples of potential savings, and Vamsi agreed to review this information within a week to make a decision.

Ubery's Ubuntu-Inspired Growth Strategy
The team discussed the firm's name "Ubery" and its meaning, which Dat explained was derived from Ubuntu principles of community and resource efficiency. Dat shared that Andrew, despite being busy with work, had requested more tasks since joining the firm. The team reviewed some financial numbers, noting an intentional error that had been made to demonstrate the impact of mistakes on the bottom line. Jason thanked the team for their thorough front-loading of discussions, which helped with decision-making.

Had a brief call with Steven Wheelis who is on the Product side of ProConnect.  Pretty interesting meeting for 15 minutes and got some good info out of it. 

First - They said they have a bunch of stuff rolling out that is confidential and won't be announced until Intuit Connect (which is probably their annual conference) that they are coming out with a QuickBooks on steroids called "Supernova" which is supposed to be built for the "Enterprise" type clients which might serve a lot of companies that might not be at NetSuite level.  Their Enterprise version right now is only on desktop I believe.   

Steve said their API wasn't ready yet because it was only built to speak internally. The issue with that is that it can't tell which Intuit profile (QBO, ProConnect, etc.) because the database is so massive and the API can't be limited to just a certain amount of data.  

He said they tried to work with Darkhorse CPAs (which is a good competitor to us) and they tried to test the API with ProConnect.  From what I gather from Steve, I think that set both sides back a lot.  He says the API can pull information out of ProConnect (but still doesn't work great) and they are still figuring out how to get information into ProConnect.  

Steve said they just got funding and the status is that the executives are fighting over where to spend the new investment.  This makes me think they might be a white label of Intuit but every "Start Uppy".  He says once they get the dollars allocated towards getting the resources they'll be able to distribute the API.  He projected a year but hopefully they'll give us the inside scoop on that.  My fear is that with the Darkhorse experiment gone poorly, Management will be hesitant to do that again.  

One thing that came into my head was that Darkhorse probably had shit data which added delays to an already massive project.  Once it got too expensive for both sides, they cut bait.  Emphasizing to the team how important it is to get the data clean in the first time so it makes us more versatile / dynamic on the back end.  

David and the Tekyz team was on the call which I appreciated because I know it's late there but I think it was good for them to hear the status of the ProConnect API and the potential avenues there.  David was good at getting a soft commitment that they would work with us on the call.   

We'll stay in touch with ProConnect but obviously it will be a Game Changer if we can get them to talk.

Caught up with Harrison which includes checking in on the clients that he has referred us.  We needed to talk through Brittany Scott with him since she contributed too much into her ROTH IRA.  

All in all, think there was some missteps with her old Financial Planner (Harrison inherited this client) and her accountant who didn't catch that she overfunded it.  

Harrison said he'd introduce us to the investment team so that we can handle it without him being a bottleneck but we actually will need an amendment for 2024 to change the ROTH IRA contribution amount to the proper amount.  He said they won't be able to do anything with the account until they get that amended return.  

I know we talked about refunding her but turns out we do need it so let's get that going and change the contribution amounts for the conversion.  

Once the investment team sells off whatever they need to, she is going to have a taxable gain/loss on her investment for 2025 so note that for year end.
column109: Hopefully we haven't already refunded her but we'll need to get the amendment done before she can make the correcting distribution.

column105:
Mark and Andrew met with Al from Crown Legends. 

Cleared up outstanding items for 2024 Bookkeeping to wrap up his taxes.  Went over partner distributions and loans on the balance sheet, and over the counter deposits. He has a business savings acct, that we were not fully aware, so he is going to send over bank statements for that acct. Mostly just monthly banks fees, they made him open up the savings acct, when he opened the business checking.  

For 2023 Amended he received a notice, saying that there wasn't enough information provided and that we need to fill out 2023 tax form. He texted me the notice, I will upload to Karbon.

He is having a hat drop, he thinks next Saturday. So might to stop by if they do the drop. 

Al asked about our thoughts on him selling a piece of the company in an equity deal.  He has pitch for the BXC investors, next week. So he seemed nervous about that, not really nervous about the pitch but what to do if he gets an offer. Walked him through some high level thoughts on equity vs debt deals, he was appreciative and good to see he sees us as a trusted advisor to his business. 

Action Items:
2023 Amended Return - Notice Review - Caroline

2024- request savings acct statements and info of loan from his fiance to the business.

Talked to Kenny for about 30 minutes.  Most of it was rambling for the most part but we talked CannaLean as well. 

We both agreed we'll get the accounting caught up for now and then we'll talk potential equity type arrangements.  I think we talked about it as a team but without the numbers and stuff, even if we did take a %, we'd be shooting blind.  

With that said, I said we'd do the Accounting Set Up and Catch Up and then assess from there.  So this will be just a bookkeeping onboarding job and a business valuation job.  Nothing too formal but once we get the numbers up to date, it should be an easy plug into Biz Equity.
column109: I think they made like $200k last year and probably around $300k this year so relatively low from a topline perspective.  Still like 2.5 years of accounting so maybe Andrew can have some input but I'm thinking like $4,500 but discount down to $1,750 and the business valuation for $1,000 and discounted down to $450.

column105:
Caroline, Dat and Mark met with Camille to go over her and Josh's estimate for 2025. Josh is a bartender and makes 100-110K/year but 2/3 of the income is tip income. His employer only withholds on his salary portion (typical scenario) so they're going to be underwithheld for 2025 unless they make estimates or increase their withholding. We suggested estimates since they can pay those in during times where his income is higher (its a sports bar so ex. fall when football starts). 

Camille had questions on whether or not it would make sense for them to file seperately instead of MFJ so that her student loan payments don't go up drastically. Mark mentioned that loophole might be going away, so it probably wont make sense for them but I am going to do some research and send her our findings.

They are definitely prospects/leads for tax estimates and financial planning. Brian - can you put this on RP so we have it for tracking purposes and don't forget? Nothing to do now for them for those items, but it will most likely transition into that in the future. She was a referral from Becca Jacobson so we don't have FA ties here.

To do's:
- Brian to add them as leads for estimates + financial planning
- Caroline to send Camille instructions on how to submit estimated payments and summary of what we discussed (timing etc.).
- Caroline to look into MFJ/MFS loophole & send Camille our findings.
Test
The last time I saw Dean he was in Nashville wearing a white cowboy hat and telling Mitch Hamilton how he doesn't respect his time (jokingly) but said he respected my time.

Caught up with Ryan for a personal appointment but spent a lot of time getting PP updates.  He said no rush on the Co-Operative front but one thing he just discovered was that he was basically taking a 50% haircut on revenue from all that insurance stuff as well as just giving out free services cause he feels bad in general.  

He said the first Medical Billers he had did such a terrible job that they almost got audited and would have lost out on all the Reimbursements from a particular insurance company.  He said they just hired another company that seems like a family owned business.  He said they were a little more expensive but hopefully the quality is much better.  The end goal is to hire an internal one but they aren't quite there yet. 

From our standpoint, I asked how he was getting the insurance info because I'd like to see what Gross vs Net billings are because in the HealthCare industry, there's a "COGs" component because if they bill something for $100, insurance will reimburse $80 or something like that.  I think right now we just see the $80 hit the bank account but obviously the Gross vs Net would be super insightful for them.  

I said to keep us posted with the new billers but think we might be able to expand their billing a bit.
column109:
Andrew, Matt, and P24 should stay ready to expand their accounting.  I think it can be a catalyst to expand our relationship in general.  Ryan constantly tells us he wants to pay his fair share when they are able to and they are getting close to that so think he'll be open to upping fees.  

We can punt on the pricing discussion for now (I think they'll be much more profitable in a couple months) so they can get ramped up with the new billers but depending on how that looks, could be a $750+ per month client.

column105:
Ryan from the VYP Fusion Mixer hit me up on Friday to go out for a drink.  We went to the Durango resort as a middle point between us (He's currently in Green Valley Ranch which is a very nice area of Henderson) but he wants to be closer to the strip. 

Ryan is from New Jersey originally but then moved to New York to work where he for a Hedgefund in Finance which he did for almost 10 years.  He said he used to be a "No Mouse" excel guy which made me a fan immediately although he admits his excel skills are weak since leaving Finance.  He moved to Chicago for a girl and then she convinced him to move to Las Vegas because that's where her family is from but that relationship ended poorly.  He's now a Vegas local though so overall still a win! 

He got sick of the Corporate America world and wanted to do something he loved.  He was always into Boxing and got REALLY into it after the movie, The Fighter.  

He worked hard to get into the industry/networks and ended up landing a Sponsorship deal for a friend of his for Teofimo Lopez. After that, his friend hired him to essentially be the Manager for about 50 professional boxers.  

He said it was good for a few years but since COVID, the boxing sport has been tough.  He said for the last Canelo fight, no one he knew was able to secure Sponsorships for the fighters or the event.  

The industry is also similar to the UFC industry how it's the wild west in the Athlete infrastructure space.  He was put between screwing over his boss or screwing over Teofimo and ended up just leaving the industry.  

He now works at a boxing equipment company but he hates it and wants to start getting back into the industry.  He's been making calls to his network and trying to get back in with a Fighter or Management company. 

He seems like he as a giant network with some famous people.  Including some of the instagrams below but he says he's friends with Adam Weitsman who is a billionaire from New York based on a Google Search.  He says they text regularly and that guy is involved with Jake Paul and Ryan is trying to network his way onto the boxing industry that way since Jake Paul is the only person in the sport who generates any money.  

He's around my age and actually moved to Vegas around the same time I did. He met a guy named Chris from Miami through Boxing and Chris was friends with Kenny.  I actually think I met him the same night I might Kenny at the J Cole concert but don't remember him.  

He'll be a LOMAR indy Prospect but think he'll be a good personal friend and also could be a good channel for referrals through his network.  

https://www.instagram.com/adamweitsman/
https://www.instagram.com/tigerjohnson216/
https://www.instagram.com/teofimolopez/
column109:
If/When we do the proposal for him, charge the $149 price.  

I think he's a Prospect at this point so Brian should turn this into a repeating work item

column105:
Met Bailey over the holidays in LA.  They are really close family friends with the Jacobson's and live up the street.  

Bailey is Cole's age and think they were both had giant brains.  Like Cole, Bailey also works with Sports Data Analytics and is the Director of Data Analytics for the Oklahoma City Thunder.  

I talked to him a little bit about what we do over the holidays and he had asked Cary "Do you do your own taxes" and Cary laughed and said "Nah, Dat handles all that" and he said "Must be nice!" so think he'll be a Motta client in 2025 if not he will be once his life gets more complicated.  

Great kid! We text whenever OKC plays the Celtics and have been talking to him about the Finals.  I'm not sure if any of the data analytics will help with my sports betting but maybe.  

Lead for 2025 for now but Cole/Bailey are getting us foots in the door with an increasing number of sports teams.  Also think this would be our first Oklahoma City client.

Cole is the middle brother of the Jacobson's.  He's also the most different of the three.  Cary/Julian are pretty similar but Cole the quiet type but absolute computer brain.  Cary/Julian went to Palisades High but Cole went to Harvard Westlake.  If you Google that school, it's one of the best Private Schools for education and sports in Southern California (maybe America?).  He then went to UPenn for college where he played some form of tackle football that wasn't real football.  I'm a lot closer to Cary and Julian (who interned at REDACTED) but I always say Cole is my favorite of the Jacobson brothers because he's a Red Sox fan.  He's also a Sixers/Eagles fan so it might cancel each other out but at least he's a Sox fan.  

Cole's about 28 and has been trying to get into sports analytics for a LONG time.  He coaches football at Harvard Westlake and also does Contract work during the baseball season where he has had published articles on Advanced Analytics.  He also has written a bunch of studies and articles on Advanced Analytics in Football and actually has been to the NFL combine a couple of times to present his study to NFL scouts.  He went last year and came in 3rd place I think.  

I learned via Snapchat that he just got a job with the Buffalo Bills.  I'm personally happy for him because he's been trying to break into the industry for YEARS and has worked hard to break into the industry.  I don't know what his job is or any of the details but glad he got a foot in the door somewhere.  

I had talked to him last year passively about doing his taxes since we help the rest of the Jacobsons but he had filed in early February on TaxAct.  He says he'll be coming our way for 2025.
column109: Charge $149.. I think that should be the floor for Tax Prep in 2025 (aside from my Comps obviously)

column105:
Met Chris at the VYP Fusion Mixer.  Upon further research, I think he's the President of the council himself.  This guy thought VERY highly of himself and also think he was another Trust Fund Baby here.  He works at a Holdings company that has over 70 McDonald's franchises in the Southwest region of the country.  His aunt is the CFO... 

He made it seem like he's essentially running the company but his contact card said he was a Senior Accountant.  He said he's starting to get involved in Finance but most of his job was helping with the Ronald McDonald house activities and also community engagement like this.  Essentially his aunt got him a cushy job where he just shakes hands and kisses babies.  

He seemed to be a big fan of me because he made it a point to give me his contact info and said he was going to reach out for whatever reason.  I'm actually not sure if this was business related or if he just wanted more friends but he will at least provide a network/opportunities so I'll follow up and follow through on the lead.

Met with Harrison at the VYP Fusion Mixer.  He thought VERY highly of himself.  He is the "Managing Member" of a Commercial Real Estate Lending company that is Dad started.  He said he's at the event because he has to do more business development stuff because his dad is the back office guy and wanted him to be the "Face" of the company.  I think he's mostly a Trust Fund Baby.  His dad also runs the General Contracting side of the business but also more behind the scenes in that business.  Harrison said his dad was a former Portfolio Manager so think he's basically just a number cruncher.  

They mostly do commercial projects but said they never say no to a project.  We talked about real estate for a bit and he talked about how he used to be a construction type project manager at Wynn but left because he feels like his voice wasn't being heard.  

Overall great and bright dude, just a bit self important is all and I am generally adverse towards Trust Fund Babies.  

He texted me this morning and going to try to get coffee/lunch with him the first week of July.  He's the "Managing Member" of the company and hinted that he didn't think their accountants were the best.  I want to say the person who does their books is a friend of his dad but he's looking to grow the business so might want a finance guy that's more a peer vs his dad's friend.  

I'll get something on the books for the first week of July but think it's two leads for a 1040 and a Partnership return.  Growing our market in Vegas either way!
column109: Lead, no proposal.  Tenatively planning to meet the first week of July

column105:
Andrew and Mark, met with Amir and AJ. Aj is the owner of Scordio Studios and Ola Mate. 

Amir wants to start bookkeeping Oct 1st because that is when his new firm will launch. Bill for June-Sept in October and Andrew would need to get the company caught up on Bookkeeping. 

Ola Mate is a new set up, with multiple integrations to figure out.  SOS Inventory, Amazon, TicToc, shopify. Various different ecommerce platforms. Want to pay for A2X to help with shopfy integration. Not familiar with that but suppose to make things easier, so we need to do some research on that front. 

AJ, was on board for Ola Mate since its new set up with no current bookkeeper. AJ had reservations about leaving current bookkeeper for Scordio. 

Amir and AJ are firends and they had pretty Firey conversation on this point that Andrew and Mark sat back on. Amir, will swear a lot on calls, so know who you are talking with. 

AJ was pushing back a lot on getting charge an onboarding fee, since he alreadys has a bookkeeper whats to onboard was his point but there would be some clean up and reorganizing the chart or accts but we can be flexible with the price for onboarding for Scordio. 

Overall good first joint client call and was good to see how Amir handles client objections and pushes back on clients thoughts on pricing/ Althought i think the relationship dynamic was unique on this call between Amir and AJ. 

Amir literally said to AJ " Your complaining about 800 fucking dollars, I would never do that to you, I could find cheaper web developer and logo creator but I use you." 

But should have both of these clients starting October 1st when Amirs RIA launches.

Talked to Lauren (Kenny's wife) for a decent amount of the event.  She didn't know I was a CPA or what I did for work before but learned this after Kenny said he was working with us on the CannaLean side.  

She gave me her business card which was a bit plain and looked like a resume of "Odd jobs" on the back of it but she says most of the time she's a Realtor.  She says her clients are always asking her about CPAs so she's glad she has someone to refer them to.  

She has an LLC for her business and I'm not particularly sure if it'll be a SMLLC or SCorp but thinking SMLLC.  She just finished school and also just had their first kid over the past year but seems like she's trying to ramp up her career now so maybe she'll grow into a bigger client.  Her and Kenny are both entrepreneurial (they are similar to Chris/Thalia in that way) so think she'll have some projects and/or referrals for us.

Met Kristina at the VYP Fusion Mixer.  She works with the council and was doing the photography for the event.  

Her day job is an Associate at a Financial Planning firm and her eyes lit up when Kenny said I was a CPA.  She said her firm is always looking for a good CPA because all their clients are asking for them but they've received bad feedback from the Professionals they've referred so far.  

She circled back a couple times because she also has a side hustle as a Photographer and she says that side of the business is growing with more Graduation photos and events like these.  She's a solo photographer so hasn't done weddings yet but she's helped as a contractor for some weddings and wants to get into the space.  

I'll follow up with her but think this could be 1040 Schedule C lead and a FA channel in Las Vegas which would help with our footprint out here.
column109: No proposal.  Tax Prep lead and FA Channel Lead

column105:
Met Ryan who is a friend of Kenny's through the Vegas Young Professionals Council (via the Vegas Chamber Leadership Foundation).  Super nice and humble dude.  

He used to work in Finance but left that world to working with Boxers in Sponsorships.  He said he had helped get an up and coming Boxer a deal which lead to an introduction with a company that manages over 50 boxers so he made a career change.  He essentially helps get Boxers sponsorship deals.  

He says it was really good when he first got into it but Boxing has fallen off in popularity since Mayweather, Pacman, and all of those boxers have retired.  He says he's hoping there's another Jake Paul card soon and that he rejuvenates the sport.  He doesn't directly work with Jake Paul but has worked with some boxers that are on the boxing cards he puts on.  

He says with the boxing market slowing down, he also works with an equipment company (not sure which one) on the other side of sponsorships to get boxers equipment and stuff like that.  

We briefly talked about how we work with fighters on the MMA side and how they need CPAs and he said it was the same on the boxing side.  Think this could be a decent channel into the Boxing athletes which I think is a decent sized market in Vegas.  

Good dude! He didn't have a business card but he followed me on Instagram so I'll follow up with him there.

Met Scott Morris who is an Injury Law Attorney with his own practice in Las Vegas.  He was in a cream turtle neck / blazer combo and immediately asked for my Instagram instead of my business card.  He then scanned my profile for ~15 seconds then started asking me about my life.  

He is born and raised in Vegas but went to Morehouse college (spelling?) which is where Kenny went so small world.  

We talked through some minor tax questions and some tax savings strategies for Professional Services firms.  

I'm not sure if the firm is a Partnership or SCorp but from what I gather it's a decent sized small business.  I'm not sure who does the accounting for the firm right now but he did not seem overly pleased with his current professional.  

I'll follow up via instagram (cause I don't have his card) but consider him a tax lead and potential bookkeeping lead.
column109: No proposal yet.  Just a lead

column105:
Mark & Caroline met with Deb Dolman who is Mitch Dolman's mom. She's not a US citizen and lives in Canada. She's an experienced Canadian accountant so she knows Canada rules really well but not US rules. She wants to buy a rental property in Myrtle Beach with Mitch (50/50 split) so she was wondering how she should go about doing that from a US tax perspective.

We walked through the benefits of an LLC with liability protection but because of the extra tax form/cost she didn't see the point of doing it. They're going to do the rentals through Airbnb/VRBO so she said they have enough coverage with insurance. Mark informed her that she should tell the real estate attorney to make sure to put the deed as tenants in common with rights to survivorship so that Mitch gets the property when she dies (what she wants). 

She also wanted to know what will happen from an estate perspective when she dies and passes the property on to mitch - Mark/Caroline to do some research here because its a grey area with the foreign aspect.

Without the LLC her and mitch will each report their 50% share on their individual 1040 sch E (instead of a partnership return). Brian - we already have a work item for her 2025 tax return, can you just make sure its on 2026 RP? We will also need a proposal but i think we should wait to send it until they actually buy the property. it will be a 1040 return + sch E, she was kind of shocked by the $500 flat fee Mark mentioned so maybe we add a discount since the books will be clean (i pray) and she'll only have a schedule E.

She needs to get an ITIN (Caroline to send her instructions) so that she will be able to file her 2025 US tax return.
column109: optional: we can give her a small discount because of simplicity of the return. thoughts?

column105:
Caught up with Camden with Caroline/Dat.  He apologized for being out of touch, he went to Japan & Thailand then rolled right into Spring Camp with the football team.  

He says from a business standpoint, they haven't made a ton of headway but has raised $100k + $5k from various sources.  The money should come in within the next couple of months.  

He says for 2025, this is essentially their FGA year so they only want to do 4-5 deals so learn/build the process on their end.  One of their partners just got their insurance title license so now they can be the title insurance broker on deals so seems like their still in the process of setting up their business infrastructure.

He says between the money that they've won along with capital contributions, they need to start to organize all of that as they launch which is typical Onboarding type stuff. 

He also says he needs a CPA Verification letter (that's notarized) stating that they have at least $10k in their bank account.  He says he'll deposit some cash in there to get over the $10k threshold but the letter is the gating item for them getting them additional financing.  

It's still too early for a Bookkeeping contract as they aren't operating yet but he wants to get the Accounting System / Payroll System set up.  I said we should keep it simple with QBO Ledger / Gusto for set up and he agreed.  

I think we have a CPA Verification work template so Caroline (or Brian) to create that and send requests for a Bank Statement or something that shows he had a balance of over $10k.  I think our template covers what we need it to but if not, ask ALFRED to write a new one.  

Once we send out the proposal, Andrew can get started with the Onboarding projects.
column109:
This will be: 

(1) CPA Verification Letter: Show $750 gross price and discounted down to $300

(2) Onboarding (QBO): $650

(3) Payroll Set Up (Gusto): $500

(4) Tax (CCorp): $1,250 discounted down to 850

(5) Camden Demsey (separate client in ignition): Comped 1040

Brian to draft the proposals and an email to explain all the proposals.  I can send it to him this afternoon once drafted

column105:
I called back Britney Scott a referral from Harrison Hunter. She is a State Trooper in Texas. 

Her email is blk006@shsu.edu

She needs to amend her 2024 return as she reported an over contribution to her ROTH IRA, that Harrison is working to fix on the back end. She didnt really get the details of anything, just said she needs to fix her return. I told her we would take a look at her return and get her an official proposal but would be in the range of $200-500. 

Action Items:

1. Create Contact - Brian
2. Create Amended 2024 Tax Return Work Item - Brian
3. Send out Discovery Requests- Brian/Caroline
4. Create Proposal for Amended Return - Brian/Caroline

Talked to Francis/Melody who are experienced grad students at Suffolk.  They are in the consulting clinic with Nick V from SEED who sent them our way.  

They are starting a consulting company that helps BIPOC companies but started as a non profit.  We talked through some structures but I think the gating item is that they are still determining their market.  Mark had the best path forward which was a "Non Profit Adjacent" where they are essentially Vendors/Providers for Non-Profits granting companies money and using BOWMEL.  

They went through their pitch deck which I gave a C/C+.  It was pretty boiler plate tbh.. they used consulting buzz words but you can throw a rock and find a firm with the same Consulting model.  

They are still in the process of finding their market and said they were planning on doing Pro Bono work to see where there market is going to be.
column109:
This will be an Entity Formation (which entity is the gating item) and Tax Preparation prospect.  

For these situations, do we still want to draft a proposal in ignition? I'll defer to Mark/Brian on this but if it is a proposal, it won't be until ~Q4 2025.

column105:
Caroline & Dat caught up with Ryan which felt like a "Pitch" meeting.  

He started by saying he's basically only getting paid for 50% of the work he's done since starting since Health Insurance registrations/approvals have been a nightmare and Ryan doesn't have the heart to turn away patients.  Having said that, the business is growing a bunch and they've had a couple of months in a row where they make enough to cover all their business expense and pay their personal bills.  This is awesome to see and they are forever appreciative of all of our help to get them to this point.  

Ryan then went through his idea of a business model where the employees own the company (He had mentioned this when he first started the company and it was a Co operative type thing).  He was going to start it with another lady but she was awful so they just went SCorp.  

I think he wants to re-engage that now that they are at a stable place (business wise).  Matt was involved in those conversations back in the day so I'll get him involved along with Caroline.  Maybe Dwyer over the top to further get his reps in the business advisory world. 

I think we should request his "Pitch Deck" and the math around it.  Also let's look into the Cooperative route and look into a potential restructure.

Julian is my roommate's (Cary Jacobson) youngest brother.  There are 3 boys total: Cary, Cole, and Julian.  

Met Julian when I first moved to Vegas as they come out for Cary's birthday every year.  Julian went to Johnson & Wales where he played baseball.  He then took a gap year while transferring to University of California Santa Cruz.  He's graduating this weekend and got a job with the WWE in Sponsorships.  Cary works a lot with TKO sports (Parent company of UFC {aka Zuffa Inc.} and the WWE) and they say Julian is killing it so far.  

When Julian was on his gap year, he actually was my intern at REDACTED and also resigned after I did.  I somewhat took Julian under my wing during that year and still maintain a mentor relationship with him.  

He was a Dependent of Eric / Wendi Jacobson for 2024 because he was still in school but he just moved to NYC (WWE office) so he'll have his own tax return this year.
column109:
Family discount.

Created a repeating work item for this return

column105:
Had an "Intro" meeting with Damion who is the De facto CEO of CannaLean.  It was a phone call and the meeting ended up being about an hour where we talked about typical backgrounds and then the state of CannaLean and where he wants to go with it.  Kenny is the "Sales / BD" side of the business, Chris is the Scientist, and Damion is on the business side.  We seem to share a lot of the same philosophies. 

He's a 20 year retired Air Force vet and then got his Masters / MBA and has a handful of ventures he has going on along with 11 rental properties.  We briefly talked through RE tax benefits.  Also talked through how we are hyper focused on efficiently and how we've set up our processes and that resonated as that is what he's trying to do with CL.  He has a tax person right now but there's a chance he'll come over if he ever gets sick of his tax people.  I think he was intrigued by what we had going on. I'm guessing he'll ask Kenny if we're legit and he'll explain to him that I'm MJ.  He's a lead for now.  

On the CannaLean side.. they basically have been operating for the same amount of time as Motta except Kenny was getting his doctorate so just doing this as a side hustle.  They've done no accounting and haven't really built the Business Infrastructure at all.  Kenny built a big Sales Infrastructure and Damion admitted that they probably spent the money to build an infrastructure to field growth but ran into operational issues which slowed them down so the money spent on that infrastructure was a bit pre mature / not efficient for a start up.  I said I could resonate with that and if anything, it's an FGA in "Start Up Infrastructure". 

Damion said he got involved to help with that and is a "Green Belt" in change mgmt.  He's essentially trying to set up the infrastructure because they've just been getting back knowing that money is coming in and money is going out.  Damion wants to actually build a plan to set them up to actually be scalable.  His goal is to get all the numbers cleaned up and build a plan / forecast to see how much inventory they need for 2026 so they can go to investors in the fall and say "This is how much money we need so we can much this much inventory".  

He said he wasn't sure why Kenny was saying we need a valuation because the numbers don't exist.  I explained that we're essentially getting caught up with the accounting to get the data first before we even get to the "Valuation" point.  He said he was skeptical but trusted Kenny so let him cook but now understands why we're here.  Damion thinks they are about 3-6 months away from that because the numbers from a sales perspective isn't strong by his standards.  They are making between $25k - $30k per month but with difficulties with inventory.  Kenny (and I guess Damion too) wants to expand into the CBD line (Which Damion said they got the design approval for?) but wants to make sure they get organized with everything they have going on first. 

I think this is mostly going to be an accounting / onboarding type engagement to start (they also agree they have no idea what the company is currently worth.   He said he's never been through the valuation before so curious the levers that factor into the overall valuation.  I said we can update valuations whenever so I'm sure we'll be working with them about it through the process. 

Damion said he'd get us the access we need for the sales reports and stuff but basically he's going to be helping on the Forecasting / Planning side and I said we'd be helping on the Accounting / Expense side.
column109:
I'm going to a networking event with Kenny on Thursday night so I'll talk to him about the proposal but I'm think we do the Accounting as a "Try out" for them to get a feel for us and for us to get more data on the company.  

I'm tenatively thinking: 

[1] - QBO Set Up / Bookkeeping Onboarding: Andrew to estimate Hours
[2] - Business Valuation: $1,500 discounted to $799

We can talk about ongoing BKPG / Taxes after I talk to Kenny but think this is will get us paid for this work and more info for a potential Motta Capital arrangement.

column105:
Went to a day party at Ayu (I went to the club by myself because I'm a loser) because Marcos Valdez's (Prospect) girlfriend, who is a DJ, was performing for the first time in Vegas so I went out in support.  

FRANK SHULMAN

I did not really intend to drink but one of Marcos' other friends, Frank Shulman, was there.  Frank is a VP with Lobos Tequila which I learned is LeBron's tequila.  Frank actually lives out in Gilbert AZ (told him we have a footprint there via OCP) but he's from Brooklyn NY originally.  He actually spent 8 months in Boston working for Legal Seafood.  He said he helped open the Airport Location as well as the one that's not the Seaport one although he helped open their test kitchen as well.  He was in Vegas for a brand activation at a Ne-Yo concert at Drai's.  He says he's in Vegas / LA all the time if the tequila is doing any kind of events.  He says a lot of their brand marketing is done through agencies so sometimes the agencies will screw them so if they are supposed to have a big activation, the agencies might forget about it or fumble it so he's always traveling to supervise these events.  We briefly talked about taxes but then did 2 consecutive shots of Lobos tequila and he had to leave.  

He gave me his card (I didn't have any on me) and I followed up via text.  I added the client contact into Karbon and the work item (folders synced.. you're welcome Brian) and added to Prospects (Not Likely) in 2026.  If he's back in town (or if I make a trip out to AZ) than we can consider him a prospect but think he's a lead for now.  

ALAN DURST

Alan is a Host at Zouk (nightclub) / Ayu (day club) and I've gotten to know him from going to Zouk so much with Cary.  When I'm not with Cary, there's usually a giant line of regular people to get into the club the regular way.  Then there's a crowd/line to check in if you get a table.  I usually politely ask those people to move out of the way and talk to Alan and he usually lets me and my friends in right away.  Also supplies us with wristbands to get on stage and some drink tickets obviously.  

While I was waiting in line, I thanked him for always getting into the club for free and said if he ever needed tax help than hit me up.  He said he definitely needs help and will hit us up at the end of the year.  I think we had sent him Knights tickets at some point but he's a Club Host so I'm not sure if he ended up just using it for work.  

Alan's a great dude in general.  He's from Ohio in general and big Ohio State guy.  Added him as a Prospect in RP 2026.  

MARCOS VALDEZ

Marcos works in Operations (?) at Zouk/Ayu.  When I first met him it was at the F1 race and he was the interim General Manager at Fuhu (EXECELLENT restaurant at Resorts World) when the GM & Assistant GM was poached by Komoto/Fountainbleau.  I'm still friends with those folks and also Marcos doesn't work at Fuhu anymore but I still see him all the time at Zouk.  He helps with Stage Bands when I don't get them from Allen and always supplies drink tickets if I'm not at a table.  

I learned that he's actually only 25 but the kid is a very kind soul and a very hard worker.  I had offered tax help last tax season but he never took me up on it.  Maybe this year but either way, think it's a prospect for 2025 taxes.
column109: All Leads/Prospects.  Only getting client notes in there for background context for future work.

column105:
Mark and Andrew met with ScheLeese for an hour. We reviewed her QB and QB payroll setup. Everything seems to be coming along. ScheLeese has some generalized questions about tips on paychecks, honeybook invoices syncing to QB, Retainers from purchase and new ones as operating the business. 

Payroll is fully setup and she should be able to run her first payroll this week. QB is fully setup and her retainers from the purchase are on the balance sheet. As the events occur, they get moved from deferred revenue to specific revenue buckets. All her product and services are updated in QB. Added her a few new COGS accounts. Any future retainers will be recorded the same. 

Action Items:
-CO PFML and make sure this setup properly in payroll
-Tips on payroll
-Sales tax rates
-Honeybook invoices sync to QB (need to confirm this feature exists)

Andrew and Mark, closed the SEED loop with Lawyer and Angela. We had told them, we would to a follow up call to check in to see, how they were doing with Quickbooks. 

Angela had questions prepared.  Went over invoices, they just want to create invoices dont need to collect online payments. Went over Paypal Integration. Went over how to do manual journal entries for items paid out of personal accounts. 

Dripped Motta Services on them. Angela wants to learn to maintain the books but depending on how fast they grow, they will most likely need assistance. 

Action Items;

Andrew to transfer billing to Future Masters of Chess. 
Mark emailed recording of the call to them.

Caught up with Mitch about Three Point Insurance and it turns out the entity is already open.  Mitch was under the assumption that 3PM would have to be a C Corp to do this.  He also wanted to move to a CCorp for the purposes of implementing an ESOP and also to FINALLY allocate DJ the 10% of the company he was promised.  

One thing I wanted to confirm is that the company HAS to be a CCorp in order to implement an ESOP.  

I don't think this is priority.  Mitch and I talked about if it makes sense to just put it under Mitch for now (same as 3PM) while we level set on the plan since the landscape has changed since he initially framed this out.  

This is an entity advisory type job so maybe we do some research (Caroline) on the topics above along with the structure in general.  Caroline will need context from me most likely so find some time on my calendar to talk through.
column109:
Mitch/DJ came to Vegas last year but my day had blown up that day and I didn't get to spend as much time with them as I wanted to.  I promised I'd get to Denver before the end of the year or I'd do the SCorp -> CCorp restructure for free.  I'm not sure if we'll actually do this but in any case, if we do move from SCorp to CCorp, the Accounting/Tax fees will definitely go up.  

I believe I had asked OCP to refresh the 3PM contract based on all the new branches and the additional work we do to come up with a new contract for them as a whole.

column105:
Andrew & I caught up with Clay for the full hour (although most of that was getting access to his JP Morgan / Wells Fargo Accounts) about 411.  

Clay just got back from Dubai where he is working his way into a company with a Crypto Platform that is supposed to have some fancy algorithm to beat the market.   We hadn't talked to him in a month because he was in Dubai and he said he's had like 100 meetings to get this going.  Even before he left, he put $1m on the platform and said he made $100k+ in a month. He also said he partners with a Commodities company that sells gold because Crypto platforms need safe investments in their portfolio? He said he was going to be the US representative for the Platform and had a friend of his that Owns and/or Runs a Canadian bank who committed $50m to the platform to "Try it out"

He's looking to close down 411 Restoration and put all his efforts into this new venture.  Working with insurance companies have been a pain and he could be waiting to get paid on jobs (that he has to front the cash for the jobs) for 3-6 months sometimes and he hates the constant chasing.  The Crypto venture is much more lucrative and much less stressful although he admits there's an element of risk to this new industry/venture.
column109:
From our standpoint it's a bit of a change in scope.  With this new venture, he was considering moving to Dubai to get residency there so he wouldn't have to pay income taxes. He also says he needs a tax advisor / strategist if he's going to be making a ton of income in the future.  I think he'll be an Advisory client soon enough.  

We talked about pricing on the call with him but the Proposal should be: 

Tax Prep (Scorp): $750
Accounting Catch Up (Onboarding): $800
Individual 1040: We didn't talk about this but I think his personal return is going to be a bitch.  I think we do this at $599

Ongoing Bookkeeping: He's basically winding this business down and there won't be much activity so I said we'd do it for $150 per month

column105:
Caroline & Dat met with Thalia & Christopher (her brother) and her Mom (Gladis, not sure of the spelling). We covered pretty much all of their businesses during this meeting.

We need to re-structure Thalia's Sweet Home Denver LLC to add her brother to it (he's been helping her with her businesses since she's had so much going on lately) - 50/50 split for now.

We need to turn Thalia's Tusla home into a multi-member LLC with her brother. She's not sure what she wants the ownership percentage to be on this one yet. 

We got the ownership details for the 91 Spring St LLC - I can now wrap this one up. they already have a signed proposal for this one i believe. ownership will be 33/33/33

Thalia's mom then joined the call to go over a ton of estate questions because her mom (Thalia's grandmother) died and the estate got a lawsuit payout (she was injured on a sidewalk). Dat & Caroline need to confirm the following for them:
- We'll send Thalia an email with proper confirmation that the monies from lawsuit are not going to be taxed at the estate level
- Give Thalia info on trustee fee info for her mom to reimburse herself and pay herself for time spent
- We'll also confirm that since one of the siblings is MIA that they can distribute it how her mom wishes since there's no will

Work items associated:
- sweet home denver re-structure (i already made this one earlier today)
- estate (i already created these - one for her moms return for 2025 prospects and then one for the estate too)

Brian can you make the following work items? Dat said he will work out the fees with you.
- Tulsa house multi member LLC (Address is on Thalia's 2024 tax return)
- one for the estate advise

Michael "Weezy" Hilborn is a good friend of mine from Baton Rouge.  When I was a consultant at Steward Medical, I convinced him to move to Boston for that job and now he lives in my condo with his wife.  They also created a baby in that condo and he's now looking to purchase a percentage of it.  I was also in his wedding as an Usher.   

His dad has about $115k saved up for him with the intent of gifting it to him for a down payment on his home.  He wants to instead put it towards The Dat Cave.  He is talking to his Dad and we have to work out the rental payments going forward but think the Dat Cave might have to become a real client now that it's not just me.  

He asked about taxes on the $115k his dad gifts him but told him they can do the lifetime gift exclusion.  Also told him with all of this, I'd most likely have to do his taxes.  He was a TurboTaxer before.  

He said he also has another $60k he has liquid that he might put towards the Dat Cave which would be a 10/10 investment obviously but he just had a kid (James) so think it's time for some financial planning and seems like a candidate that would legitimately need life insurance now.  Part of the reason he's reaching out for the purchase of the D-Cave is because now that they have a kid, it doesn't make sense for Erin to go back to work since Child care costs are too high.  

He also has a bunch of money in a Fidelity account and asked to move it over whenever we're ready.  

His parents also have a Peanut farm (it used to be a cotton farm..) and he told me that they are currently upset with their current advisor because he sold them out of some of their company stock from employer plans to diversify and the company stock has gone way up.  I don't disagree with the diversification aspect of it but I don't think he was monitoring this too closely and don't think he's doing a good job. 

Weezy (Michael.. I nicknamed him Weezy because he's from Lou-Weezy-ana) told me his mom has $6m in retirement assets yet she hasn't retired yet and bitches / complains about her job.  I'm not sure what Michael's dad has for assets but they have a literal farm so me thinks they have a lot of old Southern money.  Weezy will inherit this one day so think that'll eventually move over to Motta.  

Weezy is a great friend of mine and long term financial advising, tax, and wealth management prospect.  

I'll tag this to all the applicable work items but prospects for all of the items noted [1] Dat Cave Property Sale [2] Tax Prep [3] Financial Planning

Andrew briefly informed Mark what this meeting entailed and talking points before ScheLeese joined the meeting. ScheLeese tried to stay on Honeybook to do everything but found it very inefficient and I would agree. 

We discussed on how to process invoices in QB, how to add product and services so she can use it on invoices which will automatically sync to the financial statements in categories, track the payment status to see where it is at in QB and when to expect it, how to add sales tax rates per city which will automatically save when she creates an invoice, payroll setup and the proper documents to get her payroll all set up for 6/13 or 6/16 since 15th is on a weekend.

ScheLeese mentioned the retainer amounts and Mark and Andrew discussed the difference between Cash vs Accrual. The money doesn't get book until the service is performed so in the meantime ScheLeese will track those as well and then we can compare once we finalize the excel spreadsheet. We are still in the works of the spreadsheet which P24 is working on and Andrew will be meeting with Matt to compare the spreadsheets and then start adding these into her QB file. This is more on the backend but for the most part I was highly impressed how detailed and how on top she is with all her accounts setup for payroll, etc. 

Mark and Andrew mentioned that how customizable we can make this for her as she starts growing since she is on the basic setup with chart of accounts and what items she would like to see and to create more buckets for operations (revenue and expenses). 

Action Items:
-Review sales tax rates and add them into the system
-Export product and services and provide this to ScheLeese to let us know what she wants changed or updated
-Review payroll setup (tax accounts, employee forms, rates, salaries, direct deposit).
-Finalize retainer spreadsheet provided by ScheLeese (P24,Matt, Andrew)

Met Gim a few years back through Resorts World.  He's the Head of Sales for Hertz Car Rental.  They have a Hertz desk at Resorts World so Gim is there all the time.  He's ALWAYS traveling.  

He's a big wig but super down to earth and chill guy.  Really really smart, last time I saw him, he said he had set up a small "Hedge Fund" of sorts with some of his friends.  We had exchanged business cards and talked through Taxes/Biz Structure a little bit but nothing too extensive.  

Created the Karbon contact and 1040 work item.  I put it under RP2026 under a new section called "Leads (Not Likely)".  No action needed right now but wanted to get my notes into the system

Talked to Sean Elder's good friend (they've known each other since 1997) who is super super nice but NOTHING like Sean from a business/compliance standpoint.  

She has an Astrology business and says she makes $2k per month for reading and about $10 - $20k a quarter for readings.  She said she made about $133k top line and $70k net this year.  She just submitted the paperwork to convert to an SCorp this year.  [Caroline - If we can ask her for said paperwork as well to double check it was correct.. she might have to do the late election].  

She's kind of a mess.  She's working with tax attorney's on settling her debt with the IRS.  She's super nice and fully admits that she hates doing this stuff.  Also said her tax person said that her books were great and she said she knows she can do it, she just hates it.  

She said she just converted to an SCorp this year so needs a payroll set up.  Talked through QBO as well as different payroll platforms.  She seems partial to Xero but feel like she is flexible to anything.  Her big thing is being able to forecast cash flows in the system which I think both systems would be able to do.  She says she does some of her services on Stripe and some on Wix (I don't remember which one is which).  

We talked through salary and because of her quarterly cash flows, she doesn't want to pay herself too much cause she is usually in debt, then she collects on a quarterly basis to get even, then back in debt, then even again.  Think there's some cash flow management.  

Talked through BKPG / State & Local taxes and she shook her head immediately and asked if we're able to handle that for her.  

She'll be a great client who doesn't want to be involved in anything.  

The Intake form didn't work for her so waiting on Discovery Docs to build out the Karbon Contacts and work items but think there will be a few of them there.  

Request List:

1. Regular Discovery Documents
2. I have a request for them to pull the transactions from their bank account in excel.  She has everything go into her personal account right now and then she manually sorts it out for her taxes every year (yikes!)
3. Paperwork for S Corp Election

Once we have the docs we can get started with all the set up stuff.  

I think this would be a good fit for Caroline to lead so think she can do the Thank you email for this one.  I'd also remind her to open a business checking account and send her the client resource we have for checking accounts (I think it's in the advisory folder?) as well as the Payroll Proposal which will have the various platforms.  I know Andrew knows the costs of these.  

You can use an email template (just replace my name with yours) and send out discovery docs while Brian O cooks up the proposals (although we don't know any info yet due to lack of intake).
column109:
I think this will be:

1. QBO Set Up
2. Payroll Set Up
3. Monthly Bookkeeping
4. Payroll? 
5. Tax Prep
6. Local Tax Filings

I'm pretty sure I missed something but she's a good friend of Sean's who has been great to us and she's a small business that doesn't make much yet so let's help her out.  Also think this is one of Sean's first referrals and Sean does a lot of business with us so think we spice this deal up.  Also mentioned she'd get the friends and family.  

I'm thinking: 

Onboarding (BKPG): $250
Onboarding (BKPG): $400 (this is the cost of having the Gusto people set up all the payroll filings)

Those will be due upon completion with no deposit.  

Monthly Bookkeeping - $199
Bi-Weekly Payroll - $75

Bill this on a quarterly basis (i.e. bill for all 3 months of services every quarter) because that's when she gets the money in.  

Tax Prep

SCorp - 50% off
Individual - Comp
Local Tax Filings - Not sure if we have pricing for this but I don't care how much we charge for this. I'll leave this to Caroline.

column105:
Stephanie Griffin gave me a call with a couple of tax questions. They got some of the estate money in and they were able to pay CO taxes owed in full which means no more CO garnishing. Ross advised them to keep the Fed payment plan in place for now and then keep the rest of the estate money so they can invest and be more liquid (since they've been running on fumes for so long).

She asked when their 2024 taxes would be filed and if we needed anything else and I told her I'd circle back on them and can get them done this week for her. 

She also said that everyone is telling Phil that he's withholding too much on his paycheck, but she said that they filed out their W-4 as MFJ & spouse has a job - which is how I would fill it out too. I told her I'd request their paystubs through Karbon and put it into our tax estimator tool to see where they're falling. I dont think we need to charge them for the paystub calc since we'll be billing them for the W7 & their 2024 taxes shortly and they've had so much struggle, but lmk if anyone disagrees.

Talked to ScheLeese on Friday prior to the close of the sale and then again on Monday once she got access to all the platforms to ensure she knows how to operate the business.  They are closed on Mondays so it gave her a chance to level set and get her ducks in a row.  

On Friday there wasn't anything too concerning, just talked through the questions we've been working through with her throughout the process and think we have it all vetted out.  Close went smoothly! 

On Monday evening, we talked through QBO including the products and services as well as the information imported into the system.  We learned that the old accountants weren't applying payments to invoices so there were $100k of invoices in the system and also explains the massive AR balance we saw on the financials / tax return.  We have the Payments Detail so Andrew will work with P24 to get that side reconciled.  

She also has a bunch of deposits from customers (they do a lot of weddings.. unsure what's the split between Weddings & Walk Ins) which she has in an excel schedule.  They use Honeybooks for the wedding side of the business (which is their Ignition) with Proposals, Invoicing, etc.  The weird thing is that since you need to build an engagement in the HB platform, they use QB invoicing for Walk Ins.  Andrew to work with P24 to help reconcile her Excel sheet to HB as well. 

During the call we just moved all invoicing to HB which she liked a lot to keep everything in one place and also so that the workers don't need access to QB in general.  That's a win! 

She's going to build out the HB platform and also change the bank accounts over but we said we'd be available if she needs us! 

For billing, let's hold off on billing until we're done with those recons and have fully onboarded her.

Talked to Brett for about an hour (he's very long winded) about how it ended with Fenway as they've finally closed the loop on that and how DL2 search is going.  

He says they implemented a CRM tool that was specifically made for the Recruiting industry but there are some holes when it comes to the Accounting side.  He says when they were talking to the Company about it, they said their support team was awesome and their Accounting/Finance modules integrate with QBO easily but Brett said he had his Dad (who is a CPA) on the call who asked some pretty rudimentary questions and they had no idea.  

Brett said he'll probably reach out the second week of June after he's had a chance to work through some things with the software folks.  He doesn't think they'll need ongoing Bookkeeping just yet but they're definitely going to need to use us for taxes this year.  

He'll find some time when he's ready but wanted to Catch Up and give us some background.  I think if we can't find some APIs to help and it will require some development help, we'll loop in Tekyz.
column109: This will be a consulting job so most likely an hourly type of deal.  He wasn't able to provide us with the homie hook up on Recruiting Fees so think he'll want to pay full price for this one.  I'd draft the proposal with "Consulting Hours" or basically a really high end Accounting Onboarding project.

column105:
Mitched called me about his current expansions in the Mortgage space and how the CFO & Consultant they brought in both think 3PM was at critical risk which I think is a bit shallow.  The company is growing by 200%, the issue is Mitch is going full tilt in growth mode (I also think Mitch is taking a decent amount of distributions).  

He said he mostly brought on the Consultant because they are trying to land his wife's Realtor/Mortgage portfolio for a Joint Venture they are working on.  The interim CFO company is something that same guy pushed for so Mitch was essentially bringing them in to help facilitate an "Acquisition" of sorts.  I think he pays them like $5k a month and think we can easily win that business. 

The bigger thing he wanted to talk about was Three Point Insurance.  Mitch has been studying for his Homeowner's insurance license to be the Broker of Record on homeowners policies.  When closing on a house, the Mortgage originators basically have full control over what homeowners insurance they get upon closing and the first year premiums are usually included in closing costs.  Basically Mitch wants to use 3PI for all the insurance policies for mortgages they close on and earn the X% of commission off the deal.  It'd be an additional commission off what they are already getting on the Mortgage side.  He said in the insurance world, regardless if you go through a broker or go directly to the insurance agency (like State Farm) the prices are the same.  

Where I think this is typical Used Car Salesman Mitch, I don't know anyone who has any idea what their homeowners insurance is so they kind of just pay whatever.  Think a periodic "Audit" would help a lot of people.  

Mitch wants to start a new LLC that is owned by 3PM.  I believe it'll be a SMLLC for now so we'll need a proposal for that.  Brian, also create a new Karbon contact for this one. 

Also Connor mentioned going from Cash to Accrual for 3PM overall and think they want to move forward with it.  I don't think the conversation will be too bad but I think this gives us an opportunity to level set on the 3PM contract overall which is well overdue.  

Sidenote - Andrew, please get in the habit of debriefs after client meetings.  I don't think I've seen any come through and I know we meet with them weekly with potential new work items like this. 

Mitch scheduled a call for me tomorrow but think we create a proposal for 3PM for the work we're doing with separate bookkeeping proposals for all of their JVs.  I think we talked during the Accounting meeting that we have payroll for them but don't think we are doing any payroll services for them.   

Andrew to come up with a Monthly Bookkeeping fee for 3PM (as the TopCo where a bulk of the work is being done) along with monthly amounts for each Branch based on activity.  Take into account we'll have to do all of this on an accrual basis so pricing this with a fresh look of "This is one big business with a handful of small subsidiaries on an accrual basis".  

So an Entity Formation and then basically a Contract Renewal for the Bookkeeping side.
column109: Get the LLC to like ~$800 including Operating agreement.

column105:
Dat & Caroline met with Krystle and Drew to go over tax planning from a high level. First time meeting Drew - they're a funny couple and both super smart financially (in different ways). They have a lot of different considerations:
- RISEilience
- SE retirement considerations for Krystle
- Drew's equity grants
- the house renovations (energy credits)
- cash flow considerations given the house renos
- hiring the kids for the business

Notes for RISEilience side of things:
- krystle bought a one person sauna for the business (still no fridge)
- Krystle got the sober home deal so shes expecting 8-9K to come in from that soon
- she got a 25k rebate on the HVAC loan
- shes switched around credit cards to offload some of the debt onto one with no interest for 12 months
- they're going to most likely put the kids on payroll and pay a year end bonus which they could then put into a 529 plan (Dat & Caroline to research limits for 529 plans) or into a brokerage account of some sort

Notes on the house:
- they still dont have walls, windows, or heat!
- they're going to track the renos and items they buy that might be eligible for the home energy efficiency credits

Notes on Drew's equity grants:
- he gets 150k of them each year roughly
- he gets 50k of that in january and then the rest is spread out
- he emailed them to ask if they can stop selling grants to pay taxes on the grants since hes using us for tax planning and they have carryover losses that they can use for some of the gains
- drew also mentioned off hand that he wants to update his w-4 to stop withholding on his salary (not smart! and scares us), this is probably coming from his aggressive financial planner friend, so once we do the analysis he should then know to not do that
- he wants to utilize tax loss harvesting for 2025 but also wants to keep in mind that 2026 will probably be an even better year so he's mindful of things they can do now in 2025 to then still have excess carryovers in 2026

next steps:
- Dat to send them a sample deliverable of the equity stock analysis/planning + discuss pricing w/ them (converting riseilience + them into an advisory set up)
- Caroline to request: equity comp statements, drew's latest paystub, brokerage statements, mid year items (should be templates in the financial planning work items that I can use & change wording to be tax)
- Caroline and Dat to do the tax estimator calc and see where they're falling at the mid year point
- once thats done we'll have another meeting with them + Mark (so we can discuss SE retirement options) to regroup on these things

Mark caught with Sean Elder on his financial plan.

He is getting settled into Vermont.  He lives in South Burlington. His daughter is about an hour drive away now.  He only gets to see her for a few hours on the weekend. Said he ex-wife is tough to work with. He has recommended remediation and is hoping for a more flexible visitation schedule. But he likes VT, enjoys the trees and the water. He bought a bike, so he is looking forward to biking around the lake this summer. 

His rent is now $2500 and he will email me some other updated expenses fro me to update his plan.

He assets from his old 401k rolled over to Altruist so he was very happy and excited about that. He wants to contribute 1k a month to his 401k.  I need ot talk to Andrew and Caroline about setting that up. Also, he is wants to take around 17k distribution from the business to bring down the business assets to 15k. He will invest that money into his brokerage account. 

We briefly talked about the markets, kept it very high level. 

Action Items are to set up 401k contribution, owner distribution form the business, update his expenses on his plan and send him a PDF of his financial plan to review. Booked mid year appt for July. 

Discussed Billing, I will handle this- to make sure we are all on the same page.  It will be $1250 for planning quarterly and AUM charge of 75bp for Investment accts. No charge on his cash acct.

Dat & Caroline met with Amen (she's a woman) - she is starting her own medical clinic and is looking for advise. She used to do travel doctoring before and then she had a permeant W-2 job for the past 1-2 years that she recently left about 2 months ago. 

We told her what we do and what we have to offer at Motta but she is mainly focused on the tax side for now (she'll probably eventually be a bookkeeping client too). 

She wants to see prices for us to move her old EIN to the new business (she had an S-Corp when she did travel doctoring) & restructure the CO LLC (I assume its in an LLC) and then tax planning/advisory and tax prep. Foot in the door type of client.
column109: N/A but note she's Isabelle's friend

column105:
Met with Kenny at his office Saturday morning to talk through CannaLean.  The business has been around for a couple years but they haven't done any accounting and have no CFO.  

Also - everything is under Chris Johnson's name on paper but the ACTUAL ownership breakdown is tracked which I took a picture of.  I had this conversation with Mark but keeping it as a SMLLC just makes it so much easier from a compliance / set up standpoint so they kept everything on paper to CJ but the actuals are all tracked offline.  All the contracts are signed and everything is ready to go, they just don't really have a reason to do it because the company isn't really even making money yet.  

Essentially it's 3 companies, 

TopCo: CannaLean
Main Operations: CL Scientific LLC
CBD Syrup LLC: CBD line of the product that they are looking to launch retail.  

Because it's Cannabis - the money can't cross state lines otherwise everyone goes to jail cause it's still illegal federally.  CL Scientific LLC is the company based out of California that is where all the products are sold.  They are essentially a distributor on paper (compliance work around) and currently have 5 SKUs but Kenny/CJ want to get to 10 by the end of 2025.  CJ is the Chemist by trade but also a hippie.  

They are looking to put together a forecast but with no accounting work being done, it makes it kind of tough.  They actually have a pretty legit financial model that I think they paid someone to build out.  I give it an A- honestly, not too shabby.  

He sent over a bunch of information as well as added me to their Sales Platform (Nabis) and I also opened a QBO account for him while we were there.  I don't think the platforms interface directly but I think there are connectors out there.  Either way, he sent me a bunch of reports from the dashboard and that's more for forecasting than anything.  

I added Damion Peterson (I think it's a part owner and wants a bigger cut) to QBO along with Kenny.  Sent them instructions to sync the biz bank account and go back as far as they can.  That'll give us the actuals we need for the forecast.  

For the assumptions, he actually already built that out in the old model and sent us their budgets and all that information.  Kenny has a finance background and I think the group is pretty polished in general so we have a shit load of information.   

This will be: 

[A] - Business Valuation (with full forecast)
[B] - QBO Set Up / Onboarding with full accounting catch up
[C] - CFO Consulting Retainer

Maybe year end tax return but we don't even know what the business structure will be at that point so maybe we hold off or maybe we create a work item for an Partnership (which they are currently operating as currently).  

Action Items:
column109:
When I talked to Kenny, he seemed interested in potentially doing an exchange of services for equity.  

We had plans of Motta Capital before but maybe the opportunity came sooner.  Basically Motta Capital is essentially our small Angel Investor Fund and will "Own" CannaLean.  CannaLean would appoint Motta CFO and Motta would do the services for a steep discount or as a contribution of services for equity.  Not sure what that looks like yet but just getting started and I just got introduced to the other owners (Damion) so equity might be early but there's some opportunity for us here either way.

column105:
Shania Roper (Shade & Travel LLC) referred us one of her friends from New Jersey.  She works in New York but lived in New Jersey.  Her employer has had her as a New York resident until May 2025 but she's been in New Jersey for the past 3 years.  

The funny thing is that once HR finally updated her payroll to reflect that she's a Non-Resident of NY, she saw that her local taxes went away but also saw that her federal withholdings went down as well.  It seems weird to me because if anything, if her state taxes went down (no longer paying NY local taxes) than her Taxable Income would go up but maybe it's because she will owe more in NJ taxes.  

I did ALFRED research (below) and drafted one of those tax estimators for her.  She's typically been a Turbo Taxer so I'm not sure if she used to owe in NJ and/or NY.  Either way, seems like something has been fucked up between the state taxes with her payroll.  I'll ask for her prior tax returns to confirm this but ALFRED research says she's on pace to owe like $800 from a federal standpoint.  

I don't have her email or anything yet but call this a complimentary "Review & Assessment" for a tax prep client for 2025.  

Caroline - Can you kick the tires as well and see what you think? 



ALFRED Link: https://chatgpt.com/share/e/68321c8e-cf48-8000-b16e-bfb50080cc4a

ALFRED RESEARCH:

I have a client who's employer just updated her address from New York City to New Jersey.  That eliminated her residential / local tax but her federal withholdings also went down.  Why would that be?  

ChatGPT said:
Great question, Dat — and this is one of those sneaky “why is this happening?” payroll moments that surprises clients all the time. Let’s break it down:

🎯 Why Did Federal Withholding Decrease After Moving from NYC to NJ?
While the move from New York City to New Jersey removed local (city) tax obligations — which can be hefty — the reduction in federal withholding likely stems from how payroll tax withholding calculations work, especially in relation to:

🏡 1. Changes in the Employee’s Withholding Profile
When the employer updated her address:

It may have triggered a re-evaluation of her withholding allowances/exemptions or withholding tax form settings (W-4).

NJ has no local income tax, unlike NYC which has progressive local taxes up to ~3.876%.

Some payroll systems adjust federal withholding amounts based on expected state/local tax burdens to avoid over-withholding, particularly if the employee is using the "standard deduction" method on the W-4 rather than specifying dollar amounts.

👉 In short: If she was over-withheld in NYC to accommodate both local and federal taxes and now only has NJ state tax, her employer's system may have pulled back federal withholding to better reflect her net after-tax income.

💸 2. Difference in State Tax Withholding Approaches
NYC withholding is higher due to the combined NY State + NY City rates.

New Jersey withholding is lower — and has no city-level income tax. NJ uses marginal rates, starting at 1.4% and increasing based on income.

The overall state/local tax burden drop reduces the total tax estimate, so some systems automatically adjust federal withholdings to balance out total deductions.

🧾 3. How Payroll Software Estimates Tax Liability
Many large payroll providers (ADP, Gusto, Intuit, etc.) use algorithms that:

Look at total tax burden (federal + state + local)

Calculate target withholding to avoid over/underpayment

Adjust federal withholdings dynamically, especially if no dollar amount is locked in on a W-4

If your client had their W-4 set to “standard” with no extra dollar amounts or dependents listed, then any address change can tweak the algorithm’s inputs and nudge federal withholding accordingly.

🛠️ What Should You (or She) Do Now?
Review the latest pay stub side by side with one from before the move.

Compare Fed Withholding, State Withholding, and Local (if any).

See if the employer updated her W-4 or state tax form (some employers require separate NJ state W-4).

Run a withholding check-up:

Use the IRS Tax Withholding Estimator to see if the new withholding is appropriate based on expected income.

Consider filing a new W-4 with specific dollar withholding if she wants more withheld federally.

For 2025 tax season planning:

She may get a slightly larger refund — or owe less — since she's avoiding NYC tax.

Make sure to estimate NJ tax properly, especially if she’s a NJ resident but works in NYC — because she might still owe NY nonresident taxes on wages.

📌 Bottom Line
Yes, federal withholding dropping makes sense — not because the federal tax changed, but because the payroll system recalculated the expected total tax burden with a lighter state/local load.

Let me know if you'd like me to run a mock calculation or review a pay stub (with sensitive info redacted) to give her peace of mind — or if she’s a Motta client, we can run it through ALFRED Ai for a quick projection and prep a tax strategy doc.






You said:
So if the client moved from NYC to New Jersey, it's possible her overall tax burden is less or do you think she was overwithholding before and when she updated her address, they reassessed her federal withholdings? I'm just trying to gauge if the move to the different state was the factor in lowering the federal withholdings
ChatGPT said:
Excellent clarification, and you're thinking about this the right way.

✅ Short Answer:
Yes — the move to New Jersey is likely the reason federal withholding dropped, but not because federal tax rates changed. Instead, it's because:

Payroll systems often adjust federal withholding to keep the total withholding (federal + state + local) in balance with projected liability.

Let’s unpack it further.

🧠 Two Scenarios (Both May Be True):
🅰️ She Was Overwithholding Before
If she lived in NYC and had:

NY State + NYC local tax withheld, and

Used a default W-4 (no extra withholding or dependents)

Then her total withholding burden was higher — so the payroll system likely withheld more federal to match expected year-end totals. This is pretty common in high-tax jurisdictions, where systems aim to avoid under-withholding across the board.

🅱️ Her Move Prompted a Systemic Reassessment
When her address changed:

The payroll system likely re-ran her tax configuration using NJ state rules, which do not include city-level tax and have a different withholding table altogether.

Because her expected state/local tax liability dropped, the system may have reduced the federal withholding to compensate, trying to keep her net take-home pay more level.

Think of it like this:

In some cases, federal withholding is used like a counterweight to keep total taxes withheld roughly aligned with annual expectations, unless the employee manually overrides it on the W-4.

💡 A Useful Analogy:
Imagine her paycheck is a pie:

NYC took a thick slice (State + Local)

NJ takes a smaller slice (State only)

Now, the system sees, “Hey, she doesn’t owe NYC tax anymore,” so it:

Keeps her take-home pay roughly the same

Reduces the federal slice slightly to maintain the new balance

This isn’t the IRS being generous — it’s the employer’s payroll algorithm doing its best to stay accurate.

🔍 Recommendation
To confirm all this, check:

W-4 Form – See if she had extra withholdings before or if she left it standard.

Before vs. After Pay Stubs – Compare line-by-line (federal, state, local) for any % shifts.

Year-to-date Withholding Totals – This gives the clearest picture of where things stand relative to expected tax.

📊 Summary
Factor	Did it change her federal tax liability?	Did it change her federal withholding?
Move from NYC to NJ	❌ No	✅ Yes — due to payroll recalculation
Local tax eliminated	✅ Yes	✅ Yes
