NJ’s lower tax rates	✅ Yes	✅ Yes (indirectly)
W-4 update	Possibly	✅ Yes (if new info was input)

So yes — the move is very likely the catalyst that triggered a recalculation, even if her federal tax liability didn’t technically change.

Let me know if you want a plug-and-play table to show this to a client or if you want me to mock up a visual explainer. It's a good client education moment!

You said:
Is it possible because of the drop in federal withholdings, she would have to owe at the end of the year? From what I understand, state + local taxes could be deductible so if anything, I would think the federal taxes would go up
ChatGPT said:
Dat — you’re right to dig deeper here. This is a great question, and you're catching the subtle distinction between withholding mechanics and actual year-end tax liability.

Let’s clarify the key moving parts:

📉 Why Federal Withholding Went Down
This is a payroll calculation issue, not a change in her actual federal tax liability. The drop likely reflects:

The elimination of NYC local tax, and

The payroll system trying to maintain similar take-home pay by adjusting federal withholding.

But...

Federal withholding is just an estimate — if it’s too low, she’ll owe at tax time. If it’s too high, she’ll get a refund.

🧮 So Will She Owe at Year-End?
➤ Yes, she could owe — and here’s why:
State + Local Taxes Are Only Partially Deductible

The IRS caps SALT (State and Local Tax) deductions at $10,000.

In NYC, between state and local, she may have hit or exceeded that cap.

Now in NJ, with no city tax and potentially lower state tax, her SALT deduction may shrink, but not her federal income or federal bracket.

If her employer reduced withholding too much, she may be under-withheld for federal purposes — especially if:

She earns six figures and her marginal tax rate is high

She had no other adjustments (like extra W-4 withholding or estimated payments)

If she itemized before, and her SALT deduction was maxed out, moving to NJ may not help or hurt much on federal taxes. But if she didn’t hit the $10K cap before, she could now lose deduction room — making her federal taxable income higher.

🧠 Bottom Line: Withholding vs. Liability
Concept	Did It Likely Change?	Impact
Federal Tax Liability	Probably not much, unless she loses SALT deductions	Could stay the same or increase slightly
Federal Withholding	✅ Yes — decreased due to payroll recalculation	Might be too low
SALT Deduction (on Schedule A)	Possibly lower now	Could slightly increase federal taxable income

If withholding dropped and she doesn’t adjust her W-4 or make quarterly payments, yes, she might owe.

🛡️ What You Can Do As Her CPA:
Run a mid-year tax projection using her new withholding rate and compare to last year’s tax liability.

Estimate NJ tax vs. NY+NYC last year — is she actually saving? If so, that may help offset the lower SALT deduction.

Consider recommending a W-4 adjustment (e.g. line 4(c): extra amount withheld from each paycheck).

Check if she’s still itemizing — many don’t post-TCJA unless they have high mortgage, SALT, and charity.

🧾 Quick Recap for Client-Facing Language:
“Your employer likely lowered your federal withholding to reflect your reduced state and local taxes, but that doesn't mean your federal tax bill went down. In fact, you could owe more if you're under-withheld — especially if you lost some of the state tax deduction on your federal return. Let’s run a quick midyear checkup to make sure you’re on track.”

Want me to prep a one-pager template you can use for clients with this scenario? Or run a simple projection if you give me their last return and current paystub?






You said:





Assuming no changes to their tax profile, what would you project for their taxes due at the end of the year.  Should they adjust their withholdings?
ChatGPT said:
Based on the payroll data from April and May 2025, here’s a projected snapshot of Amanda's year-end situation assuming nothing changes in her tax profile:

📊 Annual Federal Tax Withholding Projection (2025)
Metric	Estimate
Average Gross Pay (biweekly)	$3,076.93
Estimated Annual Gross Wages	$80,000
Average Federal Withholding (biweekly)	~$334.69
Estimated Federal Tax Withheld (Annual)	$8,682

🧾 Now, Compare to Estimated Federal Tax Liability
Assuming Amanda:

Is single (filing Single status)

Takes the standard deduction (projected at $14,600 for 2025)

Has no children, no major deductions or credits

Her estimated federal taxable income would be:

bash
Copy
Edit
$80,000 – $14,600 = $65,400 taxable income
2025 federal tax brackets (projected):

10% on first ~$11,600

12% on ~$11,601–$47,150

22% on $47,151–$100,525

Estimated tax:

10% of $11,600 = $1,160

12% of $35,550 = $4,266

22% of $18,250 = $4,015
→ Total estimated tax: ≈ $9,441

⚠️ Result: Underwithholding Risk
Federal Tax Liability (estimated)	~$9,441
Projected Withholding	~$8,682
Potential Shortfall	~$759

✅ Recommendations
1. Adjust Withholding Now
To avoid underpayment penalties or a surprise tax bill:

Amanda could file a new W-4 and increase her withholding by about $30–$40 per paycheck (biweekly) to close the gap.

2. Monitor New Jersey Withholding
Currently, no NJ withholding appears on the pay stubs, which is critical. She may still owe NJ state tax even though she works in NYC, unless her employer is properly withholding NJ tax now and you just don’t have that pay stub.

🧠 Heads up: If she lives in NJ and works in NYC, NY State taxes will still apply, but she’ll be eligible for a credit on her NJ return for taxes paid to NY.

🧩 Final Thought
The drop in federal withholding seems modest but could be meaningful over the year. Combine that with possible shifts in SALT deductibility, and yes — she’s at risk of owing both federal and state at year-end if adjustments aren’t made.

Let me know if you'd like a printable PDF of this summary to share with the client — or if you want to run a projection with additional credits (e.g., student loan interest, child care, etc.). 






You said:
What would she get back from the state? She was not a local of New York for any of 2025


ChatGPT said:
If your client resided in New Jersey for the entirety of 2025 but worked in New York, she would still be subject to New York State income tax on her earnings. New York taxes nonresidents on income earned within the state, including wages from employment physically performed in New York. Therefore, she must file a New York nonresident return (Form IT-203) to report and pay taxes on her New York–sourced income.
Dimov CPA
+13
NY State Taxation & Finance
+13
Accounting Insights
+13
NY State Taxation & Finance
+10
Accounting Insights
+10
Accounting Insights
+10

However, as a New Jersey resident, she can claim a credit on her New Jersey return for the taxes paid to New York, mitigating the risk of double taxation. This credit is typically claimed on the New Jersey return using Form NJ-1040, Schedule A.

Regarding refunds, if her employer withheld New York State income tax throughout the year, and her total New York tax liability is less than the amount withheld, she may be entitled to a refund of the overpaid amount. The exact refund amount would depend on her total income, deductions, credits, and the amount of tax withheld.

It's important to note that while she is not liable for New York City personal income tax as a nonresident, she may still be subject to other taxes, such as the Metropolitan Commuter Transportation Mobility Tax (MCTMT), if applicable.
NY State Taxation & Finance

+2

To ensure accurate filing and to maximize any potential refunds, it's advisable for her to consult with a tax professional who can assess her specific situation and guide her through the filing process.

No proposal needed yet.. if anything a comp'd "Review & Assessment".

column105:
Talked to Kenny who was one of my first friends in Vegas.  I first met him during NBA Summer League at a J Cole concert at Zouk (work obviously) when he first started CannaLean. 

Kenny is a brilliant dude from Atlanta and just finished his doctorate program at UNLV.  He's super involved with the university and the black community here overall.  He's on a bunch of Cannabis Boards, Real estate stuff, etc.  He's from Atlanta originally (he referred us Clay) but he's settled into Vegas.  He's Married (wife's name is Lauren) and they have a daughter named Kennedy.  

He gave me the run down of CannaLean but they are in a lot of stores right now and have all the sales data as they white label their products.  They don't do anything or have anyone doing their Finances, Accounting, or Taxes right now.  He actually asked me if I would be willing to exchange services for equity which I would be open to.   

This is a business valuation including forecast which we will have to scrap together based on Sales Data reports basically.  I think Andrew can help with the Valuation.  I think he's going to want to set up a QBO account so I think I'm going to do that for him.  He just got back from Oakland today and then leaving for a Cruise tomorrow night so I'm going to meet up with him on Saturday morning in order to get this started.  

He says he has enough cash to get them through the end of the year but if they want to expand or anything like that than he needs capital but before that he needs Accounting.  He's super savvy with finances so he gets what we need to do.  

Chris Johnson (the chemist of CannaLean) is currently the sole owner on Paper but Kenny does all the finance stuff.  He says CannaLean will probably be between $150k - $250k in 2025 and growing fast (store expansion, product growth, etc.) but he says he's got a bunch of inventory in 1 SKU but sold out in 2 other SKUs that are super super high demand.  

He also said he wants to expand CBD because it's more widely used and he can get those drinks in retail stores easier.  

I'll know more about pricing tomorrow after I talk to him but there's a possibility that I might take this job on my own (or maybe a Motta investment sub?) to be there Finance Arm for this company but not sure on that yet.  

He's given me a ton of free product over the past few years and has been a good friend of mine.  We'll most likely be doing his personal taxes at the end of the year too.
column109:
Brian O - Frame out the proposal for Business Valuation, QBO Set Up, Monthly Bookkeeping, Tax Return for SCorp and Individual return for Kenny.  

I don't know what comp is going to look like for this yet but build out the proposals for now.

column105:
Talked to Matt who is Jess Tindor's "Baby Daddy".. their words not mine.  They both referred to each other as that but they've been together since high school and live together with a couple kids. 

Matt owns a Used Car Dealership (Drive Motor Company on Freemont Street in Las Vegas) who is going through a Sales Tax Audit.  They had gone through the audit and had the closing meeting and signed the closing letter but then they re-opened the audit and told him they are going from a Sample Audit to a Full Audit so he's reaching out for representation.  He says they are lying to his face and think they didn't get enough so coming back for more.  

He's doing everything in excel right now and but said interested in recommendations or Bookkeeping services cause they don't have anything right now but I said let's get through this audit first.  

He said he'd text me all the documents but also sent me his email so I think we build out a work item for this one [Caroline] but I'd say we request the letters and basically everything he sent to the auditors.  I did some ALFRED research which I'll paste below but think we can request a bunch of info from the auditors as well.  I think we can also verify that they legitimately re-opened the audit under some Nevada State Tax Code (in the ALFRED research).  

Also asked ALFRED for approach, request lists, pricing, etc.  See below! 

------------------------------------------------

ALFRED 

LINK: https://chatgpt.com/share/e/683104d0-cf54-8000-8871-14ea836efdec

I have a client (Drive Motor Company on Freemont Street in Las Vegas) who is going through a Sales Tax Audit.  They had gone through the audit and had the closing meeting and signed the closing letter but then they re-opened the audit and told him they are going from a Sample Audit to a Full Audit so he's reaching out for representation.  This is a new type of project for us, can you do a full analysis of the situation and a comprehensive guide on what might have happened and how we should handle this project? Also project request lists and instructions on steps for both Motta and the client


ChatGPT said:
Thanks for the thorough background, Dat. This is indeed a high-stakes situation for your client, Drive Motor Company, and it’s a great opportunity for Motta to extend its expertise into sales tax audit defense work. Below is a comprehensive breakdown of the situation, including legal context, project strategy, and action items for both Motta and the client.

🔍 Situation Analysis: Sample vs. Full Sales Tax Audit
📌 What Likely Happened
Drive Motor Company was initially under a sample-based audit—a common method where the auditor reviews a subset of transactions to extrapolate findings across the entire audit period. After the closing meeting and signed audit letter, the audit was reopened and expanded into a full audit. This shift typically happens when:

Material Errors or Omissions Were Found
The sample results raised red flags that warranted deeper inspection (e.g., underreported taxable sales, use tax gaps, resale certificate misuse).

New Information Emerged
The department may have received third-party data (supplier records, DMV records, etc.) contradicting filed returns.

Procedural Mistake or Internal Review Triggered Reopening
Rare, but sometimes internal QA flags incorrect audit closure.

Taxpayer Statements During or After Closing
If the taxpayer inadvertently disclosed additional details post-closing (like during a “final chat” or responding to a follow-up letter), the audit may be lawfully reactivated.

🧭 Motta's Strategic Response Plan
1. Client Representation Scope
Confirm with the client what’s already been provided to the state.

Request a full audit workpaper file from the auditor (and, if denied, file a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request or local equivalent).

Prepare a Power of Attorney (POA) to handle communications directly.

2. Audit Reopening Legality Review
Verify Nevada’s administrative code or regulations under NAC 372 and NRS Chapter 360–372 to assess whether the reopening was lawful.

Typical reopening must occur within the statute of limitations (e.g., 3 years), unless fraud, substantial underreporting, or a waiver is involved.

3. Damage Control: Preserve the Closing Agreement
Determine if the initial signed closing agreement was binding.

Was it a “preliminary closing” pending final supervisor approval, or a “final determination”? Legal definitions here matter.

4. Full Audit Management
Prepare to provide full transactional detail:

General ledger, POS system exports, customer invoices, and exemption documentation.

Ensure use tax compliance is fully supported (i.e., out-of-state purchases).

Review industry-specific risks (vehicle trade-ins, DMV filings, off-book cash deals).

5. Build a Defense Narrative
Tell a proactive, consistent story: explain accounting system limitations, new controls in place, and offer credible reconciliation plans.

🛠️ Project Implementation: Task Lists
✅ Motta Internal Checklist
Task	Owner	Notes
Draft Power of Attorney (NV specific)	Tax Manager	Include sales tax audit rights
Request original audit workpapers	Audit Contact	Log refusal for possible appeal use
Legal review of audit reopening	Dat/Nick	Research NAC 372 & any appeal channels
Review client records (GL, invoices, DMV data)	Staff Accountant	Ensure audit readiness
Prepare summary memo for state meeting	CPA	Include reconciliations, proactive measures
Schedule strategy meeting with client	Admin	Use ALFRED Ai to document all notes

📄 Client Checklist: Drive Motor Company
Task	Description	Due
POA Signature	Sign Motta’s representation form	ASAP
Financial Docs Upload	GL, sales journals, exemption certs	3–5 days
DMV Sales Detail	Export vehicle sale records (last 3 yrs)	5 days
Explanation of Accounting Methods	Summary of how they book revenue	Optional but helpful
Interview w/ Owner or Bookkeeper	Identify areas where errors may have occurred	Within 1 week

🧩 Additional Guidance for You and the Team
✳️ Consider Offering “MottaGuard for Sales Tax”
Given this engagement's complexity, a MottaGuard-style offering for audit defense—ongoing monitoring, representation, and compliance support—could be a high-value upsell.

⚖️ Be Ready for Appeals
If the full audit leads to a substantial liability and there are legal grounds to challenge the reopening, Nevada offers appeal rights through the Nevada Tax Commission.

📌 Next Steps Summary
Initiate POA & document request from the auditor.

Hold discovery meeting with the client (intake via JotForm).

Build audit defense file: client docs, transaction reconciliation, and narrative memo.

Coordinate audit logistics and prep for in-person or virtual audit sessions.

Offer optional MottaGuard Sales Tax Tier for post-audit compliance and monitoring.

Let me know if you’d like:

A draft of the POA

Sample email templates for audit correspondence

A proposal addendum or engagement letter for this case

Templates for workpaper organization (e.g., transaction summary spreadsheet)

Also, would you like to auto-generate the client’s project in ALFRED Ai? I can lay out the structure.






You said:
What's the typical pricing for a project like this? Can you provide the typical structure of these projects, pricing, and service descriptions / service terms that we can copy and paste into our ignition software


ChatGPT said:
Absolutely! This type of sales tax audit representation project falls under a hybrid of tax controversy and audit defense services, which is increasingly becoming a niche, premium engagement for firms like Motta. Below is a comprehensive template you can use directly in your Ignition proposals or quote software, including service descriptions, fee ranges, and terms—customized for Motta’s tone, service model, and ALFRED Ai infrastructure.

📑 PROPOSAL LANGUAGE FOR IGNITION: SALES TAX AUDIT REPRESENTATION
Service Title:
Sales Tax Audit Defense & Representation – Nevada Department of Taxation

Service Description:
Facing a state audit is daunting—but you don’t have to face it alone. Motta Financial will represent your business throughout the sales tax audit process, handling communication, documentation, strategy, and compliance with precision and professionalism.

This engagement covers the full scope of sales tax audit representation, from initial information gathering through to the audit’s final resolution—including appeal support, if applicable. We combine deep expertise with cutting-edge technology (via our ALFRED Ai platform) to minimize disruption to your business while maximizing accuracy, compliance, and peace of mind.

Scope of Services:
Phase 1 – Intake & Review
Discovery meeting and background review of audit correspondence

Analysis of prior sample audit findings and signed closing documents

Review of Nevada audit reopening statutes and procedural compliance

Power of Attorney filing with Nevada Department of Taxation

Phase 2 – Records Gathering & Risk Analysis
Request list mapping and collection of:

General ledger & point-of-sale exports

Resale certificates & exemption documentation

DMV sales records, vendor purchase data, and sales tax filings

Transaction sampling analysis and extrapolation review

Identification of high-risk areas (e.g. untaxed vehicle sales, inventory misclassification)

Phase 3 – Representation & Defense
Correspondence and meeting attendance with the auditor

Reconciliation of audited vs. reported sales

Audit narrative memo and reasonable cause support letters (if needed)

Escalation preparation (appeal or negotiated settlement support)

Phase 4 – Closeout & Advisory
Final findings review and post-audit liability mitigation planning

Recommendations for sales tax compliance improvements

Optional MottaGuard compliance monitoring proposal

Service Fees:
Billing Model	Fee Range	Notes
Fixed Fee (Audit Representation)	$5,000 – $8,500	Based on records complexity, time frame, and level of documentation
Hourly (Contingency Support, if needed)	$225 – $300/hr	For post-audit appeal, substantial additional work, or representation at hearing
Add-On: MottaGuard – Sales Tax Monitoring	$125/month	Includes ongoing state compliance checks, resale cert mgmt, quarterly file reviews

💡 Note: Pricing includes full access to Motta’s ALFRED Ai-powered platform for document management, tracking, and automated communications with the client team.

Service Terms:
Start Date: Upon engagement acceptance and POA signature.

Client Obligations: Timely response to data requests, full transparency regarding prior filings, and maintenance of audit-relevant records for the past 3–4 years.

Turnaround Time: Motta responds to state audit requests within 72 business hours; time-sensitive items are prioritized automatically by our ALFRED system.

Refund Policy: Due to the nature of audit services, fees are non-refundable once the defense file has been initiated.

Disclaimers: Motta does not guarantee any specific audit outcome. All representations are made in good faith based on current data and audit best practices.

Optional Upsell: Compliance Package
🚨 Keep your books clean year-round with MottaGuard – Sales Tax Compliance Plan
Includes quarterly sales tax return review, nexus updates, and proactive audits of resale certificate log.

Ideal for automotive, retail, and e-commerce businesses in audit-prone industries.

✅ Copy & Paste for Ignition Sections
You can break this up into:

"Services & Deliverables" section → paste entire Scope of Services

"Billing" or "Pricing" section → use Fee Range Table

"Terms & Conditions" → paste the Service Terms

Let me know if you'd like this in Markdown format, exported into a Word or PDF doc, or pushed into an Ignition CSV-style pricing template. I can also generate an ALFRED Ai workflow layout to match this engagement.

He asked about business clients who need BKPG/PYRL/TAX but then also asked about individuals who need Tax Prep / Planning and we said absolutely.  Talked through how we'd basically do all the work and for him it's some tax revenue (which he couldn't even offer before) as well as how it could be a great lead generator for his Financial Planning practice.. that really resonated with him I think.  

For us basically Ross will just go out there and either help convert all his clients over to Tax clients with Springbok (i.e. Motta) or he will now go out and basically find clients for us.  

Mark put it best but do we want to try to get 100 clients ourselves or if we identify the right opportunity (such as RIAs) than our services are easily tacked on so we can get 1 of those relationships which could lead to 100+ clients forever.  

I personally don't care if it's under the Motta "brand" or under a Partner brand under a white label.. no ego here (as long as the checks are coming in).

She said the weekend was crazy because she only got in with Alayah on Friday and was dealing with Landlord craziness.  

At Crimson Rd, one of the tenants is $1700 behind and he's late this month with next month due in a couple of weeks.   

For her 6313 Village property, the tenant is a sweet girl but the people who moved in above her are loud / crazy which has been a nightmare. She said she talked to the police on Sunday when they got back and went to the HOA today demanding they do something about those tenants.  She said real estate is currently driving her nuts and the tenants are also being terrible but then hit her with the "Sorry for bothering, I know who you are and good luck to your wife" to which Raquel said to me "IDGAF.. Lose my fucking number".  

From a payroll standpoint, I said we have it all set up with Harrison and just waiting for amounts.  For Alayah, she's going to talk to Tecia to see how they want to split it up. She said she'll be in Vegas for UFC Fan Expo so I'll hopefully see her then.

we went over the purchase allocation as well and Scheleese pointed out that they have some weird language in there about sales taxes - Dat is going to do another review and follow up with her on this item.

They typically collect all the due in the first quarter of the year. There is Associate Due or Family Dues. 

The club is open Memorial Day through the end of September. They have 1 full time manager on salary for 80k and hire up to 50 part time employees throughout the summer months. They use QBO online for everything, so that is good.  He did mention they still write a lot of checks for bills but would want us to transition that to all ACH if possible.

Everything is going well. walked through some of Andrew questions and finished connecting payroll for Stable Conference. 

Amir let us know he will be breaking off into his own solo RIA. Plans to work mainly from home. He seemed excited about and it will make it easier for us to work together.  He will get us own company emails when he set up his new firm and plan to use the same tax software that we have. 

He is going to talk to the guy who the 2 companies with outstanding proposals within the next week, so he will let us know about those, but was happy with the numbers we sent him. 

Action Item Caroline:  Can you research best practice for setting up an Accountable Plan between the Amir S-Corp and Amir.  I had never heard of an accountable plan before but said we would send over our best practices for setting one up. Research below but basicall a contract between the business and Amir.  We should look into setting these up for some of our other S-Corp owners. S-Corps are not eligilble for home office deduction, so this is one way to claim those expenses. 

what is an accountable plan for an s-corp and owner to have in place.
 
ChatGPT said:
An accountable plan is a reimbursement arrangement that allows an S-Corp to reimburse employees (including owner-employees) for business-related expenses without counting those reimbursements as taxable income—as long as the IRS requirements are met.
For an S-Corporation, having a formal accountable plan in place is especially important for owner-employees, since they are not sole proprietors and cannot deduct unreimbursed business expenses on their personal return (due to TCJA changes).
🧾 IRS Requirements for an Accountable Plan
To qualify as an accountable plan, the reimbursement arrangement must meet three conditions:
Business Connection
Expenses must have a legitimate business purpose.
Examples: mileage, home office, supplies, business travel, cell phone use.
Substantiation
The employee (owner or staff) must document expenses with receipts, mileage logs, etc.
Must be submitted to the company within a reasonable time (typically 60 days).
Return of Excess Reimbursements
If more money is advanced than the actual expense, the employee must return the excess promptly (typically within 120 days).
🧾 Common Expenses Reimbursed via Accountable Plan
Home office expenses (portion of rent, utilities, internet)
Business mileage (IRS standard mileage rate)
Cell phone or internet use (business portion only)
Meals & entertainment (50% deductible for meals, if business-related)
Travel & lodging for business trips
Continuing education or certifications
📄 What Should the Plan Include?
Here’s what a basic written accountable plan policy should address:
Who is eligible (e.g., all employees, officers)
Types of reimbursable expenses
Requirement for documentation and timely submission
Repayment of excess advances
Statement that non-business or undocumented expenses are not reimbursed
📂 You should keep it in your corporate records, and apply it consistently to all reimbursements.
💸 Why It Matters for an S-Corp Owner
Without an accountable plan, reimbursements become taxable wages, subject to:
Income tax
Payroll taxes (Social Security & Medicare)
This can lead to higher tax liability and IRS scrutiny.
✅ Example Workflow
Owner incurs a $200 internet bill for a home office used 40% for business.
Submits a reimbursement request with a copy of the bill and usage breakdown.
S-Corp reimburses 40% of the bill ($80) via payroll or ACH, not included in W-2.
Company deducts the $80 as a business expense.

Sharon and Dat first time meeting each other. Sharon is their fractional CFO and just came on a few months ago and has finished her 1 month close. Feels bad about Connor spending so much time with her to understand the business. 

April updates with the SBA loan received for 146k. 6/1 13k bill for annual sales vista subscription. Need to create a prepaid. Connor is going to bringing on 16 new people while speaking in robot form. July 1st is the target date for them to join on. JV associated partner setup. They wanted to start their own company, setting up EIN but Connor said just come with us and we will just charge a filing fee. Gaining a lot of traction and the word is getting out. Projected to bring 50 new people on by year end based on current growth. Each JV that gets brought on is bringing on more gross margin to cover overhead costs. Connor is getting backed up and trying to bring on more supporting staff. Looking at a business line of credit right around June. 

The goal is get market share and expand. 3PM covers all fixed costs like benefits, software, etc. 3PM is making about 30% topline. 

The 16 new people is one branch which are tied of running their own company and 3PM isn't doing a buyout with them and more of affiliation structure. 3PM has a great employee retention rate. 

3PM is working on a insurance platform. They found them from L&L and they are located in South Dakota. Turns out Insurance JV exist and partnered with credit unions. Connor wants to setting up a 3PM insurance company and 3PM should own that sector and wants Sharon to help with the structure. 

Dat provided Sharon with basic background of where he is located and from. Sharon is watching ocean 11 series on Netflix. Talking about streaming services and Connor was stating that comcast is offering a streamsaver that offer like apple tv so maybe cable might be coming back and everything is the getting to be the same cost eventually.

Sharon wanted some words of wisdom. Mitch was introduced to Dat in Nov of 2023. Started out at 200k topline and now is over 2 mil. Dat and Mitch get along besides Mitch being a Nuggets fan. Strap in with all this growth with the JV's and can become stressful on the cash flow standpoint. For Ex: 2025 Q1 cash flow was extremely tight bringing on the JV during the slower months. 

Sharon was part of tech startup for 30 years doing CFO work. 3PM is more of an controlled path and pretty much 3PM is at a breakeven point and Sharon was shocked about that. 

3PM is gaining traction based on their infrastructure. Initially people didn't trust the process. It is now a proven concept and people are gravitating towards them which is great. A lot of organic growth.

The last 20 minutes, Andrew and Connor were just reviewing the current accounting setup and to make sure it is on the right track. There is still some work to do but it is on the right track overall as they start growing.

Dat met Sharon for the first time today. Sharon is 3PM fractional CFO that has been on for the last 2 months. She has been learning a lot with Connor and 3PM to get her up to speed. 

They received a SBA loan for 146k. Sales vista annual subscription for like 13k will be coming out on 6/1. Will need to make this a prepaid. Connor is bring on a 16 person team and then became a robot so missed some other items. 

The group he is planning on bringing on is not a merger and they were going to start their own company but then Connor told them to just join them since they have everything setup with a structure in place so he is working on this. 7/1 is the target date. 

3PM is moving quick with these JV's being setup. If everything goes well, Connor thinks probably hiring about 50 people by the end of the year. Looking into a business line of credit and may be implemented in June.

The goal is market share and expansion. They have good employee retention. Connor found this guy from L&L which is from SD. Working on a insurance platform for June 1st but reality would be July 1st. They also work with credit unions as well. 3PM would owns the insurance sector and will aid in the revenue stream. 

Sharon asked how Dat pronounces his name and  where he located currently and where is was originally from. Sharon has been rewatching the ocean 11, 12 series on Netflix. Talking streaming services and probably eventually go back cable etc. Before Connor was leaving Comcast, they were implementing streamsaver which allows you to gain access to all the streaming services like apple tv. 

Sharon asked Dat for some words of wisdom since she has only been a CFO for 2 months with 3PM. Dat was introduced to Mitch around Nov of 2023. Get along with Mitch and a lot of same thought process besides Mitch being a Nuggets fan. Mitch started an LLC with a top line of 200k and now is surpassing over 2 mil. Strap on due to bringing on all these JV's which can be stressful at times. Bringing on JV's and growth expansion with benefits but then it adds additional cost to bring them on. 

Sharon was a tech start up CFO for 30 years with SaaS companies. 3PM is more controlled and she put all of the data for 3PM and found out it was breakeven position and was shocked but it is a good starting point. 

3PM infrastructure is giving confidence and it has been proven that their concept is working. Starting out as 9 employees and they are now  at 35. The word is getting out which enhances organic growth. 

Connor and Andrew is just going over the accounting setup and making sure everything is getting allocated properly. Still a work in progress but way better for the future months.

Andrew and Dat briefly chatting about internal schedules and meeting before Krystle joined the meeting. Krystle surpassed the annual sales from last year in just 4 months in 2025 so she is right on track. She also received an reward from the chamber of commerce as new business of the year which should help her growth as the summer months come. 

Devil's advocate and thinking about COGS in depth to see if there are any other GA expenses that can be COGS. Rent can be considered COGS since she needs the space in order to perform her services. Dat mentioning internal COGS with Andrew with time tracking hours to see billable vs how much time was spent. Internal training/coaching session as we wait for Krystle. 

Krystle has a lot of things on her plate like Drew being in FL due to his mother not doing well and now she had to teach yoga with her kids in the studio before school. Super unfortunate. 

A year ago she was just 4 days into her lease and now has surpassed her annual sales. Super exciting. 

Krystle has a few items in the works. She is working with a hotel about a summer residency where her instructors teach on the pool deck from End of May-Labor day for the next 5 years with possible ventures to have this opened up to the public. It is looking a flat rate and she proposed a 70/30 split. Offering Krystle any help for any future review of contracts to make sure the numbers and the cost associated makes sense. 

Krystle will be graduating from her yoga training on 6/1. She won't be hosting her own graduating party and will be hosted at the studio. "Krystle is not a narcissist." This is another reason is to be able to host her own class incase last minute changes with her instructors or they can't make it which is why she was a little late to the meeting. 

Dat is trying to get Krystle to start adding pastry dishes. Krystle is starting to promote within since she is growing pretty quickly which will allow her to create strategies against competitors in the area and grow the business. 

Landlord has confidence in her growth and offered her half rent for a few months. More sublease tenants she charges to cover the rent cost. She is working on an SBA loan for 34k but the interest rate was 13%. She is now working with Newburyport Bank to see what they can offer. She will also be getting the HVAC loan rebate of 25k. She also got a new credit card with US Bank and can defer interest for 18 months. 10k limit on the new card. 

SBA loan allocation and whether or not to pay off the debt or invest more into the business to increase sales instead of saving about 100/month on interest. If she invests more into her business, the loan would be paid off a lot quicker as well as have capital to still operate the business. 

Meals tax reporting and making sure she has the reports through toast for her monthly filings with MA. 

Tax talk- How do you project the business on a profitability standpoint for the year and Drew getting a bunch of grants this year that will cash out eventually. They have a carry over loss from 2024 which will help offset some of this. They are going to be liquidating it because now their house is sinking and doing a lot of work on the house since they live on a river. Her bottom floor has 3 walls instead of 4. They are trying to put in more beams and demolishing the foundation.

Krystle isn't making anything w2 wages and no severance package anymore. Monitor the contracts for growth and to forecast.

I texted Al about his gambling losses and previewed his refund for federal and state.  

On final review, it showed he had ~$2.8k in gambling winnings and I thought to myself "There's no way that mf-er was net positive three racks for the year". I said that to Al verbatim and he goes "Is my name Encore? Nah that just funded future gambling losses".  He's going on his Wynn app to get his losses but he was super jazzed up about the refund.  He asked if he was getting audited.  I said if they want to check the books than we will sick OCP on the IRS and they will not have a good time.  Plus it makes sense because they weren't taking credit for a lot of expenses and generally not taking credit for a lot of other low hanging fruit and Al has a W2 job with eversource.  2023 was a bad year for them so a refund should have happened to begin with. 

Al also talked about how his wife has a studio of some kind or a space that she rents out.  The person she works with is trying to rent a bigger space and wants to talk through some sort of partnership arrangement but she's lost on how to do all that stuff.  I'm not sure if she'll end up going through with it but I'll call it an Advisory | Entity Formation lead.  I told Al to talk to Mark about it.  

TAX - He'll get us the gambling losses but he's already signed so we're good.  

ADVS - Prospect for now so I don't know scope.  She might just want advice or she might want us to help form the partnership.. who knows.  Not a SEED client technically so we have the freedom from a proposal standpoint.  Not enough info to know yet

Brandon Miller - Lendmire LLC

Dat, Caroline & Andrew met with Brandon Miller and Kelly (I think Kelly does all the admin work for Lendmire?). 

Brandon walked through his plan for the business (again... and he has a very slow southern accent) and asked for some reassurance on the tax side and that he should switch to an s-corp and start running payroll instead of just taking draws. Lendmire will be a 2025 first year S-Corp tax return with a minimum of 11 states. He's taking about 10k in draws/month now so it makes sense to switch it to payroll instead. Kelly is going to get payroll set up for him so no action needed from Motta. We explained that the reasonable salary should be 60% of the business income and the remaining 40% would be distributions. Also explained that he can still take 'draws' if he needs to take more money one month etc. 

Eventually Andrew was able to walk him through the state allocation classes in quickbooks (why the call was scheduled in the first place, but it took 30 min for Brandon to get there). Brandon and Kelly are now educated to build the state classes and rules in quickbooks so they can track by state (this will be a huge help with taxes). They need to assign classes to all transactions since Jan 1 2025 so they have some work to do.

At the end of the call (while we were saying bye) he circled back to the s-corp stuff again and I told him the process again. He's going to let me know when he gets on payroll and he might file the s-corp form then or we'll file it with the 2025 return. i told him if he wants to file it when he goes on payroll thats fine just scan a copy i can attach to the return for proof tht it was submitted.

Overall they are in a great spot and they're being proactive with getting things done and organized the right way so that's super appreciated.

Action Items: I made the 2025 work item for the Lendmire S-Corp return (link below), Brian - can you please add this to the 2026 resource planning?

https://app2.karbonhq.com/4mTyp9lLRWTC#/work/kWldwj7bSPw?emailContact=&emailId=&filterMode=all&menu=&new=&query=&search=false

Talk with Andrew Piatelli from Baystate briefly.  We set up recurring bi weekly meetings for Thursdays at 9am to discuss, wealth management ideas, best practices, sounding boards for each other business and partnership.

Talked to Sol for about an hour an a half last night giving him a tax crash course and answering a bunch of his tax questions primarily around itemized deductions and tax planning. He's a "Single, high W2, owns nothing, not diversified". He's basically the same profile as Cary. He had sent me a photo of his tax return last year (think I tagged to work item) and I sent out full doc requests for 2024 to build a profile. I think he'll at least be a Financial Planning client since he has a bunch of money just in a regular savings. Pretty much same as Cary. He'll make between $225 - $230 between base and commission with a majority being commission. He's Head of Sponsorships at Resorts World and Cary's boss.
In a previous Debrief I mentioned his aunt is a Prepper so he still might have her do the prep work (she honestly probably doesn't want to) but he doesn't know anything about finances (similar to Cary) so looking to be more thoughtful about his finances cause he just bought a house.
He closes on 6/1 and there's a Sale / Lease back so he'll be a landlord for a month. He brought up he doesn't have a side hustle and not diversified so he didn't think he would have avenues for deductions but luckily I remembered her mentioned that on the golf course. That's what makes me elite. I think there is opportunity for renovations while the property is a rental. He sent me his tax (and financial planning) docs so I'll talk to him about what we can do in June to maximize on tax savings.
I'm not sure if he'll end up doing prep with us but most likely. We'll charge him something but think he's a good avenue for new clients (similar to how Cary has been a big advocate which has helped us grow in Nevada) and also an opener of doors in Las Vegas. He's also a good friend of mine and will most likely be a Financial Planning FGA client for Mark so I'll work with Brian for a proposal. He also still owes us for his girl's amendments.

Talked with Al, reviewed his application for Harvard Business Loan. They are going to get a loan for 25k, for around 6% interest rate. he doesnt have all the details yet but he was excited to being getting some additional working capital. 

We walked through 2023 return quickly.  Showed him the changes to expenses, he didnt have any questions, is good to go for 2023. 

Andrew need to send him 2024 Balance Sheet, P&L and Cash Flow. 

Depending on the term of the loan, he will need to send these reports within 3months of year end close annually. 

Al invited us to his next big hat exclusive in June, releasing a collab with Frank the Butcher. Said they have people sleeping outside the store to get in line for these hats. They are focused on creating more hat drops, dropping new hats more frequently and throughout the week sometimes. They will only make 72 of the exclisive hats and than they immediatly double in value in most cases on the resell market.

Action Items:

Andrew - 2024 Reports

Caroline -1. File 2023 Crown Legends Amended Returns. 2. Work on amended return for Al and Emmanuel for 2023 Taxes.  Provide Thomas updated K1 to Al for delivery.

I talked with Malisa yesterday she is purchasing a house and needs a 185k for the down payment and wants another 10k, to replenish her bank acct so she had an emergency fund. She was very nice and just super concerned about paying enough taxes now because she wont have the money in april is she gets abig tax bill from the QDRO distribution.  She has 360k QDRO, using for the down paymeny and rolling the rest into an IRA. Caroline put together a quick analysis to send over to reassure Malisa on the amount that needs to withh.eld for taxes. Malisa asked if we file taxes and I said yes, she would like us to work with her on her taxes for 2025, she doesnt feel like H&R Block understands the QDRO situation and they were not helpful with her questions. 

2025 Will be a very basic return it sounds like, W2 70k from teaching and this QDRO distribution. Work item has be created and I sent out discovery requests. 

Action Item: Brian O update discovery requests on the Tax Return work item template, to requesting tax return 2024 and 2023.  


Created Michael Holts Client ID and put in the referral section of the debrief.  If we see these empty start filling them in. It is state, last, first, last 4 digits of phone number... no phone number can put all zeros

 TX_Holt_Michael_6020

Coca Cola (Reyes Distribution) was a sponsor for a United Way golf tournament and they had one of the people drop out.  As I'm the 6th man for any of the Sponsorship friends, I was called upon to fill the spot and fulfilled my role on the "Stay Ready Crew" valiantly.  

Kevin is the Account Manager from Coca Cola who oversees the Resorts World account.  He replaced Corey Woods who left Reyes for Coca Cola Corporate.  Kevin's a great dude but Dre and I say it all the time that he's "Not Corey" as Corey is one of our close friends.  

Golf tournament was fun.  It was Cary Jacobson, Solomon Schwartz, and Kevin Horton.   The crazy thing about what is happening but Aly was the only person in our friend group who asked me for help on taxes our first year doing it (and Cary obv) but now it's getting trendy to do so.  Sol's aunt is a Tax Prepper and she did his taxes but he asked me for some tax advice last year and he also just brought a home so said he'll be calling me for taxes this year.  I'm not sure if it's tax planning or tax prep but I think it's a 2025 tax prep prospect either way.  He didn't refer Heather Conway (his GF) to his aunt so thinking he'll be over this year.  

The round was actually a decent amount of Business Development.  I don't really talk about taxes or anything.. Sol bought a house so talked through mortgages, interest rates, etc. and then Kevin asked some questions about Real Estate and some tax stuff because him and his wife owed two years in a row but nothing changed.  He asked if we do individual taxes and I said we do everything.  He said he'll be swinging our way for taxes this year and as he was saying it, Cary was walking by and go.. "Highly recommended.. he's the best in the business". 

Got some free swag but it was hot and I wanted to get home to Brody.  

Action Items: 

[1] - Made a work item for Kevin (You're welcome Brian O) but didn't attach the folders and also know he has a spouse. 

[2] - For Solomon, I want to say I created a work item for him for 2024 but cancelled it? Brian O to look to see if there was on made from way back in the day.  

I'd hold off on proposals but think we add them on the list of New Clients 2025.  We still have to think through pricing.

Firm FYI

Signed Motta Wealth Management up for compliance subscription. Conducted onboarding meeting.  Went over Compliance calendar. Continuing Education. 12hrs annual for the firm aka Mark. Looking to focus on locking down compliance over the next month to understand, all the things i need to be tracking, how a potential audit looks like, and safe guards between firms. I have 4 more 30mins sessions with onboarding and 1hr session with a compliance specialist.

Mark and Andrew did quarterly call with Matt Coleman.  He is very happy with our services and I made sure to highlight all we have done for him and the progress he has made from a compliance and organization standpoint. 

Action Item: Brian & Caroline to create quarterly tax estimate work item for Matt Coleman. 

Caroline to Calculate YTD tax estimates through April for Federal and MA. Matt said he would be able to make these payments over the next couple of weeks, once he gets some big checks coming in. This will be good, then we will have him all up to date and not have to worry about anymore big tax bills. 

General thoughts?  Do we want to charge $99 a quarter for estimates. We have all his bookkeeping numbers, should be a relatively light lift. This would include doing the calculations and making the online payments on his behalf.

Caroline and Mark met with Sally Wu.  Walked her through her 2023 Amended Tax Return. Went over Self Employment Tax in Detail. A lot of back in forth about how she doesnt think she should have to pay taxes and that her mother never pay taxes and owns real estate. So i tried to explain to her that her situation is probaly different, I asked if her "does your mother do modeling?" She admitted that her mother does not have modeling income. 

No action items here, put her 2024 return on hold for now. She is going to talk with her mother's CPA and see what he thinks, she said based on our conversation if she goes with us she will have to pay 5k in taxes, she wants to shop around and see if she can do better.  I dont think that is how taxes work, butwe had talked in circles enough for one call.

Mark, Brian and Andrew met with Tekyz.  

We set up all the accounts that tekyz will need for their work with us. We were introduced to the team, updated on timeline and hours already worked and projected hours for the projects. 

The accts included - OpenAI, AWS, Jira, 

Didnt get into any details on projects, just spent the hour setting up accts.

Vinod, is creating an app for his own music business, to help with scheduling, hosting training recordings. He just started taking classes on n8n. So he was excited to hear that, thats what we were recommended to use. 

He was just picking my brain on automation and AI, in the accounting space. He was trying to create his own app but wants to see if he could potentially apply it to other areas. He seemed impress with my knowledge of the spaces and our connections. Told him about Tekys and had him look up Anyquest.  He was super impressed, when i told him about the AI agents anyquest offers. 

He wants to have another meeting and he wants to do some research and prepare and see if he can bring us some info on whats possible for us with AI agents.  I told him we love having these conversations and happy to continue them. I said i would add Dat to our next call. 

He is having twins in July or august and they want to sell their MN house before that. Need to some estimated tax payments on the capital gain when the time comes. 

Overall, the call confirmed, we are talking to firms and individuals that are really on the cutting edge when it comes to technology. We are nimble enough to implement, test and adapt, while having a data source, our clients to use to build and improve potential AFLRED app.

column105:
Talked to Scheleese for about an hour an a half.  She's a personal friend of Ross for about 7 years.  They were introduced years ago and has since moved closer to Ross and have kids around the same age.  

Scheleese is an Attorney (not sure what kind) and her husband is a Financial Analyst.  She has already purchased TeeLee Floral and Events [Sidenote, Brian O - The business contact wasn't created so I created it to do this Debrief].  But the business owners are 3 friends who don't have any business sense.  They are selling the business for 1x Net Income ($190k) and not using a business broker.  Comparable businesses are selling for 4x... 

She says they basically have no formal infrastructure and that one of the owners who is in charge of Client Relations is the person doing deliveries for all orders so she doesn't have time to do any relationship type work.  The business was trying to be prudent and didn't want to outsource/hire for someone to do deliveries.. 

She doesn't need a full on analysis or valuation but she said she'd like us to do a check of the QuickBooks, Review the returns, and do a Compliance check on the business before she buys it.  This is sort of like what Synergy should have done with Jeremy before they bought NFC.  I'll lead the charge for this along with OCP on the Accounting side and Caroline on Tax and Mark on Compliance.  Basically just want to make sure the business is up to date.  She thinks they had a CPA and their books are pretty clean so she said they ~should be fine but wanted to be safe.  This is essentially the same as doing a final inspection before closing when you buy a house. 

She also talked about Post Acquisition so talked through Bookkeeping, Payroll, and ongoing compliance.  She already has access to their QBO and said once we get the requests out she'll send over docs ASAP.  She's a bit nervous about this acquisition and said that if the business does well, she wants to quit her job and do this full time.  

She asked for tax services as well so I said that would be easy.  I think this will be a decently big project to help with the acquisition but could expand as she enters the entrepreneur life.  

 

[1] - Review QBO to ensure there's nothing glaring. Basically do an inspection of it.  {OCP}

[2] - Caroline to Review tax returns

[3] - Mark and/or Caroline to check if the business is in good standing with registrations.  They also have sales and use tax so let's make sure they're current.  

[4] - Proposal: 

[a] - This is basically a Due Diligence job which I don't think we've really done yet but I'd use the same service as we did with Cam for the JetSki business.  I said for the Due Diligence (QBO Review, Tax Review, Compliance Check) it would be less than $1,500 all together.  This includes the consult from today and whatever else she needs between now and closing.  I think we do it around $2,500 gross and $1000 net. I said we don't need to do the full assessment because she already bought it so think she's good with it. 

[b] - Onboarding: Andrew to Assess but think she said books are pretty clean

[c] - Bookkeeping & Payroll: I said this company would typically be between $450 - $650 but said it'd be on the lower end of that (but also think she'd need Payroll & Sales / Use Tax) so thinking around $450/$500.  Defer to OCP on this.  

[d] - Taxes: Her husband does their taxes now and was uncomfortable when they were W2 works so asked if we can do the business and personal taxes.  She is not sure if they'll be an SCorp this year (I think she'll be Schedule C).  We talked about bundling so think we can do the 1040 with Schedule C for $200.

Caught up with Stephanie Griffin through text because she's currently on hold with the IRS (for over an hour now) so she didn't want to loose her spot in line. She had questions on the W-7 and who signs and how to coordinate. I'll attach my texts below for reference but the summary is:
- Helen (Phil's sister) is the executor and she's going to be signing
- I attached the letters of administration showing that and the death certificate the the w-7 form to try to avoid any issues with the IRS
- the IRS needs it to be a wet signature so Helen is going to have to print and sign and mail the form to Stephanie from the UK
- Stephanie will then mail the passport & signed form w/ attachments to the IRS (I sent her a prepaid shipping label)

Hi team - 

Please see the "Tax Post Mortem" work item which was discussed last Friday.  We should re-brand this work item but I think it's more like an "Internal Projects 2025" work item for each of our respective areas.  

I've also created a section under tasks for all of the WORKING Karbon templates that are out there.  Similar to our tax template, these work items are the most current draft of the Karbon templates.  For example, the old tax template didn't have the requests for Bank Account info with the Draft return and didn't have the Client Testimonial task under the Final Return (Previously it's own section).  With all of these templates, the idea is to use these to make our continuous improvements to these work items and save them down as Karbon Work Templates.  

Best,
Dat

Caught up with Shania and opened her new LLC for her.  

The original entity was formed as a Partnership with her ex boyfriend when she still lived in NYC.  His father was an attorney and they have since dissolved the entity and finalized everything in 2024.  

Established the new entity in Nevada and put the registration fees on the Corporate Card.  She has a travel trip to Belize coming up and one of her clients is a bartender and paid her in cash so she just paid me in cash.  I said it would be $500 total and the total registration fees was like $425 or something.  She also wanted registered agent services so that can be the additional $75.  

She doesn't need an Operating Agreement (SMLLC) so just registration and EIN for this one. 

[1] - If Brian can toss that in a proposal and make as paid via alternative method.  Still technically a sale so want to get credit for it. (A) Entity Formation [SMLLC] - $425 (B) Registered Agent Services - $75 annually

[2] - Caroline,  I wasn't able to get the EIN established cause you have to do it during business hours.  Can you Apply for an EIN?

[3] - Caroline, Can you create a work item for the registered agent services? I think Mark created one for their annual registrations too. 

[4] - Note for IA (Internal Accounting) that should not hit cash but "Owner's Equity" cause I'm not going to deposit this into the bank account cause it's pointless.

column105:
Camden is currently a senior at CU. Go Buffs! He also used to be an offensive lineman for the buffs but transitioned to long snapper. Highly impressive individual as well as being very knowledgeable at his age. 

Camden was connected through Mitch through a class at the leed school of business in CO. Camden just started up a title insurance company. There was a big pitching competition in CO and he just won like 150k from that. Mitch is helping him on connections in the industry. He is planning on talking with someone else on services located in CO as well. In the next few months, the goal is to raise about 500k. He has about 15k of like non dilutive capital in the bank account. 

They are going to be a digital title insurance underwriting platform. They will be the actual underwriter and they need 200k of paid in capital to get licensed as a title insurance agency and to issue out policies. Need 750k of capital reserve in the state of CO. Joking about Gatorade vs Body Armor. 

They are a C Corp out of Delaware. No employees. No payroll. Wanted to know who we use for the accounting and tax side so he can talk with his tech side. QuickBooks, multiple payroll providers.

Talked to Brandon for about an hour, he's from the hills of North Carolina in the Ashville area.  He's a mortgage broker (Lendmire LLC) like 3PM so they have all the same state registration requirements similar to that mortgage space.  This will be an Andrew  job.  

But first, from a tax standpoint.. Lendmire LLC is a Sole Prop right now because he's been operating at a loss for the first few years but says he's already made enough profits to cover the carry over loss as of 4/30 so he's already breakeven from a tax standpoint.  He's most likely going to see a decent profit this year so talked through LLC vs SCorp and the salary requirements there.   

[1] - Financial Statement Compilation (Cash -> Accrual)

He has a CPA right now but the guy is in his late 60's and is looking to retire.  He is looking for a new CPA because he is trying to get Financial Statements in accrual form for his Tennessee mortgage registration.  

He also is looking to expand nationally and dump the profits into infrastructure (getting registered/licensed in every state, hiring more mortgage officers in different states, etc.) so he's looking to expand to Tennessee cause it's right next door and California because it's a massive market.  He's also looking to do Illonois and Oklahoma soon as well.  These states usually need Financial Statements compiled by a CPA on an accrual basis (Andrew has done this before) and Tennessee is the priority right now.  His current CPA said they would need to do a full on audit if he's going to compile the financials which is stupid.  They also said it would take at least 3 months to do and that he was currently traveling across the country in an RV.  He's basically retired and Brandon was like "Yeah good for you and all but I'm trying to grow a business".  


He uses QBO which he'll give us access to and he uses Gusto for Payroll.  He has an Operations person who does all the accounting, payroll, operations, etc. for the entire business.  She'll be a key contact.  

[2] - Consulting | QBO by state

He was dead set on wanting to track all of his revenue and expenses by state so he's looking to build that out in QuickBooks.  He said they can probably map all of their revenue and expenses by state right now if he meets with his Ops person for a few hours.  He also said they're gonna start checking transactions a few times a week to make sure they are going to the right state.  I said this was probably overkill and we could do a state apportionment from a tax standpoint but he wanted to do this for internal business purposes as well (track which state is doing better or worse).  

He said he'd like help with all of that and also helping with mapping employees by state in Gusto into QBO as well.  

He said he's reconciled with bank statements through 12/31 but hasn't done anything in 2025 yet because he was about to do this overhaul.  He said he'll get all the information for 2025 reconciled then mapped to states and we can use that as a template to build out the pending states (Cali, Tennessee, etc.).
column109:
He asked about fees and I said usually when a client is looking to do different things, it's more advantageous to bundle the services together but I'd send him our fee schedule (including the consulting sheet Sophia just made).  

He said he's not cash flowing too strong right now and it might be tough to commit to a giant fixed fee bundle so he'd rather do an Hourly basis.  I'm fine with this.  He's a good guy and from talking to him, he's thinking about this in all the right ways and super diligent.  He doesn't seem like a Mitch Mortgage person.. more like a Todd Mortgage person... hopefully.  

I think the FS Compilation will be $799 or whatever.  Bring it down to $600.  

I also said how we often help with CPA Verification and he was jazzed about that so he'll keep us in mind.  Overall he was pretty excited because the old CPA seemed good but old and not looking to go a the same pace he is.  Brandon seems like a smart / good dude overall.. THICC North Carolina accent.

column105:
Mark spoke with Torres Quetzal. 

Torres was inquiring about our interest in teaching a career development class on Quickbooks. I am still not sure if he is legit or not.  He said he is a sole prop and create career advance classes across various topics and gets referrals from college across the country for students for his programs.  No website. Phone call connection was spotty. 

He currently is estimating a budget of $1350 to pay for the class. Wants to know if we think that is reasonable and how long would it take to teach a class like this.  He is emailing the curriculum for us to review.

Caught up with Heather via text and then Sol (Heather is a nurse and this is super not her thing so Sol helps translate) via phone call.  Both people were super impressed.  

The change was that Heather thought that if the child is over 18 than they can't be claimed anymore.  She also sent me a picture of the divorce agreement that said that Lola would be claimed by the father from 2011 until 2023 when Lola was emancipated (I believe when she turned 18) but the question is whether or not the father claimed Lola in 2023 which would be huge.  The agreement says they alternate years for who gets to claim their son Cian until he turns 18 as well.  

Key word in all that is that the dad can claim Lola UNTIL 2023 when she was emancipated so it's possible that he didn't claim her on her taxes because she was 18 at that point.  What the agreement didn't consider is that you can still claim a child past 18 if they are in college so if the father didn't claim her because she was 18, Heather could because Lola lived with Heather and the father is pretty out of the picture so doesn't pay for any of the kid's expenses.  

I explained to Sol that a decent Tax person would be able to identity that Lola can still be claimed as a dependent which is only a $500 credit but gets the HoH designation which is pretty clutch for the tax rates and standard deduction.  Kobe used to say he wasn't worried about the primary defender guarding him because he knew he already had him beat but he was always looking at the help defender to see how he was going to beat him.  Turn that into what I'm about to tell you but the Help Defender in this situation is the American Opportunity Credit.  She made below the Income Threshold (think it's like $90k or something) to qualify and she pays for all of Lola's education expenses so got an extra tax credit for that.  Also the state of Arizona gives a tax credit for fees paid to public schools so got those fees for Cian as well.  

All in all it was $5k for each year (2023 and 2024).  2024 is approved by her and she signed the signature, also verified bank account info already.  Caroline to take a final review but this should be good to file. 

Sol is going to find out if Lola was claimed in 2023 and will confirm that once he finds out.  Sol also said to invoice him for whatever it costs to do all of this.  I think we have his Gmail so just invoice him for 2024 but under Heather's name.  I know I originally said comp it so Brian did the right thing in showing the $0 for her because we need to get a signed proposal from the person we're filing the taxes for but also send an invoice or separate proposal TO SOLOMAN SCHWARTZ'S GMAIL but still label it under Heather's client contact.  I think this is similar to how we did it for Shane O'Shea / Lauren Vargo. 

Sol has decently high influence in Las Vegas so think this will help us in a lot of ways in this market.

Dat and Caroline met with Stephanie and Phil Griffin to connect on the IRS notices (intent to levy) and CO wage garnishes for taxes owed from the 2023 returns. They filed an extension in 2023 so they didn't actually file these until October of 2024. Their H&R block advisor did a horrible job of preparing them for the capital gain and basically told them the gain would be excluded - and then flipped the story at tax time since they hadn't lived there for two of the past five years (which is correct, but the delivery/lack of consulting on it was horrible). They had owned the house for 20 years but moved to CO in 2019, and decided to rent the house to a family friend (for the same amount as the mortgage), and then sold it in 2023. so they got hit with roughly 68K of taxes due. they have not paid any of it yet, and stephanies wages are being garnished by CO. Stephanie was super upset/stressed on the call, understandably so. 

Plan is for Caroline to look at payment options through the IRS pro account and send them to Stephanie/Phil, ideally we get a payment plan to start on June 1st. ALFRED RESEARCH: 

https://chatgpt.com/share/e/680aa935-6aa8-8000-b393-f9bc1c3c6bc1

Can you claim your client who is over 18 as a depdendant? They lived with them for more than half the year (also went to college) but covers over half their expenses


ChatGPT said:
Yes, it's possible to claim a client over age 18 as a dependent under certain conditions — but it depends on whether they qualify as a Qualifying Child or a Qualifying Relative under IRS rules. Let’s break this down for your scenario:

✅ Potential Eligibility as a Qualifying Child
Since you mentioned the client is over 18 and attending college, we need to consider whether they qualify under the "student" exception to the age rule.

Requirements for a Qualifying Child:
Relationship: They must be your child, stepchild, foster child, sibling, stepsibling, or a descendant of any of them.

Age:

Must be under 19 OR

Under 24 and a full-time student for at least 5 months of the year.

No age limit if permanently and totally disabled.

Residency: Must live with you for more than half the year (time away at college counts as living with you).

Support: They cannot have provided more than half of their own support during the year.

Joint Return: They didn’t file a joint return unless it was only to claim a refund.

➡️ Key Catch Here: If they cover more than half of their own expenses, they may fail the support test for a qualifying child. That alone would disqualify them under this category.

🧐 Can They Qualify as a Qualifying Relative?
If they don't qualify as a qualifying child, check for qualifying relative status instead.

Requirements for a Qualifying Relative:
Not a qualifying child of anyone else.

Relationship or residence: Must either live with you all year as a member of your household OR be related to you in a way that does not require living with you.

Gross income: Their gross income for the year must be less than $4,700 (2023 threshold; indexed annually).

You must provide more than half their total support.

➡️ Another Key Catch: You said they cover more than half of their own expenses, so unless their total support is still mostly coming from you (or the client you represent), they likely wouldn’t qualify here either.

Summary

Test	Requirement	Likely Outcome
Qualifying Child	Under 24 and full-time student	✅ Possibly, if they didn’t provide >50% of their own support
Qualifying Relative	Gross income under limit + you provide >50% of support	❌ Likely fails if they covered most of their expenses
What You Should Do
Run a support worksheet (Pub 501 has a good one) to get the exact breakdown of support provided.

Confirm whether the client paid more than half of the individual's total support, not just "expenses."

Be careful if they file their own return — especially if they claim themselves.

Let me know if you'd like to walk through a support worksheet or need help modeling out the support split. We can run some numbers together.
