column105:
Caught up with Sean via phone call originally about his trust but didn't really spend much time other than general mechanics as he wanted to talk through Financial Planning.  

He just sold his house 2 weeks ago and has about $100k net from it.  He said he sold it at a loss which got a bit awkward but think it was driven by the divorce.  Either way, he was the "I have a bunch of money and I don't know what to do with it". Talked through high level planning mechanics such as diversification but said Mark was our guy for that although I dabbed in a past life.  It turns out, Sean used to be an advisor as well with MassMutual.  He said he's currently not working with an Advisor and loves working with us so wants to keep it all in house.  He also said he has a Solo 401k that he opened himself and wanted to bring that over as well.  I said we're most likely going to contribute to that from a tax savings perspective anyways so we can do all of this at once.  After we get a plan together and know what he's going to have as far as assets, we'll finalize the trust.  

Do we think this is an Italian Job? We can do it from an RIA standpoint as we're registered in Nevada but not sure about life insurance.  I think a Whole Life policy would make sense for him.  Especially if he's self employed.  

He also said he got a couple IRS notices saying that he was going to get about $8k back (great job us, if I remember, we were a bit more conservative so this generally makes sense).  He said he sent the letter to Sweeney and was wondering how long it was going to take to get the money.  In my opinion, I think he'd me more than happy to just pay us the $8k for the financial plan along with all his accounting, payroll, and taxes for 2025.. idno, we'll see.  

Action items: 

1. DLe to send an email introducing Sean & Mark. 
2. Sweeney to research the tax letter to ensure it's just the IRS taking a long time to pay people
3. Mark to compile a list of documents we need for financial planning.  ChatGPT'd a common request list, see below.  
4. Mark to schedule time with Sean to roll his old Solo401k over.  I think we'll contribute to it for his tax stuff and he said he always has trouble contributing for it.  
5. Mark to open a Brokerage account for Sean so we can at least put his money in a money market fund for now.  He has it in a savings account and he didn't like that it's depreciating. 
6. Mark to look into insurance options for Nevada.  I know Landon Mance is a planner here but not sure if Hunter or Gaye would be licensed in Nevada. We can also get licensed ourselves but not sure the lift on that.  If it's easy enough, WL policy commissions are niceeeeee

column33:
Michael Nwansi called me for a CPA Verification / P&L statement for Adrienne & Michael.  He also gave us an email intro which I will pin to the work item.  I also added both Adrienne & Michael and their respective businesses into Karbon.  A bit of googling but not the necessary contact info (I think).   

Michael says they'll need the CPA verification and/or P&L in February for a Construction Loan (this is very similar to the Sally Wu client so let's not fuck this up) for around ~$4 million with a property value over $10 million or something.  It might have been a $2 million with $4 value but I heard all of those numbers so not sure.  Either way 7 figure loan.  This won't be till February but wanted us to get queued up early. 

I'm not sure if they are together or just biz partners but Michael said they were both business owners.  

Adrienne has a Realty Shop and also used to be a professional athlete (runner) in Amsterdam and now some hot shot realtor.  She has a pretty decent size team of Realtors so could be a good lead referral stream.  

Michael is a Partner at LMB Partners. LMB is "Law Meets Business" and the firm specializes in transactions.  I briefly read he did some sort of $10.5 million dollar Cannabis transaction.  Probably too big for us but who knows, we seem to start to be dabbling into the M&A space.  

I sent out the email for the Intake form so we'll see what comes back but think the idea is to get their taxes (and may do their taxes?) but start to get the process together for the CPA verification.  We'll probably definitely need bank statements for her but not sure what we'd need for Michael.  I think it might be a Letter for her and P&L for Michael.  We'll see what the scope is but "Stay Ready"

column105:
Mark Dwyer talked with Matt Coleman. Went over our recap of questions from bookkeeping onboarding.

1. Payroll Acct, he is going to just close it
2. He will stop doing all the transactions between personal and business now that we have payroll set up
3. He will stop Whatnot charges and move those to personal. 
4.Checks are all contractor pay to Jason Baker, he will have a conversation with Jason about adding him to Gusto as a contractor; he withheld 25% for taxes though, whole situation doesnt make sense

Payroll
We have completed payroll set up, need to invoice him $400 for onboarding fee.  We set his salary on auto pay weekly for 2k. He said he has a bunch off money coming into the business so not worried about cash flow.

Went to New Hampshire to meet with Adzemen at their office for a level set meeting.  It was with Brian / Ann at their home that they use as an office as well.  

I think we did a terrible job on this client since bringing them on so wanted to see how their experience has been and what areas we can help.  

Matty has never sent them financials for their books.  I sent them their QB Management Report and Gilgun was super confused on all of that.  We talked through the P&L and started to talk through how we are doing to do a full COA Scrub (AG is working on this currently) then we can change account names, mappings, rules, etc.).  Once we get the data cleaned up, we can start to develop analyses and actually provide financials that make sense.  

For example, right now he's pricing jobs based on a 12% estimated overhead.  Not sure if that's correct.  

Brian also talked about tracking Projects in QBO.  He's currently just doing it on paper right now and not really tracking.  We can start to implement this in QBO I think. I asked him to scan/send all those bids and quotes so that we can start tracking.  We'll need to do data clean up before we can fully implement.  

He talked about how they are taking less work but around the same Revenue / Profits.  He says it's been frustrating to stay around the $1 - $1.5 top line mark and not grow.  

We talked through some business strategy because (1) he says he pays significantly higher than the competition (2) They are spending tons of unnecessary costs such as

(a) His Foremen (project managers) are not doing a great job and just not great from a leadership or management standpoint.  Brian says it's creating a toxic environment and costing the company dollars.  For example, he says one of his guys leads jobs but hasn't got his license in 7 years so that limits his abilities and makes jobs more inefficient.  

(b) Equipment Rentals because guys break tools all the time and they need to rent additional to get it done. 

(c) Lost tools.  He said they had 11 ladders at the beginning of the year and now they have 5.  No one knows where they are. 

Along with these costs, Brian is spending most of his time leading projects and not leading the company.  He says he's okay with paying his guys the highest compared to market but would like the quality if that's the case.  He says he's going to do some restructuring.  

I suggested an incentive program for Foreman.  Right now their bonuses are arbitrary cause Brian's a nice guy but I told him if their bonuses was based on Project performance (efficiency, injuries, tools, etc.) that it would give them a reason to care about those things because right now there are no tools to keep them accountable.  He loved that idea.  He has 3 Foreman and 1 of whom the company thinks is a "Kiss ass" because he cleans the tools after he's done and makes sure job sites are tight.  I said if you pay him the biggest bonus, others will see that's how they make more money and think it would be helpful to save on all these lost money.  

We talked about some other business strategies such as buying a dump truck for around $40-$50k and I said that was a no brainer as they are spending ~$2 - $5k a week on dumpsters.  He got an auto loan with Capital One so he's gonna pull trig on that in 2024.  

He also uses a large portion of his home for Adze including (1) Parking Trucks & Large Equipment (2) Using his separated barn as storage for tools, equipment, etc.  and also going to convert that into the Adze HQ.  (3) Large offices for Brian / Ann.  (4) He also hosts company functions at his house.  

I told him that he can either write those off or he can rent his personal home to the business as well.  He was very excited about that idea. 

Action Items on our end are: 

(1) Clean up COA - Andrew
(2) Add vendors to transactions - P24
(3) Schedule regular monthly meetings with Adze - Dat
(4) Follow up with action items on their side.

Raaaaaaaaaaaaaaaay

Great guy, just checking in and making sure he's doing things the right way. Guy is more organized than 95% of our client.

Still working a 9-5, doing some bartending, then also this LLC side work.

He's sort of shifted from low level electrical work to overall handyman work, wants to make sure he's compliant with how his LLC is structured. I think he'll be fine.

Has an excel sheet with expenses for LLC (materials, fuel, food receipts, vehicle repairs/maintenance, miles) basically everything you can think of.

Has a business checking account & credit card, doesn't mix any personal with business, vice versa.

Only thing that's changed from last year is transactions through the business, but thinks with all the repairs to his work vehicle he'll be close to making no money, but still squirreled away from money in case he owes taxes (smart).

Actions Items:

-Wants a good list of items to track for write offs (home office) uses garage, yard for storage, basically anything he didn't think of, industry specific or not.

Mark - potential financial advising client for sure.  He's very interested in investing and making some coin in that area

He has investments kind of all over but questions include:

-Investments to make off 401k, HSA, if they should pull ETFs and invest differently
-About $100k in home equity, what can he do
-How to raise credit

Wants to check in once more before tax season, maybe talk to Mark about Financial Planning, but not much to do now. I'll be in touch with him sometime in December and pop off a tax quote then.

Had a close meeting with Garrett on Pawz Inc. and our proposal. 

https://ignt.io/E8Hm7l2qffB

He said he'd taken a look through so quick 5 minute conversation. Talked him through all the services and asked if he had any questions.  He said he was going to look it over and get back to us over the next couple of days. 

Feels like he's interviewing a handful of shops so we'll see how it shakes out.  In my opinion, if he's going somewhere else, the tax prep fees are either going to be shit or a very high cost for tax prep.  

Either way, good FGA in the new software from the squad and I'll follow up with him over the next couple of days.

Met with Isabelle for about an hour.  She has a bookkeeper right now who I think is virtual and in the Philippines or something but she says she's happy with him. The rest of her experiences with accountants has been terrible.  

Her first accountant did her taxes wrong by taking her top line revenue number as net income.. yikes.  Then she went to an accountant who is a super nice guy but fucked up her quarterly taxes twice so she said she didn't trust his work but wanted to continue working with him because he's a nice guy but wanted to bring in a tax strategist for oversight.  He got offended by that and left so she worked with this CPA lady who said she'd take care of everything and was 'good' but literally can't get a hold of her.  She is the type of person who wants to get everything done on time and she's very diligent about providing things in a timely manner so it's frustrating because she had all her stuff done on time but the CPA didn't file her taxes until 9/15 (ext deadline) when she had her shit over to her in time for 4/15.  

She's an SCorp already and talked her through salary considerations but when I said she was doing all the right things and paying herself a salary she hesitated as if what I just explained to her isn't what she is doing.  She also said she hired a W2 employee but doesn't think the withholding taxes are set up correctly and she's currently putting some money in a savings account because she doesn't think enough taxes are being withheld.  

She said she wants us to help with payroll from  a clean up and oversight perspective (basically onboarding and payroll client) with quarterly tax estimates.  She wants her biz and individual return too which I said was $1200 (I should know the new prices by now) and also said she wants to do Tax & Financial Planning but I said let's see what we're working with first so that we can build a more intelligent plan after she gets cleaned up.  She was very receptive to that.  

From a quote and pricing perspective let's do Complimentary review / assessment, SCorp/Indy return for stated prices, payroll onboarding / clean up for $799 (confirm this after we get access to gusto), Payroll & Compliance for $99 monthly.  Give a 12% discount (Three Point Mortgage) discount.

column13:
Accounting - Client Onboarding - Bookkeeping
Taxes - Business
column18:
Talked to Krystle via Zoom for about 30 minutes.  She's a referral from Golden Hour because they opened their businesses at similar times and Golden Hour is about three doors down from her so no personal connection here.  

She incorporated in May as an SCorp but got started in July.  See intake form for profile / services but she's currently using Toast for the Cafe, Walla (spelling?) for Yoga / Salt therapy, and Freshbooks to keep expenses and what not.  She said she had an accountant that was a friend help but didn't seem like the person had the time or was executing on what they need. 

She used to work in HR for awhile doing payroll so she's familiar with that side of the house but finance/taxes is not her strong suit.  She's looking for an accountant to essentially handle the bookkeeping, reporting, and taxes as she already feels like she is spending too much time on it.  She says she just wants the accounting to be off her plate but know the numbers and stay compliant.  

I walked her through our services and our typical relationship with entrepreneurs of the sort.  We digressed a little bit and her husband went to LSU so.. Geaux Tigers. 

I think she'd benefit from QBO, monthly bookkeeping, and tax services.  Thinking reporting on a monthly basis and meeting on Quarterly basis? She said she's doing the payroll right now and it's through Toast.  Instructions to provide accountant level access is below. 

https://central.toasttab.com/s/article/Toast-Payroll-Giving-Access-to-a-Non-Employee

https://central.toasttab.com/s/article/Access-Permissions-Reference

Action items are to send a thank you email with our bookkeeping packages and request reports. 

Let's bundle Onboarding, Bookkeeping, Basic Compliance, and Taxes.

column41: Tax - Ind. w/ Sch C (1040 + Sch C)
column44:
Derrick is a smart young dude (25) that's beginning to dip into the entrepreneur space. He's looking for guidance in all areas (taxes, tax planning, financial advising, business).

First item to take care of is creating an LLC for this Turo business he's been dabbling in. Wants to register the business in Wyoming for tax purposes (will need registered agent services, Dat also pitched the idea to form in Nevada for similar tax advantages). He doesn't want to have to deal with the day to day transactions so let's also include in the quote bookkeeping onboarding & monthly bookkeeping. We should have a better idea of that lift after discovery docs but he did say he was tracking as much as he thought he should on a google doc (stupidly optimistic it isn't complete ass).

He also mentioned wanting to get into the vending machine game in the near future so if we handle this first LLC creation, bookkeeping, and his taxes well then I could see another Biggie Smalls package in the very near future.

He kind of gave me Ben White vibes so we'll need to keep an eye out for a million questions and may need to hop into a consulting retainer if it gets out of hand.

Action Items:
Dat - Send a follow up email and begin the discovery doc requests to see what we're dealing with

Nick - take a quick peek at the google docs and see what kind of shit show we're potentially dealing with, then circle up with me on bookkeeping onboarding pricing

Sweeney - LLC creation

Brian O - want you to take a shot at creating a proposal in Ignition, utilize myself or Mark Dwyer in that process when needed but would like you to take a solid FGA after we get discovery docs & finalize some pricing
column94:
Federal Individual Return (1040) - $450
State Return - $50
LLC (1040 with Sch C) - $450
column100:
Quickbooks/Bookkeeping Services - $109 (per hour)
Bookkeeping Onboarding - $500
Single Member LLC Creation - $1000
column109:
Let's give him a 50% discount on tax services (1040C + MA state return), assuming that he decides to move forward with the LLC Creation & Bookkeeping services. Make a note that the discount is due to bundling our services.

(Wyoming Filing Fee - $100)

column105: Dat and Mark had lunch with Boris and Chaim. They just presented the SEED program to the Suffolk Board, said it went really well and gaining a ton of support at the college. Also recently engaged with the City of Boston, SEED will be taking on 2 trial cases from the City of Boston, along with the cases from the Boston Exhange. SEED relationship with Eastern Bank deteriorated, Eastern Bank did not want to commit to the program. Boris has transitioned to building a partnership with Santandar. SEED Nick will be coming on full time with the program next week and will interview and select students for the progam.  Currently have about 46 students signed up, and will cut that down to around 36 students. 12 per class. They are working on setting up the SEED space, there will be 3 classrooms and a lounge. They will promote our Motta logo at the space our logo was also included in the slide presented to the board. Need to get them our logo kit and they will provide us their marketing kit, Chaim said prob not for a couple of weeks. Boris has 2 rescue dogs, he is going to his house in Florida this week, and brother was in a crazy motorcycle accident in las vegas about 5 months ago. he is fine now but crashed going 120 on the highway.

Caught up with Chris regarding all of his projects and to give him an update on Motta.  

On his side, the market is down so he'll end up around $170 income this year from his W2 job.  

Walked him through Elmira and the Notary of that OA but I told him we've gotten started on the Elmira QBO account already so just need him to sync up the account.  I'll send that request.  

Also he said the rental property he's been renovating is now being rented and he has it as Subsidized housing.  He said the two bottom bedrooms didn't have something so the Section 8 people gave him a rate at a $200 loss for the year but he's going to put those in and they should be good in the long term.  

I asked him to gather all of those documents and that he should keep it all in a separate bank account and that we could manage all of that for him.  I'll create a request list for this year but he said it's probably going to be easier to open a new personal account and use his bank account as biz because the Section 8 people have that bank account for payments and stuff so might be a nightmare to change.  I'll send him a request list for this as well but also offered to get him on QBO for that rental as well.  He's been very valuable to our firm and think this will save him and us a bunch of time.

column50:
Soloman is a friend of mine from Las Vegas and actually my roommates boss at Resorts World.  He's originally from New Jersey but moved to Vegas shortly after.  Well connected man in Vegas and has helped me out / invited me to a lot of places.  Plus he'd handle our account at Resorts World so kind of a 'foot in the door' and partner play.  

His aunt is a tax prepper back in New Jersey and I don't want to step on any toes.  Much like Cary, he just started earning commissions and didn't want to owe so had asked me awhile back to look at his stuff to make sure he's in a good spot. 

Should be just a quick tax withholdings job so I can take care of this.
column109: Quick review and hoping to parlay this into referrals or discounted advertising at RW.  Also they've already given me a lot of free things..

column105:
Talked to Derek and Jenna for about an hour about the Tax Assessment.  See meeting recording and meeting summary notes. 

Derek is getting the $1.2m pay out this year as he is an owner of CEI Constructors (Civil Engineering Co in CO) which was sold.  I believe there was a buy out because they informed me that he will be getting a payout for the next few years (until around 2028). Not for $1.2m but will be significant and all W2. 

I talked to the RE Pro benefits as they make too much money to go towards retirement to offset the W2 income.  

Went through Cost Seg / Solar and other considerations around being a RE Pro.  Seemed to resonate.  Jenna seemed like she wanted to aggressively lean into the RE Pro and purchase another property in 2024 to reduce the tax liability.  They might purchase a couple more as this income will remain high for a few years. 

I talked them to solar too but their investment property is a townhome so the HOA owns the roof.  They asked if they did Solar on their primary if they would get the same benefits but told them they'd get all the same tax credits but not the accelerated depreciation which is generally the big advantage.  Derek did say maybe not for their primary but it will be a tool in their tool chest for future properties. 

I also talked through financial planning and they didn't seem to have an advisor.  Could be a good planning and AUM opportunity.

From a pricing standpoint, I presented the rough fee schedule and disclosed that this is baseline and that pricing would be based on what path they take. I told them that there was a 20% discount if they go with the Tax Plan and the discount would be applied to all the items within the plan.  

Action items are for me to check in over the next couple of days and see if they want to move forward.  Seems like they do and think there will be A LOT of project expansion.  

If she is leaning into the RE professional career, there is going to be some ADVS, BKPG, and tons of Tax planning so this could be a big one.  Also think they are in the circles of High Net Worth Indys so think this could turn into a good referral channel.

Talked to Dom on Thursday Night (10/24).  He's a Marine and moving from Arizona to North Carolina. 

He just purchased a home in NC and was thinking of selling his home in AZ.  He purchased it for around ~$300 and has $280 left on his mortgage.  He currently has it listed for $410 and has been in the AZ home for 3 years.  He already purchased his new home so want to confirm he'd still qualify for 1031 exchange. 

He actually was talking about potentially keeping the property (Harrison mentioned this and suggested it) because he was going to sell and put the money in the market.  He knows the NC home isn't a forever home so the plan is to stay in NC for 2-3 years and then go from there.  I talked about rental properties and the real estate market in general including the HELOC.  Seems like he was now considering keeping the home.  

He said he is going to NC for the Marines but also might have to get Medically discharged which means he'd be retired.  He's not sure of that yet but either way, he'd stay in NC for the 1031 aspect.  

The meeting was relatively short, he's a simple case.  He said 10 minutes into the meeting that he will going to Motta for his taxes so let him know what the next steps are.  I'll send TY email and client requests.

Company Description: Future Masters Chess Academy uses chess to promote better decision making in order to help youths become future masters on the chess board, but more importantly in life.

Wealth Impact: Yes it does. Our program has a youth program within it that allows youths to give back to the younger generation once they reach a certain level of chess proficiency and maturity. We get them in a paid status in our program. We also have access to 20 coaches that we use to facilitate our program at our centers and our schools. This program open doors to better colleges. We already have key contacts and deans from Harvard that support us. We have youths on our team who are the best at chess and math in the country that have volunteered to help underserved communities get this same education they have received.

We believe when you combine our master coaches with parental support and the right education this is the formula to close the racial wealth gap in our underserved communities.

As our production company grows and new relationships are bonded, we'll use our influence to ensure BIPOC filmmakers/creatives are given real opportunities to make real money as opposed to the lower level positions that are typically handed out to them. 
We are here to empower and influence these filmmakers to open up their own production companies. The more more successful black owned production companies there are here in Boston, the less excuse the big marketing agencies will have of not being able to find minorities in the film industry in Boston; an excuse unfortunately heard way too often.

Company Description: Dorchester Art Project (DAP) is a dynamic, community-driven art and cultural cooperative dedicated to fostering creativity, inclusivity, and economic empowerment in Boston. Our mission is to provide affordable studios, performance spaces, and educational resources to artists, creators, and organizers, with a focus on supporting the BIPOC and arts-driven communities.

Wealth Impact: Our most innovative solution lies in our recent transition into a cooperative, which ensures equity for all members. By distributing wealth, decision-making power, and responsibilities among a committed group of people who are dedicated to supporting the creators in our neighborhood, we are fostering true wealth creation. This approach is groundbreaking in bringing economic autonomy to multidisciplinary creators in Dorchester, and by centering our community, we are actively addressing the racial wealth gap that persists today.
Empowering artists to reject exploitative opportunities and instead gain equity in their own work is nothing short of revolutionary. We define, determine and manage our value, cost and worth. One of our key pillars is economic stimulation: we aim to provide services and products that catalyze the creation of new businesses and creative job opportunities, spurring growth and revitalization within the community.

Having grown up in one of such communities and seen my dad leverage his artistic expression to grow a successful business, I learned firsthand about entrepreneurship through art. Today artists drive a significant amount of commerce from brand partnerships to ecommerce sales etc and they also drive culture and influence consumers more than any other community. Building Rivet for us is not just about helping artists be more successful, but also about the types of artists from these overlooked communities who can now exist and have a fair shot at building sustainable and scalable businesses that can support their surrounding communities.

column50:
Caught up with Harrison about Rowland and also on some of the other projects and leads we have with Harrison.  Gave us some insight on Dominic Escuela (different debrief) and also said he wanted to get his plugged in with another one of his athletes, Morgan Fox, who players for the Chargers. 

Harrison said he works with Morgan with another advisor (who has most of Morgan's assets right now) and the other advisor recommended an accountant who he's working with currently.  Harrison said that Morgan "likes" his accountant but said he'd like us a lot better.  He said he knows Morgan and he knows Morgan would prefer an accountant he can actually talk to and understands the world of professional athletes.  

Seems like Harrison has a better relationship with Morgan than the other advisor so we'll see if this lead pans out but wanted to include the debrief while it's fresh in the brain.

I have an intro meeting with Dominic tonight (10/24/24) at 7:00 PM EST but Harrison had provided some background on this lead.  

Harrison said Dominic is in the military (special forces of some kind) and looking for some tax help.  He might be retiring but Harrison mentioned he also might get med deployed or something.  

Either way, he's got some real estate and has to move for the military so typical tax lead.  Harrison said he's not 'officially' a client of his yet so this could be a double close.

column105: Dat and Mark did a 30minute call with Kristen.  She is very nice started her speech therapy business Jan 2023, she has been filing as schedule C and using a DBA. She recently hired a bookkeeping firm, 2024 she has been focusing more on the "business side" of the business.  She on pace to net around 50k this year.  The main discussion was around Schedule C individual, LLC, and Scorp. So we walked her through the differences and emphasized the importance of LLC for liability portection and than we could analyze S-corp designation for her once she was an LLC sounds like she is on the cusp right now but if her business grows a little more would be a good fit for her.  Most of her revenue comes through a contract she has with the state of maine. Her income is consistent an nice fit for Scorp as well as making quarterly tax payments which she asked about. Need to send her a proposal for LLC creation and taxes.  We let her know we would do a free tax review of her prior year tax return. She said she believe she knows of issues that could be amended but didnt elaborate. Proposal for single member LLC in Maine and taxes 1040 schedule C.  Discovery request for 2023 tax return for us to review

Met with Harrison Hunter (NM) who is Raquel's Financial Planner and referred us the Penningtons.  We have a Zoom recording and Meeting summary as well so that will be attached.  

Turns out, her Solo 401k is with Invesco, not with Harrison.  He only handles her Northwestern Mutual Signature Portfolio Premium Brokerage account (which he informed me was around $400k).  I also texted her afterwards because that isn't efficient.  Generally you are charged less fees if you have a higher balance at one place.  Especially with the Sig P at Northwestern, I used to work with clients in that space so did a bunch of work with that team and also went to a handful of their trainings.  Pretty good product and service is really good.  If she moved her retirement, she'd already be over the Sig P threshold (which I think can vary but my office had a $250k minimum for that or something).  

We also talked about retirement strategies for Tecia and Raquel basically said she's mentioned it but Tecia hates talking about anything finance related.  I feel that on the tax side as well.  Pretty sure Hunter is in charge of that one.  I think Harrison said Tecia has a Whole Life (perm) Insurance policy and that Alayah as a WL Policy as well.  

Talked through the DAF, savings plan for Alayah, and retirement stuff with Raquel as well.  Talked through the mechanics of it all to ensure we're aligned with Hunter's side of the house.  He agreed with it all.  

One thing that he thinks will be key is the DAF.  He said she expressed that she wanted to open up her own gym and how that could be a Non-Profit that is funded by the DAF.  Once it's registered as a 501(c)3 the DAF can grant that NPO this cash.  It's actually brilliant.  Tax savings now to fund a post-retirement venture. Harrison was impressed.  I sent him the Motta 1-Pager on that as well.  

Action items on our side is to do a Tax Plan (Dat) and to open her payroll accounts (I think Gusto will do.. and also Mark get those started with Sweeney/Sophia on support).  

After Raquel left Harrison also talked about his practice and how that he's a field director, the CFO of his region likes to do a YE P&L review with the field directors.  He knows his books are behind but they sent him a 10 minute QBO training video to prep him for this.  I think he's really trying to nail this so want to get this books caught up as quick as possible.  I think I'm gonna meet with him again because his platform MUST interface with QBO if they are sending him trainings about it.  I want to personally take care of this one (with the help of P24 which I'll get them started on).  He said he synced his bank account so we should be ready to Rock.  Ganesh, use the P&Ls provided by his previous accountant as a reference point as we're building the chart of accounts and categorizing transactions.  He's a financial advisor.  He collects money from selling life insurance, managing investments, and a % of revenue for his office as he's the head of his satellite office.  

He also talked about a potential client.  The wife is the superintendent of some school system and the husband also does some W2 type job.  She earns a pension but he says that how the compensation system works, they start paying the first year of the pension the last year of the employee's working year.. so they get double compensation that year.  They also don't have a lot of tax deferred assets and their income is too high to do anything now.  Harrison said to max out their other retirement plans through work but that won't make much of a dent.  He asked about real estate investment strategies so I briefly talked about the RE professional criteria.  They said they wanted to do a ST rental... in Mexico.  He said he suggested the same thing  but didn't know the tax side of it so wanted to loop us in.  Tax lead as well.  Nick to research this side of the house.  Brian O asked about Cost Seg which I suggested along with Solar and he seemed receptive to it.  

Also talked to Harrison about the instant chemistry as we went into a Collab client meeting and really worked well with each other.  I think he sees the value of having a CPA in his holster.  Especially if it helps him bring over more AUM with the Solo 401k.  He said Raquel is one of his more important clients and that he trusts us a lot.  I think we've successfully executed on his first referral and the partnership is growing in a very positive direction.

Consulting Debrief

Met with Connor at 3PM for a weekly meeting to help them improve their processes without anyone's knowledge and not getting paid for it. 

Connor is basically manually calculating commissions and branch P&Ls instead of using their commission system to do it. I think Matt was trying to build a journal entry to help band aid this but think they need an infrastructure overhaul. We talked about needing to revamp their infrastructure when they grew big enough. 

Mitch also wants to implement an Employee Stock Option Purchase Plan (ESOP) so let's do some research on that from and potentially loop in a Specialist for this. 

Audit Readiness Debrief

I have asked Matt/Paul to assess the lift from getting from Cash to Accrual and haven't seen anything on that front. We need to get started on this (maybe AB)? So please find time this week to talk about it. 

Business Valuation

I took the FGA with the old system for Biz Val and I think someone took an FGA with BizEquity on this. I think next steps are for quote and then see what they want to do with it or how much they would like us to help. I think this was more or less for them to gauge how much they can sell 3PM for and I don't think they're doing that anymore because the company isn't worth enough. 

 Action Items

Paul - When is the next monthly meeting? Please make sure Mattys meetings are deleted and we have the monthly meeting on our bookkeeping template with what deliverables we need for each meeting. 

Brian O & Sweeney - Level set on scope / billing for this client. Check what they signed quotes for. I'm planning to bundle all of the above as in level setting on their contract. If you guys want to draft up a quote for this convo, that would be ideal. All the projects are based on consulting hours estimates so work with the teams on that front. 

Dat - look through the docs for infrastructure revamp. Send the biz val. And email Mitch about level setting on the contract. Him and DJ are out here the first week of November so I can talk to them about it then if not earlier

Mark - Research ESOPs

column50: Training

column105:
Pennington Debrief (10/17/2024)
Met with Raquel as her taxes are late to get some last details for 2023 but also talked about all the other projects we have going on including planning for 2024.  I’ll provide those updates in the 2023 work item directly and update notes in that work item but this debrief is going to hit a bunch of different things.  
1.	Taxes (2023) – Got final numbers so those will be submitted today
2.	Taxes (2024) – Income: Tecia made about $240k and Raquel made ~$900k top line from a purse standpoint.  They both also have some small endorsement & sponsorship deals (Raquel said Venom pays her $25k).  Raquel also said she got PPV points for the last fight which is based on PPV buys so she’ll get that payment within 120 days of the fight after numbers are settled.  She said she expects that to be around $1.2m and some more over the next year if there are additional PPV buys.  All in income is probably around $2.5 million.  There’s a lot of room for financial / tax planning.  Harrison is her FA so unfortunately no AUM on this one.
3.	Dan Johnson LLC – We went through the Agreement and she gave me all the numbers from her initial contributions so I’ll finalize those.  She also said this one will be a flip and the house is currently listed for sale and she will probably get a ~$100k cap gains on that project.  
4.	Lincoln – She’s dumped a bunch of money into this but it’s a 4 unit and they’ve renovated the property.  She said they have renters ready so as soon as they are done, it’ll see income.  They are also getting HELOC on the property to repay her initial investment.  She also said she wants Bookkeeping on Lincoln but wants to talk to her partners first. 
5.	New Property – She is closing on a Cabin on 11/4 which she plans on using as a ST rental. She’ll need an LLC on that.  
6.	Team Rocky – She wants full Bookkeeping & Payroll including set up.  Payroll will be monthly and she won’t need reporting or anything.
7.	Team Tiny – Same with Team Rocky. 
Dat to Finalize the LLCs and get a video Notarization on the books.  I’ll also finalize the 2023 returns today and start/distribute work items for the rest of the work projects.  I’ll also create a Client Group for all of the “Pennington Family” work.

column38:
Talked to Lily Huang (RSM) who has a friend who's role is to help companies buy companies.  He doesn't actually do anything but finds the service providers (lawyers, CPAs, etc.) in order to get the acquisitions done. Pretty cool job actually and could be a good channel for us for project based consulting work. 

So there's a Parent Company (who I believe is under PCAOB standards) is looking to acquire an E-Commerce business called Wookoo.  Lily sent me the pitch deck so I'll include that along with their website and all that jazz.  

Lily said the last auditor was a 1 person shop who was able to do the audit in 3 days including helping them write the financial statements (which I don't think is technically allowed for independence issues) but seems like a smaller company.  $7 million top line and I don't think they have much of a balance sheet.. Nick would know better than I. 

Lily will introduce us via email but they were shooting for Mid November to get this done.  She wasn't sure if it was a Audit or Review and also if it was PCAOB or AICPA.  That significantly changes the scope so I said I'd at least talk to them about it.  

We'd have to register in Texas (they're in Dallas) in order to do this but if it's an AICPA audit it'd be easy and if it's an AICPA review it's even easier.  I did some research on Texas requirements for firms to perform audits and it's basic shit.   

I think Nick/I would be the Partners on the audit with AB and Sophia helping on the audit side if needed.  Nick knows the industry, AB has audit experience in this world, and I'm good at both things.  Sophia on support.
column109:
Lily said the guy was looking for around $10k for audit fees.  Think I'm gonna ask for at least $12k but we'll feel it out. 

I did $199 hourly rate / $10k and it was around 50 hours.  We'll see if we'd be able to do this in 50 hours but if it's what she says it might be than this is easy money.

column105:
Creating a work item for the TLL Medical Retainer.  

We will use this client as an FGA to build a template for retained services. 

TLL Medical is a large tax and bookkeeping client of ours.  Part of their contract is a retainer for CPA services.  I thought we had an invoice for Onboarding for them as well for $10k but I can't find that invoice so if someone can look into that.  

Anyways, I also created a "Client Finance Summary" for TLL as they have a lot of projects going on. I'll add this to the client folder.  

Assigning this to Sweeney for now and it will be his until he can train Brian O on managing this.  I'll be involved from a process building standpoint and obviously from a client management standpoint.

Missed a phone call from a 3PM referral but she called me back just now and we had an introduction call. 

Jenna is a homemaker in Colorado who also had a short term rental (Property #1) which has been in an LLC since 2019 and in the market for another rental property (Potentially Property #2) which is why they are working with Mitch.  They are currently looking and put an offer in on a home but it didn't work out.  Jenna isn't optimistic that they'll find what they are looking for is as the inventory in their area is very low.   

She also has another LLC (started in 2022 she thinks) for property management which hasn't done a ton with from a sales standpoint but has been working on really creating a ST Rental conglomerate.  

I talked through the RE Professional criteria and she definitely qualifies as she has no other income and spends much more than 14 hours a week (750 a year) between the ST rental bookings, property management, and currently working on renovating the ST rental since September.  

They are currently squatting at the house right now and she said the whole "I'm not sure if you'd like me to change that answer for tax purposes" but she said they had to renovate and figure they'd use the livable space while they renovate and look for another house.  She projects that renovations will be done next June but also said that could all change if they purchase another property as that would require a lot of capital.   

She has a small 1 person tax shop working on the property management LLC and her husband's company handles their individual taxes.  

Her husband has a W2 job at a place where he also earns a K1.  I'm not sure what he does but she said the company is being sold in the middle of December and he's going to get a massive payout from it.  The tax firm is a larger regional firm called Wiffy or something? She didn't seem satisfied with them or didn't trust them because she asked if we could review her previous returns to see IF it's advisable to amend.  She just thinks that the accountants would look out for the businesses / OG owners' best interest vs the lower level shareholders so think she just wants us to take a look to see if everything looks logical.

She essentially wanted to talk to an accountant with the big K1 distribution coming in and their current home buying process, she just wants to make sure someone is doing the math and guiding them to make sure they are (1) Planning for the big pay out (2) When that pay out happens, would it be advisable to purchase another home to save on taxes.  

She said the business is going away and said they could go with the same firm but she's currently looking elsewhere.  She basically said that if we look at her returns and have a good plan for saving on taxes in 2024 than she'd just move everything over to us.  

I originally had this as a Dwyer job but it's looking kind of more on the Sweeney/Nick train.  Maybe Dwyer on support. 

She asked about fees (saying she understand it depends) so I gave her a high level walk through of pricing with BASELINE tax pricing and told her amendments are hourly as the scope can vary.  She seems super smart and gets it.  Seemed like she left the conversation satisfied. 

Next steps are is that she's going to take the intake form (we don't have her email currently) then I'll send her our materials on RE Professionals, fee schedule, and the document request list. 

We aren't at quote stage yet but I'd say it looks like 1040c with 2 LLCs and also said we'd review the documents and see if an amendment makes sense complimentary (which I think is part of our process anyways).  I can't tell if this would be considered tax planning (i.e. planning for 2024 pay out and advising on if it makes sense to buy another investment property) but open to thoughts from the team from a pricing standpoint.

Talked to Thalia for about 25 minutes with about 10 minutes of catch up and 15 minutes of updating on what's going on with her businesses.  

She said after our last discussion, she was finally able to look at the client resources we sent over and she's been worried about starting her business (cleaning mostly) and having something happen if one of her 1099's fuck something up at the house.  She says she works a lot with Realtors and helping with cleanings for staged homes so if the cleaners break anything there.. she thinks it could be bad.  Her biggest concerns were legal protection and business insurance.  

First, she wants to put her rental property into an LLC.  This was with her brother so it'll be a Partnership LLC (Basically the same thing as Elmira). I told her the filing and stuff is easy but the big thing would be the Partnership agreement but it's technically not 'mandatory'.  I said up to her since it's family but she really wanted to establish a structure which I said was smart.  Partnership formation + Partnership agreement here.  I think we use the one we used for Raquel for her MMLLC for her rental property as a basis.  

For her cleaning business, it will be an entity formation for that in Colorado as a SMLLC with an operating agreement with that one.  I also talked to her about the Entrepreneur Essentials package which she LOVED.  So LLC Creation + EE package. 

Action items are for Sweeney to draw up the quotes on these for the itemized pricing for all of those individual items listed. Include the state filing fees for both states and stuff like that too.  

I'm going to use this client as an opportunity to create a EE type package but for Real Estate clients / Rental Properties.  This will be for the class of clients we have that keep buying properties (Martin, Raquel, etc.) so think it'll be good to have a product/package in this space.  Super easy lift and easy P24 job.  

Action item for me is to send her background instructions for operating agreements (same shit I templated for Raquel) as well as the EE package.  

Also is that LLC Creation questionnaire still out there? I think we can deploy that here and build it into the template as well (if not already which it probably is).

column28:
Thalia is a multi project client / prospect for us and the significant other of Chris Martin, who is extremely loyal to Motta.  I'm not sure if she was just saying this for lower fees but remember her saying she hears Chris on the phone while he's talking shop and how great Motta is to work with and how they are the backbone to all his plans. 

Thalia has a rental property in CT (she's in CO but originally from CT.. she moved to CO specifically for Chris) that I think she 'technically' owns with her brother.  I feel as though she deals with a lot of it.  The rental property was a Schedule C or E for her last year and I remember we did an amendment for it as well because she had did the driveway over.  

Guessing this will be a rental property entity formation but I technically haven't talked to her yet.  She scheduled a 15 minute phone call tomorrow (10/15) but I think I know what's about to happen.  I'll do an additional debrief anyways but this one is pretty straightforward so wanted to get started on it. 

I'm also going to use this client as an FGA client to template out the process for Entity Formations in regards to rental properties so I'll be more hands on with Sweeney on the wing.

Basically the same price (maybe a touch higher) but when one of our clients buys another rental property (which happens a lot), we can just deploy this package.

column94: Self-Employed Sole Proprietor or Single Member - $975

column105:
Had an 'introduction' call with Ryan since I think only Mark/Matty had spoken to him before.  

We first talked through Motta and moving over to to ADP on our side.  Pretty straight foward. 

Talked through TLL and some of the features and items that they would need for their operation.  

He said it'd be around $325 per pay period for TLL and ~$160 per month for us but obviously that goes away once we hit 3 clients.  He also said he could give us 50% off or something for months 4 through 6.  

It was good to get a walkthrough of the software (which is basically the same as all the other ones) and resources (which I think is the difference maker).  To understand the features and how it could be a solution for our clients.   I assumed that it would be better but would come at a higher cost as they are built for larger companies.  

Ryan actually told me that he probably opens 9-10 single owner SCorps a week for small businesses who are SCorp so they have to have a salary on the books.  I asked him about pricing and he said for that situation with payroll run monthly, it would be around $100 per month including all the resources.  I said that's double what Gusto charges but you get a lot more so it makes sense.  He said he will never lose a client for pricing so it seems like he'd be able to be pretty flexible.  Seems like he's just trying to get more businesses onto the platform and not just the larger clients.  I was under the assumption that it was just too large of a software but he said that he'll always be able to find a price to work for these businesses.   He also says he'll actually drive to the business and train them on the software or help them get the State ID numbers if they need it.  He's the small business guy so he hinted that ADP considers this an "emerging markets" of sorts so they are just looking to get businesses on their system and hope they grow and will upgrade later on.  

He talked about Rev Share and how they are having a promotion right now that he will send us more details tomorrow or end of the week at the latest.  Same as Gusto but they are giving pretty large bonuses for new firms from a Rev Share standpoint.  He said if we get X clients, we can get a $5k bonus or something.  

As a firm, I think we'll still use Gusto but this guy seems like the service would be great and if he's going to work with us on pricing, I think ADP should be our default payroll referral partner. 

From a client standpoint, he said he'll send quotes for Motta and TLL by tomorrow as well.  I said while he's at it, send quotes for Team Rocky and Team Tiny cause I think they will be ADP people.

Had a 15 minute intro call with Jason Salit who is the current outsourced CFO for Hancock Processing.  Looking at his LinkedIn, he was a former E&Y guy but learned that he mostly worked in Banking and was also in the mortgage industry.  I remember Tyler telling us that him and two other guys (another mortgage guy and an accountant guy) started a company before Hancock and sold that before he started Hancock.  Then he wanted to sell Hancock and when we asked what he would do next, he'd just start another company with those other guys.  Doesn't make a ton of sense to me but learning that the Real Estate industry is filled with used car salesmen who are into the "Pump and Dump" method of entrepreneurship.  

I think Jason was the accountant guy that Tyler was referencing.  The good news is that the guy seems very competent.  The bad news is that he seems like he wants to keep everything in house.  I asked for access to his QB and he was hesitant and made it clear to not change anything in the system.  I said we mostly only need it to sync up with our Tax & Biz Valuation Software.  He then said he isn't sure if the Tax Mappings are correct and I told him we'll take a look and would just suggest mappings if anything.  He then said he'd give us User Access not Accountant access so that we couldn't change anything but then gave us accountant access because he wanted to save the User slot for other people.  I thought User Access would have more access than Accountant but either way.  

He was definitely stern and came off like a dick but I think he's just skeptical of some of the professionals out there and didn't want someone like David Winter fucking around with their books.  I don't necessarily blame him.  I will say if we had Tyler's full trust, Jason wouldn't have pushed back as hard. Part of me thinks that after we talked through some of the tax questions he had, he figured I was qualified.  Not sure but either way, I think Motta is in the "Vendor / Service Provider" bucket and not the "Partner" bucket.  

From a business valuation perspective, I think we sync up the books and run it through the Biz Valuation tool.  We technically haven't "Sold" the report to him yet so maybe there are marketing materials we can send him about that.  We also need to figure out how much we're going to charge for just the report and how much we would charge in order to help them with projections and assumptions.  Me thinks this guy will just want the report so I think at a minimum, we'd have to send some sort of proposal and/or sample of a report and see if he wants to purchase it from us for $X dollars.  We'd still need to send a request list of assumptions for them to answer even if they just want the report (Growth rates, Officer Comp, etc.) so think this will be an FGA client for that.  I would have rathered a client that we had a closer relationship with but this isn't terrible. Sweeney, Nick, and Mark on support for this one.  I'll also be involved.  Action item is to review the QB once we get access to it then sync it up to Biz Equity.  Then get some sample deliverable, Proposal, and Request List for the info we need.  

We'll use this work item to build out the steps and save it as a Karbon work template after.  Nick to run point on this.

From a Tax standpoint, I think he was also hesitant because of some of the poop going on in 2024.  I said getting access to the books to see if there's anything we should do before YE. 
 He asked about SCorp election and said they were gonna do it 1/1 because they thought it was too late.  When I told him it wasn't, he also said the company also had a Loan to Tyler during 2024 which is another reason why Jason was hesitant on moving to SCorp.  The loan is paid off and the method that Jason used to pay off the loan was basically if the HP made a profit of $100 that month, Jason would make a Journal Entry (JE) to reduce the loan by $100 to pay it down.  Essentially instead of paying out the profit then Tyler paying back the company, he just did it via JE.  I'm sure the correct accountant way would be to do all the steps but I think as long as your documentation is there, this is the more efficient step. He said he wasn't sure how this practice would impact the SCorp filing as he was more concerned about it from a compliance standpoint but I told him that there would be basis implications either way so we'll do the math on that.  

Jason is aware that SCorp is the more advantageous route and would save them a zillion dollars on SE tax but he's concerned from a compliance standpoint which is why he wanted to just take the hit then start fresh 1/1/2025.  Although I think that's something we can look into (maybe BB?) but I don't really think this dude understands legal entities in general.  On to the next issue I'm seeing when figuring out if they should do SMLLC or SCorp is that Tyler is paying himself a salary.  

From what I believe, it's still a SMLLC as of now but Tyler is getting paid a $5k per week salary.  I asked if they are withholding both ER/EE taxes and he was dismissive and said that they are withholding all the regular payroll taxes. I don't think he was understanding that the owner of an SMLLC can't pay himself a salary.  I did some research to confirm that this is not allowed but I don't think a majority of people understand this. Shows that even if you're a talented bookkeeper that you're ass in taxes and legal entity shit.   

Action items here are: 

(1) TAX: Do the math to see how much additional he's going to have to pay in SE tax if he keeps it as an SMLLC cause that number could impact how much risk they are willing to take on a compliance standpoint.

(2) TAX: Look into or ask BB about the Loan and Loan Repayment to see if that will be risky from an SCorp compliance standpoint.  Avoid BB if we can figure it out on our own. 

(3) TAX: We're gonna have to do this anyways but do the basis calculations based on salary, loan repayment, etc. because Jason admitted he didn't know that world but that would be a big factor in their practices going forward. 

(4) ADVS: Accept access to their QBO 

(5) TAX: Review their accounting including the tax mappings

(6) ADVS: Sync their QBO with Biz Equity. Maybe we just send Jason the link to fill out the info? I think we'd get the report either way.  

(7) ADVS: Find some sample deliverables or marketing materials for Biz Valuation. We technically haven't closed this one so want to make sure they sign a quote before we provide anything formal. 

(8) ADVS: Come up with pricing for Biz Val for just the report and if they want us to consult on the assumptions & forecasts.  Also there's a menu of types of reports we can provide so pricing for all of that on an itemized level.  I think there's some research to be done on that market is for each individual report to see if it makes sense or just 1 report always.  

(9) MKT: Create a client resource as a PSA to tell people the implications if you're a SMLLC and pay yourself a salary.  I'll drop the research I did below and also comment on the debrief note.  


SMLLC: Owner Salary Rules and Implications

Question (Compliance): Can the owner of a single member LLC pay themselves a salary without considering the salary a distribution?

Answer (Compliance): No, the owner of a single-member LLC (SMLLC) cannot pay themselves a salary as they would an employee, and that payment is not considered a salary in the traditional sense for tax purposes. 

For federal tax purposes, a single-member LLC is treated as a **disregarded entity**. This means the IRS views the LLC and its owner as the same entity. The income generated by the business flows directly to the owner, and it's reported on the owner's personal tax return (Form 1040, Schedule C).

Here’s why it’s different from a salary:
1. **No W-2 for the owner**: In a sole proprietorship or SMLLC (taxed as a disregarded entity), the owner is not an employee and thus cannot issue themselves a W-2 form. Any money the owner takes from the business is simply a distribution of profits, not a salary.
  
2. **Self-employment tax**: The net income of the LLC, after deducting business expenses, is subject to **self-employment tax** (Social Security and Medicare) rather than payroll taxes like employee wages.

3. **No withholding**: Since the owner’s payments aren’t classified as wages, there’s no withholding of federal income tax, Social Security, or Medicare taxes directly from the payments. The owner must make **estimated tax payments** to cover their tax liability.

The only way for an LLC owner to pay themselves a true salary, complete with withholding and payroll taxes, is by electing to have the LLC taxed as an **S corporation** or **C corporation** (via filing IRS Form 2553 for S-corp or Form 8832 for C-corp). If the LLC elects to be taxed as an S-corp, the owner can pay themselves a “reasonable salary,” with proper payroll tax treatment.

So, in short:
- **No salary**: Payments to the owner are treated as distributions and not as wages/salary.
- **Taxes**: The owner reports the LLC’s profits on their personal tax return and pays self-employment taxes.

Question (Implications): 

What are the implications if the owner is receiving a salary and only withholding the employee payroll taxes? 

Answer (Implications): 

If the owner of a single-member LLC (SMLLC) is paying themselves a **salary** and only withholding employee payroll taxes (Social Security and Medicare), while not properly treating the payments or withholding the employer’s share of taxes, several potential tax and legal issues arise. Here’s a breakdown of the implications:

### 1. **Improper Classification of Payments**
   Since a single-member LLC is considered a **disregarded entity** for tax purposes (unless an S-Corp or C-Corp election is made), the IRS doesn’t allow the owner to pay themselves a salary or wages. If the owner is treating distributions as a salary:
   - **Mistaken Tax Treatment**: The IRS could consider those salary payments as misclassified distributions. This can lead to the IRS **disregarding the payroll altogether** and treating all income as pass-through income on the owner’s personal tax return, subject to self-employment tax.

### 2. **Self-Employment Taxes vs. Payroll Taxes**
   - As a single-member LLC owner, the entire business income (minus expenses) is subject to **self-employment tax**, which consists of both the **employee** and **employer** portions of Social Security and Medicare taxes (totaling 15.3%).
   - By only withholding the **employee portion** (7.65%), the owner is underpaying taxes because they aren’t accounting for the **employer portion** (the other 7.65%) of Social Security and Medicare taxes.
   
   - **Tax Consequences**: This underpayment can result in:
     - **Underpayment penalties** for the employer portion of taxes.
     - Interest on unpaid taxes.
     - Potential scrutiny from the IRS if they notice that the proper amounts of payroll taxes aren’t being reported.

### 3. **IRS Penalties and Fines**
   The IRS takes payroll tax compliance seriously. If the owner is only withholding the employee portion of payroll taxes and failing to remit the employer portion, the business may face:
   - **Penalties for underpaying employment taxes**. This can range from **2% to 15%** of the unpaid taxes, depending on how late the payment is.
   - **Failure to file employment tax returns (Forms 941, 940, etc.)**: If proper employment tax forms aren’t filed, the business could incur additional penalties.
   - **Trust Fund Recovery Penalty**: If the withheld employee taxes (e.g., Social Security, Medicare) aren’t properly remitted to the IRS, the owner could be personally liable for a penalty of **100% of the unpaid tax**. This is known as the **Trust Fund Recovery Penalty** and can be assessed against individuals responsible for the unpaid tax, including business owners.

### 4. **S-Corp Election**: The Right Way to Pay Yourself a Salary
   The owner may have misunderstood the rules about how to take a salary from their business. If they want to pay themselves a salary:
   - The **SMLLC must elect S-Corporation status** (using IRS Form 2553). Once that election is in place, the owner can pay themselves a reasonable salary, and both the employee and employer portions of payroll taxes must be withheld and paid to the IRS.
   - **Employer responsibilities**: As an S-Corp, the LLC would be responsible for:
     - Withholding both the **employee portion** (7.65%) and paying the **employer portion** (7.65%) of payroll taxes.
     - Filing quarterly payroll tax returns (Form 941).
     - Issuing a W-2 to the owner and other employees at year-end.
     - Filing Form 940 for federal unemployment taxes (FUTA).

### 5. **Risk of IRS Audit**
   If the IRS reviews the business tax filings and notices inconsistent payroll tax payments or improper classification of the owner’s compensation, it could trigger an **audit**. This could lead to:
   - **Reclassification of payments**: The IRS might reclassify the so-called salary as distributions, subjecting them to self-employment taxes instead.
   - **Fines and back taxes**: If payroll taxes were underpaid, the IRS could demand back taxes, penalties, and interest.

### 6. **State-Level Implications**
   Some states have their own payroll tax rules that mirror federal law, so the owner might also face state penalties for improper payroll tax withholding. States like California or New York, for example, have strict payroll tax enforcement.

---

### Summary of Key Implications:
1. **Tax misclassification**: The payments may be reclassified as distributions subject to self-employment tax.
2. **Underpayment of payroll taxes**: Without paying the employer portion of taxes, the business is underpaying Social Security and Medicare taxes, leading to penalties.
3. **Penalties**: Failure to remit the full payroll tax amounts can result in fines and penalties, including the Trust Fund Recovery Penalty.
4. **IRS scrutiny**: Incorrect payroll filings or improper salary payments can raise red flags and lead to audits.

### Next Steps:
If the LLC owner wants to properly pay themselves a salary, they should consider electing S-Corporation status. This would allow for a true salary, with appropriate employee and employer payroll taxes being withheld and remitted. Until that election is made, the owner should take distributions, report income on their personal tax return, and pay self-employment taxes.

If they’ve already been paying themselves a salary incorrectly, it might be a good idea to consult with a CPA or tax professional to correct the situation before the IRS notices.

Let me know if you’d like more details on the S-Corp election or the process of correcting past filings!

column18:
See debriefs from 

(1) Steve Hanus (husband)'s work item 

https://app2.karbonhq.com/4mTyp9lLRWTC#/work/3G7mLGbYPVmx?emailId=2jwln1Z7FmQw

(2) 10/2 Debrief from Lunch with Dania/Steve

https://app2.karbonhq.com/4mTyp9lLRWTC#/conversation/42pnJbn4Y4RH/email


Dania Debrief

Had lunch with Steve and his fiance (Dania Batiste, who will be another 1040c) to talk through their tax situation.

Dania will be a lot of tax poop clean up on the tax side, then a return (maybe 2023 and 2024), and bookkeeping for her side businesses. 

She has an ECommerce business on Etsy where she will create (or take) designs and print them on clothes that is manufactured by a printing shop which is sold via Etsy and another where she works with Companies and takes their designs and puts them on Mugs and shit.  I know Michalene has used Etsy before so maybe she'll be a new vendor! 

We talked through different easy strategies such as car mileage, home office, etc.  It was more of an educational close similar to others.  Honestly lit it up with rizz and think they'll throw us the keys.  Also talked about the value of having a good accountant for Entrepreneurs like themselves.  They said they've been trying to find a younger accountant as they are both trying to create YouTube channels and explained that old CPAs don't even understand how making money on the internet works.  

I'll create Dania's work in a separate Karbon item because they aren't married yet but are Married Filing Separate.  Dania has a W2 job but has also started an ECommerce business on Etsy that's doing very well (from what I'm told).  She was really excited to be actually working with a competent accountant and asked "Would you file taxes too?" which I thought was an odd question until I heard her history working with CPAs.  When she was a lot younger, and first started filing taxes she went to a CPA who said that she had a bookkeeping business which was losing money so she got a refund of like $5k.  She has never done bookkeeping before and she got audited.  The CPA ended up going to federal prison and I'm told that accountant is in jail to this day.  She paid all that money back but this year she had an accountant referred to her but after the initial conversation, she hasn't heard from him since and doesn't know if her taxes are filed.  She said she found him in a Facebook group and I asked if it was David Winter.  She said it wasn't but she's seen that name a bunch with not a lot of good reviews.  She admitted she was a hot mess and I said "we've seen worse" but she said it's also still her fault for being neglectful of this side of her adult life.  She had a traumatic experience with taxes and think she gets PTSD getting audited so she's just been whistling past the graveyard ever since.  She'll need a POA to get this squared away and probably her 2023 return filed.  

Also asked about QuickBooks and explained all the benefits of that and they were both all in on that idea.  They said they have a credit card and a bank statement where ALL of their business activity go through and there's nothing else attached to it.  That's the dream.  QBO set up should be cake which will definitely help with the taxes.  

Mark's out this week so I'll throw together a Quote/Proposal for this one but they'll both need QBO set ups, BKPG, Taxes, and a POA.

QBO set up should be cake which will definitely help with the taxes.  

Mark's out this week so I'll throw together a Quote/Proposal for this one but they'll both need QBO set ups, BKPG, Taxes, and some consulting hours it seems like.

column50:

We have his PY tax return so we can start inputting the information and all related fees to be billed to the business. 

Document requests for him should also go through my Aunt or Dat.  I also have a POA out for him for both the IRS and MA so we'll be able to get this return relatively easily as all his income is tied to TLL.

column18:
See work item with conversation debrief for this work item.

https://app2.karbonhq.com/#/search-view/dZMQYLWdTDH/note

Talked to my Aunt about the PY taxes and part of the conversation was how QB Payroll isn't the best at reporting and meant for smaller companies so we're going to move them over to ADP.  Part of their issues from our tax review was that Payroll looks way wrong.  Could have been the accountant or QB payroll but I don't think either were high quality.  

Mark is moving Motta over to ADP so he can lead the charge on this transition as well with the assistance of Paul. 

We're also going to have to show them how to use the platform as well but I'd say target date to get them completely set up on ADP would be 12/31/2024.  A bunch of their employees got IRS letters because of this payroll issue (or also their mistakes so there will be payroll poop clean up).  

My aunt is the operations person so she'll be handling their payroll so they won't be a payroll client per se but I think they'll have the Accountant Package so think we'll at least be responsible for the accounting side of Payroll which is essentially ensuring they are properly set up in ADP then making sure the information is synced to QB properly.  

Mark, Matt, Paul, and Nick on this one to learn the process and also to sync up and price this one.
column109:
Nick, Matty, and Paul to come up with a price for payroll transition. I'm estimating 8 hours but could be more? 

We have their QB Payroll so we have the data we need to gauge poop clean up and transition hours.

column105:
Caught up with Ben and he is definitely a interesting dude.  He's very happy with Motta and towards the end of the call said he's been through 4 different accountants and they've all been ass.  He said his most recent one was some guy named James that charged him $6,600 for the year which Ben paid upfront as an investment into the partnership and when April came around, the guy asked Ben to file the extension himself.  They found him in a Facebook group and some others reported the same thing. He's skeptical of accountants and we actually have access to his QBO so I'm not sure if we've ever talked to him about a bookkeeping relationship.  Matty / Mark to brief us on those communications. 

Note for the team but Facebook small business groups in local cities seems like the place to find these tiny small businesses.  Basically a channel of LOMAR BIZ clients if we want it.  

I'm not really sure how to approach this one because I'm not sure if he's looking for a bookkeeper.  We talked through Motta and how it's been valuable to business owners.  We can sync up on the huddle tomorrow on how to handle this next but he's gonna need both services but his company makes no money and we already have all his info and already had the close meeting.  

Part of my conversation with him was our idea from a few months back of a "Small Business 101" video series so he provided a lot of questions on that.  He said he has a friend who will turn it into a digital course but he's never actually worked with him yet.  I think this is a back burner idea for us and I'm also not sure I trust this loose referral.

Had a call (via cell) with Garrett on Monday September 30th for Pawz Inc. He was on the Bachelor's Party with one of the Monmouth Baseball guys but he wasn't one of those frat boys, he actually doesn't drink.  Turns out, he married the Bachelor's (Harry Paytas) sister earlier this year.  He also started his own LLC and purchased a retail operation this year.  Very busy 2024 for him.

He was a super nice and well spoken.  You can tell he's a good dude.  He gave me background on his career but his family has been in retail clothing for a long time.  His father started "Big Johnson T Shirts" which is a company that makes those goofy tourist beach t-shirts that is sold in beach city gift shops.  Him and his sister worked for his father's company for the past 7 years before he decided to split off and start a company of his own.  He made it seem like it was a dramatic situation but that he gave his family enough notice before he ventured off. 

Since starting his own company, he purchased Pawz Inc which is a retail business that has been around since 2015 but has changed ownership 1 other time since it's existence, so he'll be the third owner.  

He said Pawz Inc did between $1.0 - $1.5M last year when I talked to him which makes sense cause he said he'd do between $250k-$500k but he purchased it in May so this makes sense.  He said they have been 100% direct to consumer e-commerce before but he's working on getting into retail and wholesale. 

He's currently the only employee and does not use an accounting system.  Garrett admitted that he's strong from the Operations front but doesn't know anything from the accounting / tax standpoint so he's been looking for bookkeepers (mostly local shops in the Maryland area).  I asked him what are the important factors for him as far as Accountants and he mentioned the education aspect saying "I can pay whoever can do this stuff but looking to get trained on this stuff so I can know what I'm doing when running the business".  I think he'd be the perfect fit for what we're looking for. 

He said multiple times this is not his area of expertise and don't think he has a personal connection with the other shops he's talking to so said "You take the lead here". 

I talked to him about our background, approach, and some of our success stories.  Also gave him a quick run down of the services we provided and our packages will reflect the services included.  He said he was just starting out and knows this is an area he needs to lock down but as this is new to him, he's unsure of what services he actually needs.  I think this will be an easy close from a client acquisition standpoint but a 'build the trust' client at first then we can increase scope as we earn said trust.  

For next steps: 

(1) I'm going to send him a thank you note and include our Bookkeeping packages (which Sophia is going to make pretty for situations like this) but also told him we'd be able to help with pricing a bit due to the referral from Cary.

(2) He asked for next steps and for me to 'take the lead' so said I'd send out a request list for docs to frame out the project and to gauge volume of transactions.  He said it's pretty straight forward but Nick knows this world way more than me so I'll defer to Nick related to pricing.  

(3) There are some action items I think we have to do for this proposal including:

[A] Creating Proposals for the "Accountant" BKPG package spelling out the various services we offer within the package.  

[B] Creating Proposals for the "Bookkeeper" BKPG package spelling out the various services we offer within the package.  

[C] Creating a "Success Stories" for Adzemen Demo to demonstrate that we can work with Entrepreneurs with limited accounting background where we partner with them and help them grow.
