column50:
Holly (Nickname from his last name "Holland") is a Monmouth baseball guy that I've been friends with for just as long as I've been friends with my roommate.  

Holly is a doctor from Pittsburgh, PA.  He's currently doing his Residency in Emergency Medicine.  You don't make shit for money as a Resident.  I think he makes like ~$75k a year while working 70-80 hours a week.  He'll be wrapping up his residency in a little less than 1.5 years but might be sooner. 

I'm looking at this like an INDY LOMAR for 2024 and maybe 2025 from a tax prep standpoint but with some tax and financial planning.  He asked what is the purpose of starting with us now vs later because he doesn't really have any money to save or anything right now, I told him it's never too early to start planning and if he anticipates to go from $75k to $250 - $500k, he's going to get phased out of a lot of benefits or savings tools quick so it would be efficient to take advantage of those while he still can and at the same time start building a personal financial infrastructure for when his income significantly increases.  

I talked to him originally from the bachelor's party from last weekend and he's in Vegas this weekend (9/28) for a conference with some of his co-workers so I'm meeting up with him this weekend to close on this deal. 

Assigning this for Mark for long term MWM prospect but also as a planning FGA.  People like Holly and some of our other clients (Mikey, Cary, etc.) who are high income lomars from a tax perspective so real value will be from a financial planning standpoint.  I think it would be good to start to strategize (at a basic level) for Tax / Financial Planning with the ideal of "selling" a full on financial plan when their situations really pop off.  Some of the prospects potentially already need a Financial Plan but too young and not in the stage of life where they know what their long term goals are.  Basically just planting seeds at this point.
column109:

We don't even have the software yet so lots of building to do on this side of the house and also think we'll run into a lot of INDYS that fall into this bucket so should start thinking about our approach as preparation for this season's hunting.

Krysta-Lyn is a former colleague of mine from WM and a very good friend. 

She left corporate america a few years back, went back to school for mental health counseling and now starting her own Yoga, Reiki, Counseling, and Barre.  She just got the keys to the building and approved for zoning this week (last week of September) with a target launch for 11/1.  

She's an accountant and keeps all her stuff pretty organized (although she's also embarrassed of the condition of her books because she's also a CPA) via excel but doesn't know a lot about the advisory type work and also not familiar with QBO or anything like that because she came from Big 4 then WM and then she did her own thing.  

She was nervous about taking on any contracts or spending any more money until she opened and refused to accept free work.  I'm not considering this free but I said she probably doesn't ~need QBO right now but also she's about to spend a lot of money so she should have some form of accounting in place.  Maybe we start just to get the process going and she can "pay us when she can" or barter for yoga classes or something.  

Either way - If I'm going to be offering up these types of services than I will perform the work.

Donald is an old from from Deloitte who I think most of the team has met.  When we originally spoke with him, he wanted to make Partner at Deloitte but now he's done with that path and looking for the next move.  I think he wants it to be Motta. I told him when he chose the Deloitte path that I was rooting for him but you can't trust Big 4 firms to actually promote the most qualified people.  Aside from the realization that making Partner isn't a very high percentage play, he also decided he did not want that life anyways.  

I'm speaking with him on 10/17 and think it will be more of a long term recruit (I think he has a decently high price tag and not sure where his head is at when it comes to Start Up / Entrepreneur life.) 

Either way, Nick is elite on the tax side but we'd need more Nicks anyways and I don't think Nick was looking for Tax to be his long term plan with Motta.  Donald is a career long tax guy and was in Deloitte's National Office for tax.  Way different market than what he's used to but think he'd figure it out pretty quick and if/when we enter the larger corporate clients, he'll have the credentials and experience to take those on.

column50:

I thought it was a personal catch up call so I didn't record it but he also said he needed his taxes done because he usually does it himself but now he has K1's and shit so at the point where he wants to get them professionally done.  

Told him about Motta and all that we have going on and he believes we're about to tear the industry a new b-hole.  

Overall it's just an Indy with a K1.  He was going to refer us to his younger twin brothers (they are actually Irish triplets) but they come from money and one of his younger brothers works in iBanking so he's got some dough.

column93:
Brian is someone I've had numerous conversations with over the past year or so.  He's a nightlife promoter in Boston who I've known for a few years now.  

He actually went to Suffolk and majored in Marketing / Data or Info Systems.  At first, I was thinking of him in a sales roles but gave him a pretty good idea of what Motta is and what it's like working here, especially for a career changer like himself. 

He seems hungry and mostly works at night so think he'd have capacity while still ramping up part time.  I view him as a tax prep grinder until we get ALFRED up and running while also helping on the PM front.  

Action items are for Mark to email him for an interview ASAP.  With potential career changers, there will be a ramp up and thinking Sonny is less flexible in the day time and he's less flexible in the night time so might be a good combo of resources.

column13:
Accounting - Client Onboarding - Bookkeeping
Taxes - Individual With Schedule C
column18:
Harrison had a district director role at Northwestern Mutual under the Denver office but now they are spinning off to a Satellite office where he'd essentially be running that office. 

He gets bonuses and stuff based on the performance of the team for managing the office which is W2 and everything he makes for his individual practice is 1099. 

Harrison was waiting until he wrapped up with his old Bookkeeper/Tax people (separate) and then he got this new role and life just became a bit of a mess. 

7/10 of the top advisors in the office left and then also hit COVID so they're trying to recover from that.  Connected Harrison with my old boss, Aaron Miller, at NWM who was the keynote speaker at their annual conference this year I think.  He basically just got a head coaching job for an expansion team then had all the star players leave for free agency.  Transition year.  

For this project, he's a Sole Prop.  He has staff but the other advisor takes care of the payroll then HH pays him whatever his share is.  I think Harrison will eventually need his own payroll but we'll cross that bridge when we get there.  Seems like the guy is trying to get his foundation built for this office.  

The old accountants had closed his old QuickBooks account so think we'll need to open a new one and actually sync his bank account to it.  He was previously emailing his commission statements every month and they would send him a P&L every quarter.  Stupid.  

This will be the "Entrepreneur" package, see fee notes below.  It'll be onboarding (basically 2024 isn't done), monthly bookkeeping, quarterly reporting, and 1040/C for tax prep.  I think he'll want to open an LLC and do payroll at some point but let's let the guy move over first before we throw too much at him. 

Also talked to him about the FA/CPA type relationship we have with other FAs and said they've seen tremendous value out of that which could also strengthen his practice.  He was very interested in that and we already have a client where we are starting to collab with him (Raquel).  

We'll keep all of those talks going but first step is to send out a request for initial documents (basically just tax returns) and send him a quote. 
 Then we fire up a QBO account for him, sync his bank account, and get to work. 

I didn't see Paul on the drop down list so put Mark for both but thinking this will be a good one for Paul to cracking on and then Mark can handle the tax side.

column109:

I guess action item is to discuss with the marketing team what that deal would look like or if we were to ask for a social media post, how we would want that to look.  Raquel said after she posted the picture of her buying another property that a bunch of fighters hit her up so might be a good lead generation tool.

column23:
Northern Farms acquired an abandoned and inactive waste conversion / energy company that the state pays them $1m a month and if the plant is up and running than it would be $20 to $100m a month.

Essentially, the old owners of the plant abandoned the plant and it became an asset of the state.  The state sold the plant to NF and provided a tax credit and energy subsidy.  They need financing in order to get the capital to get it up and running so we need to come up with a financial model to show what the financials look like now, and what they will look like once the plant is up and running.  This includes the tax credits under the Inflation Reduction Act that will be used once the plant is up and running. 

I think this is a modeling exercise and definitely thinking we'll need to loop in Blackburn for the tax implications.  

Action items are for me to follow up with Steve / Evan with a rough request list for necessary documents.
column109:
Bundle with the Northern Farms model refresh. 

Steve has referred us some pretty good clients and there are two projects here NF (Power Plant) and NF (Strawberry Farm). The latter being a pretty light lift. I remember them saying they might need us to help model other Greenhouses and also looking for continuing help as they get the plant up and running.  

Guessing between both models will total 24 hours including Prep, Reviews, and some inefficiencies built in as we know this client.

column62:
There wasn't a ton of networking opportunities at the Fierce Urgency of Now festival and the value add from a Motta perspective was essentially to get marketing content for SEED as they prepare for launch, take an FGA with the other service providers, and to demonstrate engagement.  


However, we did meet Rashawn who is the Managing Director for Recruitment, Cultivation & Diversity Programs.  Seemed like a great dude! 

Not a ton of biz development at the event but did take an FGA in having Motta go to Boston Public Schools to do Financial Literacy seminars for the students.  Although this won't directly help grow our client base, I think it could potentially help with our brand and help engagement with the City of Boston in general.  

Only action item is to send a thank you email and keep this in our holster if the opportunity presents itself.

Had a call with Rae / Teague about the WCEF annual Gala at the Woburn country club.  I believe they sent Sponsorship information and asked us to be a sponsor ($2,500).  I tentatively committed but said I'd confirm.  They said they'd follow up at the end of the week with info. 

Also asked if we would start the fundraising efforts through our network and think we can start spreading the good word.  Thinking the Woburn Chamber of Commerce might be a good channel for this or whoever else we can think of. 

They also asked about Auction items for the actual event but Sponsorships are priority.  They got $20k in Sponsorships last year and $10k in auction items.   

For auction items, people are donating things like baskets of booze and someone else donated Celtics tickets with parking.  We brainstormed ideas and they brought up Jason and that historically, it's been an older crowd but they are looking to bring it down to a younger class and turn this into a giant party.  

For auction items, I informally threw out the following: 

(1) Signed Cookbook / Restaurant Gift Card from Jason
(2) Signed memorabilia from Raquel.  
(3) Motta Financial Services - I offered to add a discount for sponsors / attendees as an incentive and Teague said we might be able to use that as an auction item (tax deductible for us obviously)
(4) Celtics tickets
(5) Vegas Golden Knights tickets

column38:
Met Mark on the plane ride back from Las Vegas on 9/15.  Mark is a legendary Muay Thai trainer who works with a lot of UFC athletes.  He also works for the UFC on the production team during the fights as a "Technical Advisor". Essentially, he sits in a room of screens watching the fights and providing Joe Rogan with analysis.  He also works in "Talent Acquisition" and essentially helps train fighters and find good fighters for the UFC to sign.  I think he said he got Rob Font (Boston native) and Tecia Torres (our client) some of their first fights in the UFC. 

Mark confirmed what Raquel said but the MMA industry doesn't have the same infrastructure for athletes as the NFL, NBA, etc. have thus there isn't really a lot of great advisors from an Agent, Manager, Financial Advisor type of role and Mark finds himself helping a lot of fighters out on the business side.  He's been trying to find a solution to help the athletes and we had a GREAT conversation about philosophies, the industry and how Motta aligns with that he's looking to fix.  

Mark asked me to stop by the gym while I'm home and tentatively planning to do that Wednesday but adding a work item to keep the notes from the conversation. 

He also asked that I don't share his phone number with anyone so the contact information will be for his gym Sitodtong USA which translates to "Student of Dtong".  He says he has 21 locations.  He was certified as the US representative for Muay Thai kickboxing in the US and think their gym is among the top gyms for fighters looking to develop Muay Thai kickboxing skills.  

Not 100% sure I'll be stopping by the gym but thinking there is opportunity to build a good network of UFC fighters as clients.  I.e. Mark has a network of fighters and he can white label our services under his.  Raquel said her first year in the UFC they had a seminar and brought in Financial Advisors and stuff but that's been once in her whole time with the UFC.  

Mark said he wanted to connect me with someone on his team (native american name) who helps with that stuff but more on the finding fights side of the house, he wants to connect me with him to start to open the line of communication to see how we can help.
column109: No fees so far.  Made a general work item but hopefully he'll move his stuff over to us once we've established trust.

column62:
Spoke to Bryce at White Tiger - M&A firm.

White Tiger Connections:

•80% M&A consulting firm – ~90% of their business are accounting practices
•Represent buy/sell and talent acquisition in accounting.
•Represents all states
•Has ~30 active businesses for sale (Can run a targeted search for us based on some inputs) 

-We'd need to pay a few to be their partner no timetable to find a deal ($5,000) to ensure we aren't tire kickers. 

-Success Fee - 10% of Purchase Price of the firm (Paid pro-rata as seller is exited by buyer)


Current Nevada Firm (Reno NV)

•$750k gross revenue
•EBIDTA (w owner salary added) $450k

•Services – Tax, assurance (audits) Heavier on tax side ~50% Tax, 25% assurance, remaining mix bookkeeping/advisory

•Client breakdown: Didn’t have a breakdown of biz vs personal

•1 sole owner (“Lost fire in belly with running firm”) Would be willing to stay on post-acquisition	

o Wants to ensure his clients and staff are taken care of

o Wants his staff to stay on:
	1 CPA Staff (mid 20’s, does a bunch of things, few years with firm)
	1 FT & PT admin
	Few contractors during tax season (not worried about them)

•Valuation –Rough estimate based on gross revenue (1-1.4x gross revenue) 1.1-1.2x multiple (looking for 20-33% cash down up front, rest deal paid out over 24 months) has wiggle room

Time to close an acquisition is case by case basis. Had some close in 2 weeks and others take 9-12 months. Average ~2-4 months from first introduction. Most of time is due diligence and then integration (with seller) post integration. White tiger can help with as much or little of the process as needed.

column67:
Went to lunch with Dean and his wife Karen on Tuesday 9/3/2024 at Lago in the Bellagio.  Sonny and his Wife, Mallory, were also there so I was 5th wheeling.  

Dean is a BD financial advisor in Northern Louisiana and Sonny/Mallory's family advisor.  Guys a baller.  Didn't talk a ton of shop as this meeting was more introductory in nature but consider the seed planted for an FA partner.

column41: Tax - Ind. w/ Sch C (1040 + Sch C)
column44:
Steve is a friend of mine that I met through Jason Santo's best friend and my Nevada realtor, Mike Marino (who's gonna be our client for 2024 returns, he's on my to do list to talk). 

Steve is an iGaming recruiter (gaming as in gambling not video games).  He worked for an agency in 2024 but was laid off and now he's doing it on his own.  He had a couple small W2s and 1099 jobs throughout 2024 while he was putting together his iGaming Consulting company, SIV Enterprises.  This includes creating a YouTube channel for iGaming. 

He also has a iGaming Proxy Service where he facilitates his clients who want to enter contests put on by the various casinos.  You have to be in the state at the time of the bet thus he facilitates the transaction. 

He said he's seen a little below $19k in sales this year all in (YouTube, Recruiting, Proxy) but I'm unsure when he started.   

He called ahead of our meeting next week because he is looking to enter a season long NFL contest and asked if he'd be able to enter on behalf of the business.  Essentially, his business is to 'sell' these contests thus his argument is that this would be R&D.  I can't speak to the compliance on the gaming side of the house but in my view, I'd say it'd be the same as a restaurant critique eating at a restaurant he's reviewing.  I think the same rules would apply (i.e. can only offset losses from gaming income) but think it makes sense.  Contest is this Saturday (9/14) so looking for some quick research. 

I'm meeting with Steve and his wife next Wednesday which he wants to move to noon for lunch but if we can get started on the research end, that would be great! 

Also note I used the 1040SchC template for the purposes of the FGA for this process but I've been making template updates to the Individual template.

column18: Talked with Dale and Mike, they use a pretty old system that a partner developed for tracking pricing and invoices and than Mike enters those numbers into AccountEdge. They havent change there process in 18yrs and dont want to. We had some questions on how their old accountants were doing certain things but not clear from the conversation, we request all transaction report for YTD and 2023 to get an idea of whats going. They are look for tax estimates and a couple advisory hrs per quarter.  I think there is potentail for us to help them out a lot more but we need to review their current transaction to get an idea.

column50:
Jeremy and Nick discussed their current business and personal tax situations, with a focus on their contract with Moda and the handling of K-1 forms. They also considered potential cost-saving measures, such as bundling their contract with Moda. Additionally, Jeremy's financial situation, including his pass-through business and personal income sources, were discussed, with Nick advising on the tax implications of certain transactions.

Next steps
• Jeremy to send Nick a copy of his 2022 tax return and all relevant 2023 tax documents, including K-1s and loan interest information.
• Nick to review Jeremy's tax documents and provide a quote for preparing Jeremy's 2023 personal tax return.
• Nick to double-check if tax return preparation is included in the current contract between Jeremy's businesses and Moda.

Discussing Moda Accounting Contract Bundling

Jeremy and Nick discussed their current accounting contract with Moda. Jeremy expressed interest in potentially bundling their current contract to reduce costs. Nick confirmed that Moda handles all the accounting and bookkeeping, including tax returns, which are an additional cost. Jeremy clarified that he is associated with only one of the seven entities included in the contract, which is Motivation Health Partners, the parent company of Symmetry. Nick agreed to review the details of the contract to confirm the current arrangement.

Personal Tax Discussion and Preparation

Jeremy and Nick discussed their personal tax situations. Jeremy was uncertain about how to handle his personal 2023 taxes, especially regarding the K-1 forms from a business. Nick clarified that the K-1 forms indicated the key ones from the business that should be included in Jeremy's personal tax return. Jeremy confirmed that he had no other significant personal income sources, except for monthly payments from a loan. Nick advised that any interest earned from the loan would be subject to tax. Jeremy also mentioned his financial situation, including his pass-through business and his wife's lack of income source. Nick requested Jeremy to send his 2022 tax returns and 2023 documents for preparing a quote.

NOTES: 

MFJ TAX RETURN – WIFE HAD NO INCOME/W2 IN 2023

NO ESTIMATED TAX PAYMENTS OR EXTENSION PAYMENT MADE
column109:
Possible heavy discount via Synergy partnership. I looked at the proposal between Motta & Synergy - we have biz returns at $999 and Synergy owners are $0 for FY2024. 

This is a 2023 / ad hoc. If the tax return is as basic as we discussed - 1040, no W2 and 1-2 k-1's, this should be a <1 HR for tax prep and review.

column50:
Met with Kim who is a referral from Joe Montgomery.  Check the timeline for background but essentially left Amazon where she was for 20 years and has a TON of stock options.  She sold some off last year to purchase a house in cash and got sticker shock when she got her tax bill from it. That's when she got in touch with Joe.  

She's planning to sell more off in order to potentially open a retail business or invest in more real estate with her sister via the Battle Born Equity Partners business.  Her sister is a real estate broker which is the inspiration for the real estate side and they also purchased a pizza place with the LLC and has had to go through massive renovations.  

Her sister's current CPA is counting the TOTAL commissions on her sales as part of her income but she just gets a percentage via broker fee.. unless he's offsetting the rest of the commission somewhere, I think she's probably paying a lot more tax than she should.  The CPA also said that they weren't allowed to deduct the money they've invested into renovating the business or the expenses on their business? I'm not sure his rationale behind that.  

This will probably be a stock evaluation client similar to what Mark was working on so assigning him this one as well.  She said her sister is also looking for a new CPA with her couple of businesses so could be an easy referral.  

She also asked to keep the items separate so let's make sure we're doing everything as separate work items from the business / individual side.

column93:
Eric is a high school classmate who has a background in accounting.  He says he left the accounting world behind and working in FP&A.. which I would argue is still accounting.  

He's looking for work and has been applying elsewhere but intrigued by what we have going on.  No tax background and unsure of what he's looking for as far as comp.  He said he'd be open to part time roles or keeping the conversation going. 

I think our Resource Pipeline is decently full so I don't know what we have available but I do think this could be a good FGA for internal interview process.  Not sure if we have a template for that but thought Ant had created some sort of application / questionnaire at some point.  Also think we can build out a Work Template to ask for resume and basic hiring info (again, we might already have this) but also to work through the hiring process so let's schedule some time for Peary to speak with you and Matty and see if there's any opportunity / fit.

column50:
Connie is a referral and mother of our client, Sally Wu. She said Sally couldn't speak enough about how great her experience with Motta has been. Connie is in Colorado Springs but think most of her properties are in Texas.  

Connie said her old CPA was very bad and unresponsive.  She said his printer was broken so he couldn't get her tax documents to close on a loan and she lost a deal on a house. She also says he put a lot of properties on Schedule E but I would think she would very much qualify as an RE Professional so we need to see what this fool was doing.  Lots wrong in there. 

Connie is self employed and has 40 properties.  She actively buys, sells, and manages all of the properties (RE Prof).  She also does flips but generally will buy, fix, rent, repeat.  Within the 40 properties, she has Seller Financed, Short Term Rentals, and Long Term Rentals. Think this one is gonna be a big mess.  

She said she had an excel sheet similar to Sally where she tracks everything.  Let's see what that thing looks like. 

I'll send out a request list just to start getting docs because she said she also has an SCorp so might have to jump on this.  

I sent her the intake form as well but wanted to get the doc requests out so we might get an intake form for this one.

column109: This will be a big one so once we get docs, Matt/Nick/Sweeney can help gauge pricing with Sonny running point.

column93: Dat and Mark spoke with Alex Rae on a phone call, we covered the Motta story and vision.  Alex recently was let go from his mortgage broker job but he was only doing it part time for the last 3 years.  He works full time for the Harvard Business School Security Team, analyzing data and providing KPIs.  Similar story to other people we talked to, Alex is tired of corporate world dangling carrot that you never get to eat.  He is open to a career change and looking for a company that he can get behind and his contribution can be more meaningful. Dat and Mark told them they world circle up with the team and get back to him on any potential opportunities with Motta. He could be a good potential part time employee, currently has no tax experience but very knowledgeable in the mortgage space  and said he uses excel daily, not sure to what extent.

column56:
Alex is a referral from Tracey Riley who is responsible for almost all of my success.  Still wasn't able to get a lot of rizz going but still a good meeting.  I gave myself a C and Matty (who listened not on the call but in the background) said B+.  He's an easy grader though. 

Alex is a tax planning client who is essentially a consulting firm in the fire protection space.  They sound similar to us where they are essentially 100% virtual with clients and resources across the US.  

They said they had an "accountant" but he said bookkeeping specifically.  I'm not sure if he has a tax guy so said the conversation was around tax planning.  

Alex & Andy said they are experiencing tremendous growth and was about to get whacked with a huge tax bill last year so they paid out 25% of employee wages in Q4.  They are looking to help build a tax strategy that is more proactive vs reactive.  

He talked about fee structure and I explained that this is generally an intro call and next steps are that we would request some high level documents in order for us to see how much there is to plan for and what they already have in place.  Told him we can either propose a plan for a "Per plan fee" or if you hire us to help implement these strategies than it would be an itemized fee for each part of the plan we implement.  

Matty and I brainstormed a couple strategies (mostly Matty) of: 

(1) Fringe benefits - Things like paying for employee phone, internet.  You're investing in your own people and this could be a good retention, culture, and recruiting tool which are all critical in fast growing start ups. 

(2) Investing infrastructure.  Not sure the compliance requirements for their business or where they are looking to grow but similar to 3PM, they are a consulting firm so if they were to eventually sell, there isn't really much to buy so ROI is lower.  But an idea is to pay for the licensing / registrations for expansion because you're reinvesting into the business and if they were to sell, they are selling the nation wide infrastructure.  Basically creating an asset.  

(2) Low level but if they want to do the profit share plan, at least implement a % profit so even having their plan be more pro active. 

They said they have a 401k and talking through Profit Share options as I took a shot with SEP IRAs and they also brought up another CPA suggesting they buy a farm.  Matty said the additional work in a different industry is not worth it unless you have the time/infrastructure.  I think the plans we brainstormed alone are ways to get the same benefit but create more value into the business.  

I also think we can kick the tires on the Intuit Tax Advisor software if there are any kind of visualizations we can use for this.
column109: See debrief about fee structure but think we do $1,500 - $2,000 gross based on what people feel like the market would rate this product and the time/expertise for crafting a tax strategy like this.
